I only wear Carhart pants.

They're tough, rugged, they look ok (pass for slacks) and they last 10x 
longer than regular jean.  They rock.

Jeans, shorts, over alls, jackets, etc.  They make a wide assortment.  
100% American materials and American made.  Say what you want about the 
gov't, but that means jobs for people that live here so they can put 
food on their tables.

Deepfog wrote:
> There are some things I probably just won't buy American made, such as 
> most of the cars.  As most of you know, I'm hooked on the 
> Volkswagen-Audi-BMW-Mercedez train, I just think they have the best 
> engineering.
>
> But as far as other things made in America, I think it doesn't have to 
> be this way.  We can stop this.  Now I'm not necessarily saying you 
> sitting behind the computer screen reading this.
>
> One of the problems with businesses in America today has been the 
> problem for perhaps the past 150 years, is corporate greed consuming 
> the small businesses and consolidating them.  This happened in farming 
> and is one of the biggest shifts, people moved from the small country 
> to the big cities after that.  What I think needs to happen is a 
> grassroots effort of a massive number of Americans to start 
> manufacturing products in America.
>
> Now some people in the rave scene have entrepeneurial minds and do 
> stuff like t-shirts and party promoting or do clothing stores.  Then 
> the problem becomes when they get big they get tempted to have their 
> clothes manufactured overseas.
>
> Those of you who are digging deep or just reading some of my rants 
> already know about the North American Union plans and the Trans-Texas 
> Corridor they plan on turning into the NAFTA superhighway going from 
> Mexico to Canada with the port of entry for America being in Kansas 
> City.  My point is they're not even close to finishing this yet so it 
> doesn't have to be like Aldous Huxley's world if there are thousands 
> of people like busy little bees starting manufacturing businesses in 
> America.
>
> Right now you can buy jeans made in America for around $40, twice the 
> price you'd pay at Wal-Mart.  It's not that much more expensive and it 
> doesn't take that much to simply look at the labels, see where it's 
> made and try to find out if there's a locally made version that's 
> similar quality.  America's not dead yet.
>
> OK, that's enough for right now, I was going to get into the book I 
> just finished The Deliberate Dumbing Down of America all about the 
> education system but we'll talk about that later.  And I'm not saying 
> you're dumb!  I'm not that smart myself so get over it.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

Ya, I mean, I'm not against genetically modified foods.  My problem is 
we really don't know the long term effects of such. 

You stance on the subject is one we have heard before.  In the 50's they 
sprayed DDT all over.  Right onto kids talking about how safe and 
wonderful it was.  We know how that story ended.  Early adopting is fine 
and you're right, as long as things are labeled correctly, and people 
are given a choice I'm all for it.  Personally, I don't want to early 
adopt with my body.  I'll save that for my computers.

Aspartame has been found to eat holes in brain tissue.

Hydrogenated oils were originally designed to be healthy.  The logic is 
sound.  If pepel are eating oils and it's bad for you, create a single 
chain molecule that only contains half the chain.  Great idea!  
Unfortunately our bodies have no idea how to process a fat chain that's 
been split and augmented with a hydrogen molecule to close it off, so, 
we store it until we figure out what to do.  Typically you don't get rid 
if it until there nothing less then our mysterious chemical factories 
manage to break it down and expel it.  Until then, it's the gut.  Is it 
any wonder we have an obesity problem in this nation?

This is further complicated by the fact that it's VERY hard to buy 
anything in a grocery store outside of organic that doesn't contain 
hydrogenated or partially hydrogenated products.

I would LOVE labeling that right on the front says if it contains trans 
fats, and hydrogenated oils.  It would make my shopping a lot easier.  
It also means that there's a lot of products I won't buy, and those 
companies will pitch a huge fit saying that such labeling will hurt 
their business.  They're 100% right. 

A few years ago I lost a lot of weight.  I did this in a very simple 
way.  I stopped intaking sugar.  This was very hard.  I also stopped 
eating anything with hydrogenated products or trans fats.  I went down 3 
pant sizes in a year without getting off my ass.  The thing with the 
hydrogenated products is we had no idea what the effects were for over 
20 years.  Meanwhile it was saturated into our food supply without any 
notice or warning.


John B wrote:
> I'm all in favor of modern agriculture and high tech foods.  Sucralose 
> and aspratame let me sweeten my coffee and enjoy my coke while adding 
> a few less calories to my waistline.  Modern agriculture, and the 
> distribution network that goes with it, lets me live in the city and 
> do a job that's enjoyable to me without having to worry if I'll have 
> food to last the winter.  And even with the vices I do have, I stand 
> to live a good twenty years longer than people did just a few 
> generations ago... just through plentiful food and nutrition.
>
> I'll happily eat most genetically modified foods... especially if they 
> could figure a way to bring the price of sashimi-grade tuna down.  I 
> do think that organic produce tastes better than that safeway crap 
> though.
>
> But where agribusiness really DOES piss me off is the way they've been 
> fighting tooth-and-nail to prevent stringent labeling requirements for 
> food that does contain genetically modified ingredients, and to water 
> down the standards to certify food as organic.  I'm very much for 
> truth-in-advertising and the right to control what I put in my own 
> body.  And I absolutely loathe the business practice these companies 
> are engaging in to trick me into eating food that I'd probably be 
> perfectly willing to eat anyway.  But if someone *DOES* want to avoid 
> GM foods and *DOES* want to eat all organic foods; then that's their 
> right and no one has any business trying to stop them.  And foodstuffs 
> should be clearly labeled as to exactly what is in them so people can 
> make that decision for themselves.
>
> Regardless of *why* someone might not want to eat something, or wether 
> you think that's an intelligent decision or not, it's downright assy 
> to try to trick someone... hell to fight for the legal RIGHT to trick 
> someone... into eating it.
>
>
> cya,
> john
>
>
> On Sep 30, 2007, at 8:01 AM, Shatter wrote:
>
>> ya, it's late but...
>>
>> I'm more of trying to avoid the trans fats, hydrogenated oils, and 
>> other chemicals put into food for no good reason.  Take a look at the 
>> recent recall on the micro pop corn because the artificial butter 
>> flavoring chemical turned out to be really nasty.  What's wrong with 
>> making butter flavor with, oh i dunno...  butter?
>>
>> Enriching rice with niacin is fine.  So is enriched flour.  I have no 
>> problem with that, though if they didn't bleach the hell out of it in 
>> teh first place, and run it through over processing, why does it need 
>> to be enriched?  What was wrong with it in the first place?
>>
>> As for western medicine, my only issue is the business of treating 
>> problems instead of curing them.  Somebody is overweight and has 
>> cholesterol, so we give them pills instead of making them get off 
>> their ass and go walk around the block.

I'm not too into genetically modified foods myself, especially after =20
hearing stories about the Monsanto corn and how it all spreads through =20
the pollen, I'm not eating corn out of a can anymore, only if it's =20
locally grown.  I am now more and more trying to just get the fruits =20
and vegetables from a farmer's market and the dairy stuff from a real =20
dairy place that has real butter and creamline milk, etc. and there's =20
usually some good local bread places.  basically local, local, and =20
local.  i find places like whole foods too be way too expensive for =20
the most part but you're paying for the convenience of not having to =20
go all around for the healthier stuff.

I'm not too into genetically modified foods myself, especially after =20
hearing stories about the Monsanto corn and how it all spreads through =20
the pollen, I'm not eating corn out of a can anymore, only if it's =20
locally grown.  I am now more and more trying to just get the fruits =20
and vegetables from a farmer's market and the dairy stuff from a real =20
dairy place that has real butter and creamline milk, etc. and there's =20
usually some good local bread places.  basically local, local, and =20
local.  i find places like whole foods too be way too expensive for =20
the most part but you're paying for the convenience of not having to =20
go all around for the healthier stuff.

Quoting Shatter <shatter@sonic.net>:

> Ya, I mean, I'm not against genetically modified foods.  My problem is
> we really don't know the long term effects of such. You stance on the
> subject is one we have heard before.  Hydrogenated oils were =20
> originally designed to be healthy.  The logic is
> sound.  If pepel are eating oils and it's bad for you, create a single
> chain molecule that only contains half the chain.  Great idea!
> Unfortunately our bodies have no idea how to process a fat chain that's
> been split and augmented with a hydrogen molecule to close it off, so,
> we store it until we figure out what to do.  Typically you don't get
> rid if it until there nothing less then our mysterious chemical
> factories manage to break it down and expel it.  Until then, it's the
> gut.  Is it any wonder we have an obesity problem in this nation?
>
> This is further complicated by the fact that it's VERY hard to buy
> anything in a grocery store outside of organic that doesn't contain
> hydrogenated or partially hydrogenated products.
>
> I would LOVE labeling that right on the front says if it contains trans
> fats, and hydrogenated oils.  It would make my shopping a lot easier.
> It also means that there's a lot of products I won't buy, and those
> companies will pitch a huge fit saying that such labeling will hurt
> their business.  They're 100% right. A few years ago I lost a lot of
> weight.  I did this in a very simple way.  I stopped intaking sugar.
> This was very hard.  I also stopped eating anything with hydrogenated
> products or trans fats.  I went down 3 pant sizes in a year without
> getting off my ass.  The thing with the hydrogenated products is we had
> no idea what the effects were for over 20 years.  Meanwhile it was
> saturated into our food supply without any notice or warning.
>
>
> John B wrote:
>> I'm all in favor of modern agriculture and high tech foods.   =20

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

--

Today, we need a nation of Minutemen, citizens who are not only
prepared to take arms, but citizens who regard the preservation of
freedom as the basic purpose of their daily life and who are willing
to consciously work and sacrifice for that freedom.


By calling attention to 'a well regulated militia,' the 'security' of
the nation, and the right of each citizen 'to keep and bear arms,' our
founding fathers recognized the essentially civilian nature of our
economy.  Although it is extremely unlikely that the fears of
governmental tyranny, which gave rise to the Second Amendment, will
ever be a major danger to our nation, the Amendment still remains an
important declaration of our basic civilian-military relationships, in
which every citizen must be ready to participate in the defense of his
country.  For that reason I believe the Second Amendment will always
be important.

- John F. Kennedy

Received: (qmail 43811 invoked from network); 3 Oct 2007 10:17:48 -0000
Message-ID: <4055.71.198.250.91.1191406667.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>
Date: Wed, 3 Oct 2007 03:17:47 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Reply-To: osby@viberation.com
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.10a

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] My WR part 1: LoveFest 07 & the :codeTV stuff :n)

OK.. So Friday night.. i no go out 'cause i wanted to rest for the
loooooong day ahead... my Mom decided that it'd be Groovy to throw my Pops
a bday party since his bday was 2 days prior.. ok.. so hella food, hella
relatives, & GAMBLING!!!  I mean.. they made the garage into a card parlor
& I even had 1 drunk Uncle like going outside every 15 minutes takin' a
piss in the plants!  In the kitchen, my Mom & all my Aunties played
Majong!  So i was pretty much up in my room w/ my cat Pheobe watchin TV &
tryin' to sleep.. but all the laughing & majong tile shuffling & uncles
hitting the card table 'til 4AM kept me up & even still i couldn't sleep
afterwards 'cause i do have fucked up raver weekend sleeping patterns...
so all in all.. i probably managed to get 1/2 an hour sleep if any.. oh
well...

So by 6AM.. i woke up from already being awake & got ready.. i was outta
the house & was at the stage area/ 111 Minna by 8:20... oh yeah.. i saw a
DR Keith Ablo look alike on the BART train... but yeah... hours past, the
floats all slowly came & it all fuckin' went dooooooooown!!! :)

Love Fest 2007
-=-=-=-=-

So this year again.. i was a Wheel Monitor for the BADNB float & that was
pretty easy this year!!  I mean.. last year.. it was really messy getting
people to move over 'cause Hello 2Day.. you'll get hit by the float kinda
dealie.. & i still don't get the need to run directly infront of a moving
vehicle like strait across... wtf is up with that man?  But yeah.. it was
Awesome seein' some of y'all down market while i dragged my tired ass down
the street :)  Actually... seein' y'all got me kinda hyper & oooh.. the
ch00nage that was comin' from the float.. YUMMMY!!!  All the DJs on BADNB
tore it fuckin' UP!!

The procession towards the end was kinda weird this time.. like the City
is getting harder on us float people now & we had to turn off our music
upon entering Civic.. everyone involved with the float had to be riding...
it jus seemed so strict now.. but as soon our music blasted up again...
the same crowd that was following us down market was right there brockin'
the fuck out!!  Loved it!!  Then when we went to our parkin spot on the
corner, the crowd slowly built up.. HELLO 2DAY.. it was so fuckin' ILL!! 
I Loved it!!

I didn't walk around too much, but i did stop over the KONTROL float for a
bit!!  That was Dope!!  YUM!!  Well.. i was there pretty much alot 'cause
i was always sitting on the step @ City Hall... so yeah.. @ one point the
KONTROL float was spinning all this yummy Techno & the float next to it, i
think it was Supper Club, was playing all this Tech House.. I was in Yummy
Heaven!!!  I also did get ice cream.. so that was Pretty Dope also!!
 YAAAAY

I mean.. 'cause of my not so much yummy needed mondo sleep i sohulda got..
i was kinda on edge i guess & kinda tired the whole day & sat as much as
possible during LF... but mixed w/ the hyper i got from seein' every1 I
saw... & the music... i did pretty good stayin' up eerrrr.. awake rather
w/ minimal assistance of caffine.. i barely even had 1 red bull the whole
day know that i think about it.. or drink any coke for that matter.. oh
well... next year i guess! :)

ok

:codetv
=-=-=-=-

In the staging area in the morning from when the parade started, we
managed to get alot of  interveiws with people everywhere all up n down
2nd street.. then after a few hours of running around interviewing people,
then i did my Wheel MOnitor duties...

So then we got to like Civic for the festival part... again... it was
fun... but i was so tired yada yada yada.. i think though... when we all
met up in the VIP Lounge, like well.. i started seein' more and like more
familiar faces.. so that was Fun & it like got me hyper.. then like I
literally jumped on the interview ball & w/in an hour, interviewed like
7-8 DJs & made some new friends!!!

We taped somemore outside.. did some MOS interviews... then everything
just went yummy 'til i had to leave... but it was fulfilling & So Dope to
do that!!!

So my whole LF experience this year was overalll fun!!! YAAAAY




-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Message-ID: <4120.71.198.250.91.1191409605.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>
Date: Wed, 3 Oct 2007 04:06:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] MY WR part 2: HELLO 2DAY: EKLEKTIC!!!!

OK.. so like i had to like cut early from LF to well... i was told to help
"load in" by 6:30 at like Cat Club,  but there really wasn't much to
design the club with when the decorations came in... so we just like
kicked it 'til 8PM... i ended up workin' door for a bit & missed Mikey J's
& someone elses set in the back... but in the front, like ummm.. Frogger
then Jammin were bad ass w/ their breaks & dubstep sets :)

The whole night at EK was fuckin' sick... i mean... i literally felt like
i was Home again 'cause everything just felt so like familiar & missing
from my life.. that whole vibe, that whole feeling of just being
surrounded by my EK familia & the freaks, the punks, the Sat night Folsum
st club hoppers, & everyone who was there!!!

OK.. in the back, like everyone spun bad ass sets, no doubt, but as soon
as Star Eyes got on the decks... i mean.. this girl does not hold back &
she just went strait up hard, jumpy, techy, all that yummy jungle shit I
love well.. 4Real spun a bad ass set too I mean.. he totallly broke the
back room for me 'cause he always drops the choonage i Love dancing too...
but it felt more like home when Star Eyes was up there & I swear... i was
dancinmg my ass off!!!  Sage went on after her & continued the fuckin'
madness... ooh man.... i hella had music gasms dancing & the whoooole
floor was brokin' out heeella hard!!!

Up front... like Felix got on the decks & played hella Techno... which was
funny 'cause well.. well.. alota people weren't used to it... Then.. OK..
Hello 2Day.. when Ms. E got on.. she kinda started out kinda like plunky
minimal kinda breaks.. but built up from there...  UFO spun in both
rooms.. in the front, he dropped alota breaks mixed with alota 4 on the
floor craaaazy beats he made.. it was fuckin' sick!!!  OK.. then in the
back room... he dropped alooooooota well.. i call his music marching band
dnb 'cause that's what it sounds like...

OK... I gotta go step by step here 'cause it just well... where everything
got reeeeeally emotional...  the music up front stopped, so everyo9ne
headed to the back to brock out to UFO... alota people were gone, so like
1/2 the club was still there, & that's alota people still... so were in
the back hella dancing our asses off.. UFO started droppin' classics... MC
Duh was on the mic & oh yeah... Audio Angel was MCing to & they switched
off alot... but yeah.. so UFO's spinning, Duh's spitting... & everything
just got way nostalgic & i hella got that feeling in my tummy like i was
nervous, but excited.. & we were all dancing, yelling, some of us were in
tears 'cause it was like the last set & we knew it... but like the GS crew
was back there & we were just lookin' @ each other smiling & dancing &
laughing & it was like 1 of them moments, ya know?!  Then the music
stopped 'cause the bouncer made that hand gesture knife across the neck
motion & alota us just stood there for a sec then like looked @ each other
& hugged.,... ya know... it was seriously like touching 'cause yeah...

But fuck man... it was just fuckin' Sick!!  I mean... i've gone through
alot w/ GS & each person in it.. like ummmm... I can't properly describe
what i felt during UFO's set, excpet that it was just fuckin' Ill!!!  I
can honestly say that I was more touched & inspired at Eklektic than i was
@ LoveFest This year... i mean.. LP/ LF always gave me this mondo buzz
days/ weeks after, but shit man... I been soooo fuckin' like hardcore
mondo afterglowin high from Eklektic just 'cause that night/ early morning
touched me sooo much in yet ways i can't still describe, ok.. well.. being
with alota people i hardcore Love is 1 of them.. the music... jsut
everything i guess... reflecting on all the nostalgia & yet looking foward
to what's gonna happen next i guess too... I mean.. does that make sense?

All i know is that i had a bad ass Groovy time, all the people i gave
flyers to @ LF were there... the vibe was sooo thick of people excited to
be there, & the music.. oh my fuckin' goodness.. Mondo Fuckin Ill!!!  For
me personally, i just felt all these emotions inside swirling around &
danced harder than i have in a long time that night 'cause there was
something spiritual i was feeling & just alota fluffy yummy goodnes man!!!


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] constructivism examples as well as an introduction

--_90f46c20-6616-4c08-8175-ef97ed04ad52_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


Good morning friends!

To the SF heads, I am new to the list and am a techno dj/party thrower on t=
he east coast. Your input would be much appreciated.

IMO,
new ideas from people all over on how parties should look/feel/sound is
very welcome. I am very interested in new ideas and concepts so we
don't fall into the same old same old trap.

Of late I have been intrigued by
minimal flyer design, specifically along the lines of constructivism,
and of course the work mathew hawtin and the m_nus crew.
Are they are examples out there on teh internets that you find intriguing, =
compelling/exciting/titilating ?
if so, send me links!
And of course, any discussion regarding things that you would like to see b=
eing done at parties besides the usual is always a good thing!



thank you!


Sinestro

A kissing booth filled with goth girls in latex
catsuits!!


But on a more serious note, interactive environmentals
are a neet-o thing -- they can be as simple a long
drapes with projections on them that the audience can
move, thusly creating a different appearance, or as
complex as stuff on this site:
http://www.interactivearchitecture.org/

It's hard to beat the wow factor of an interactive
environment.

Subject: [sfraves] srr: Howl against censorship

>From today's Chronicle

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/10/03/MN0PSIM67.DTL

"Fifty years ago today, a San Francisco Municipal
Court judge ruled that Allen Ginsberg's Beat-era poem
"Howl" was not obscene. Yet today, a New York public
broadcasting station decided not to air the poem,
fearing that the Federal Communications Commission
will find it indecent and crush the network with
crippling fines.

Instead of broadcasting the poem on the air today, New
York listener-supported radio station WBAI will
include a reading of the poem in a special online-only
program called "Howl Against Censorship." It will be
posted on www.pacifica.org, the Internet home of the
Berkeley-based Pacifica Foundation, because online
sites do not fall under the FCC's purview."

"Howl Against Censorship?"  How ironic...



-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Where the First Amendment is implicated, the tie goes to the
speaker, not the censor"
- Chief Justice John Roberts, commenting on the McCain-Feingold
law, the same day the high court ruled 5-4 against student
Joseph Frederick in his suspension for showing a "Bong Hits
4 Jesus" banner.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Oct.6th [KONTROL] w/ DAN BELL (3hr set) + Billy Dalessandro (live)!

Saturday, October 6th, 2007

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


featuring from Detroit via Berlin:

DANIEL BELL aka DBX

( Accellerate . Tresor . Logistic . Peacefrog . 7th City . Perlon )

Rightfully considered to be one of the pioneers of the minimal techno
genre, the legendary Daniel Bell returns to SF for an unprecedented
fourth appearance at [KONTROL].  Dan, whom we jokingly refer to as our
"unofficial 5th resident", is just so damn good, we'd probably book
him every month if he'd let us.


and from Chicago:

BILLY DALESSANDRO  :  LIVE

( SiteHolder . Harthouse . Force Inc . Resopal )

SiteHolder Records' Billy Dallessandro has devastated the decks of SF
a few times in the last year, but he's never played here LIVE... until
now. In support of his third long player "Into The Atom" just released
on Harthouse, this talented and prolific artist is coming prepared to
give us a serious live set lashing


and [KONTROL] residents:

SAMMY D  ( Classic . Utensil )
CRAIG KUNA   ( Concept SF . ESDJCO )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )
NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )


________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

[ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28F.jpg

Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28B.jpg


____________________________________________________


DANIEL BELL (aka DBX)

Born in Sacramento, California, Daniel Bell grew up outside of
Toronto, Canada, and then moved to Detroit where he collaborated with
Richie Hawtin as Cybersonik for three years on Plus 8 Records. In
1991, he started his own label, Accelerate, on which he released his
influential releases as DBX. Based on nearby Chicago "track" records,
he reduced that sound further into funky, streamlined grooves. The
formula proved to be successful and helped launch a new aesthetic in
techno and house music known as "minimal".

With the overwhelming success of his "Losing Control" single in 1994,
Daniel set up 7th City Distribution in order to assist smaller Midwest
labels to get distribution in overseas markets. He also created three
new labels - 7th City, Elevate and Harmonie Park. In 2000, he
relocated to Berlin, Germany, and released his first mix CD, "The
Button-Down Mind of Daniel Bell", on Tresor Records, followed in 2003
by "The Button-Down Mind Strikes Back!" He since has produced a series
of remixes for a diverse range of artists, includng John Tejada,
Pantytec, Akufen and John Thomas. He has spent the last 3 years
traveling and DJing around the world.

Dan is playing a grand total of five gigs in North America in 2007.
We are truly honored to be able to say two of them are for us. To be
honest, we'll pretty much book this guy anytime he's available...he's
just that good!  His last appearance in January (with Matthew
Dear/Audion live) was probably the craziest any of us had EVER seen
the Endup.  What's in store this time? I guess we'll have to find out.


Daniel Bell's website:
http://www.daniel-bell.com/

Daniel Bell's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Daniel%20Bell

Daniel Bell interview @ InTheMix.com:
http://www.inthemix.com.au/features/23336/


MUSIC:

DBX - Phreak  (mp3 sample)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Phreak.mp3

DBX - Losing Control  (mp3 sample)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Losing_Control.mp3

Daniel Bell - Live @ Movement (DEMF) 2006  (real audio)
http://www.demf.com/sounds/2006/hmay/05-27-06_danielbell_movement06.ram


________________________________________________


BILLY DALESSANDRO (aka Huge Hephner)

Chicago native Billy Dalessandro first brought his unique production
style to the forefront of the electronic music community in 2002. The
five years since then have seen him release two full length albums,
nearly 20 original EPs, and a slew of remixes. His works have found
their way into the record bags of many respectable DJs, as well as
some of the most prestigious jocks' compilations.

Recently he established his own labels Siteholder and UnCut with
friends Brian Ffar and Daniel Mnookin which have already gained
massive feedback on each of the 7 releases. Standouts include "Don`t
Sleep" on SH001 and "That Trick She Knows" on SH002, both of which
were charted and played by many top DJs.  His latest release
"Blackjack" on Sonicutlure 006 is a jacking dancefloor bomb.

Billy will be in Europe from mid October to early December in support
of his just-released LP on Harthouse, after which he'll make stops in
select US cities. "Into the Atom", Dalessandro's third full length
album, takes listeners on a voyage into the bits and pieces of what
separates the average tracks from the very best.  Similar to the role
an atom plays in the molecular build up of all things on this planet,
the release exemplifies the minute twists and turns Dalessandro takes
with his music that help define him as among the true artists in the
production field.  It separates those who build the bandwagon from
those who wait until its completion to hop aboard.  Billy undeniably
belongs to the former of the two.


SiteHolder Records Website:
www.siteholder.net

Billy Dalessandro's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Billy%20Dalessandro

Billy Dalessandro interview in ResidentAdviser.net:
http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature-read.aspx?id=734

MySpace profiles:
www.myspace.com/billydalessandro
www.myspace.com/siteholder

Music samples on Beatport.com
http://www.beatport.com/Billy%20Dalessandro

http://www.kontrolsf.com

Here it is folks....

Bam and the greasy tan naked man!   (not work friendly, duh)

http://www.kontrolsf.com/GB/LF07/bam_and_naked_man.jpg

I hear that by day this guy is a gynecologist.  ...eeeww.

...not Bam, dummy, the other guy. ;)



Thanks to everyone that made it out to dance by our float and
supported at the afterparty.  I haven't had that much fun in a long
time.

We'll definitely be back next year!


Here's a couple lil' videos from our float.

My roommate J.Phlip made the song in the background, and Worthy from
dirtybird is the guy taking the video.
http://tinyurl.com/35aj8k

Here's another vid from later on when Claude VonStroke hopped on to
tag with Alland for a bit...
http://tinyurl.com/3x4ruy

I have a few more cool vids that i took myself, but some are too big
(over 100mb) to put up on YouTube.  Does anyone know how to shrink the
res or crop .mov files to make them smaller?


Man, what a fun day!  Already looking forward to 2008!

Thanks again, everyone.

i think if i could write the man in this picture a letter, it would say
this:

"dear sir, while i do not fully understand your decision to dress [sic] in
this manner while in public, i nonetheless respect your right to do so,
especially in this fine city, and almost even admire the courage it must
take to face the world as god made you.  my only question for you is
this:  i can clearly see the tip of your appendage, but.. um, how shall i
phrase this... where's the rest?"

seriously, tho. you'd think if you were hung like a pencil eraser you'd be
hiding that shit in shame for eternity. not this guy.  where are all the
naked dudes with the bigass johnsons hanging halfway to their knees?  you
never see that shit. it's always these tiny dick mofos that feel the need to
show 'em off.

so what makes these dudes want to do this? really, can someone explain it to
me?

entertaining, no doubt, either way.

maybe they just like making people smile and laugh.  the last true
humanitarians. ;)


-------? gb


p.s.  since were already sharing pics, i might as well throw this one in
too.

you can tell this guy means business... he's wearing his minimal scarf.
http://www.kontrolsf.com/GB/LF07/all_you_need.jpg

>=20
> Saturday, October 6th, 2007
>=20
> [ K O N T R O L ]
>=20
> minimal techno + avant-house
> every 1st Saturday @ The Endup
>=20
>=20
> featuring from Detroit via Berlin:
>=20
> DANIEL BELL aka DBX
>=20
> ( Accellerate . Tresor . Logistic . Peacefrog . 7th City . Perlon )
>=20
> Rightfully considered to be one of the pioneers of the minimal techno
> genre, the legendary Daniel Bell returns to SF for an unprecedented
> fourth appearance at [KONTROL].  Dan, whom we jokingly refer to as our
> "unofficial 5th resident", is just so damn good, we'd probably book
> him every month if he'd let us.
>=20
>=20
> and from Chicago:
>=20
> BILLY DALESSANDRO  :  LIVE
>=20
> ( SiteHolder . Harthouse . Force Inc . Resopal )
>=20
> SiteHolder Records' Billy Dallessandro has devastated the decks of SF
> a few times in the last year, but he's never played here LIVE... until
> now. In support of his third long player "Into The Atom" just released
> on Harthouse, this talented and prolific artist is coming prepared to
> give us a serious live set lashing
>=20
>=20
> and [KONTROL] residents:
>=20
> SAMMY D  ( Classic . Utensil )
> CRAIG KUNA   ( Concept SF . ESDJCO )
> ALLAND BYALLO   ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )
> NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )
>=20
>=20
> ________________________________________________
>=20
> The ENDUP
> 401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
> 10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
> http://www.theendup.com
>=20
> FREE until 11pm!
>=20
> ____________________________________________________
>=20
>=20
> Full bios, pics and FREE music:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com
>=20
> [KONTROL] on MySpace:
> http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf
>=20
> [ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
> http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/
>=20
> Flyer front:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28F.jpg
>=20
> Flyer back:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28B.jpg
>=20
>=20
> ____________________________________________________
>=20
>=20
> DANIEL BELL (aka DBX)
>=20
> Born in Sacramento, California, Daniel Bell grew up outside of
> Toronto, Canada, and then moved to Detroit where he collaborated with
> Richie Hawtin as Cybersonik for three years on Plus 8 Records. In
> 1991, he started his own label, Accelerate, on which he released his
> influential releases as DBX. Based on nearby Chicago "track" records,
> he reduced that sound further into funky, streamlined grooves. The
> formula proved to be successful and helped launch a new aesthetic in
> techno and house music known as "minimal".
>=20
> With the overwhelming success of his "Losing Control" single in 1994,
> Daniel set up 7th City Distribution in order to assist smaller Midwest
> labels to get distribution in overseas markets. He also created three
> new labels - 7th City, Elevate and Harmonie Park. In 2000, he
> relocated to Berlin, Germany, and released his first mix CD, "The
> Button-Down Mind of Daniel Bell", on Tresor Records, followed in 2003
> by "The Button-Down Mind Strikes Back!" He since has produced a series
> of remixes for a diverse range of artists, includng John Tejada,
> Pantytec, Akufen and John Thomas. He has spent the last 3 years
> traveling and DJing around the world.
>=20
> Dan is playing a grand total of five gigs in North America in 2007.
> We are truly honored to be able to say two of them are for us. To be
> honest, we'll pretty much book this guy anytime he's available...he's
> just that good!  His last appearance in January (with Matthew
> Dear/Audion live) was probably the craziest any of us had EVER seen
> the Endup.  What's in store this time? I guess we'll have to find out.
>=20
>=20
> Daniel Bell's website:
> http://www.daniel-bell.com/
>=20
> Daniel Bell's discography:
> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Daniel%20Bell
>=20
> Daniel Bell interview @ InTheMix.com:
> http://www.inthemix.com.au/features/23336/
>=20
>=20
> MUSIC:
>=20
> DBX - Phreak  (mp3 sample)
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Phreak.mp3
>=20
> DBX - Losing Control  (mp3 sample)
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Losing_Control.mp3
>=20
> Daniel Bell - Live @ Movement (DEMF) 2006  (real audio)
> http://www.demf.com/sounds/2006/hmay/05-27-06_danielbell_movement06.ram
>=20
>=20
> ________________________________________________
>=20
>=20
> BILLY DALESSANDRO (aka Huge Hephner)
>=20
> Chicago native Billy Dalessandro first brought his unique production
> style to the forefront of the electronic music community in 2002. The
> five years since then have seen him release two full length albums,
> nearly 20 original EPs, and a slew of remixes. His works have found
> their way into the record bags of many respectable DJs, as well as
> some of the most prestigious jocks' compilations.
>=20
> Recently he established his own labels Siteholder and UnCut with
> friends Brian Ffar and Daniel Mnookin which have already gained
> massive feedback on each of the 7 releases. Standouts include "Don`t
> Sleep" on SH001 and "That Trick She Knows" on SH002, both of which
> were charted and played by many top DJs.  His latest release
> "Blackjack" on Sonicutlure 006 is a jacking dancefloor bomb.
>=20
> Billy will be in Europe from mid October to early December in support
> of his just-released LP on Harthouse, after which he'll make stops in
> select US cities. "Into the Atom", Dalessandro's third full length
> album, takes listeners on a voyage into the bits and pieces of what
> separates the average tracks from the very best.  Similar to the role
> an atom plays in the molecular build up of all things on this planet,
> the release exemplifies the minute twists and turns Dalessandro takes
> with his music that help define him as among the true artists in the
> production field.  It separates those who build the bandwagon from
> those who wait until its completion to hop aboard.  Billy undeniably
> belongs to the former of the two.
>=20
>=20
> SiteHolder Records Website:
> www.siteholder.net
>=20
> Billy Dalessandro's Discography:
> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Billy%20Dalessandro
>=20
> Billy Dalessandro interview in ResidentAdviser.net:
> http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature-read.aspx?id=3D734
>=20

>=20

>> Date: Wed, 3 Oct 2007 17:14:15 -0700
>> From: bird415@gmail.com
>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Oct.6th [KONTROL] w/ DAN BELL (3hr set) + Bi=
lly Dalessandro (live)!
>>
>> Saturday, October 6th, 2007
>>
>> [ K O N T R O L ]
>>
>> minimal techno + avant-house
>> every 1st Saturday @ The Endup
>>
>>
>> featuring from Detroit via Berlin:
>>
>> DANIEL BELL aka DBX
>>
>> ( Accellerate . Tresor . Logistic . Peacefrog . 7th City . Perlon )
>>
>> Rightfully considered to be one of the pioneers of the minimal techno
>> genre, the legendary Daniel Bell returns to SF for an unprecedented
>> fourth appearance at [KONTROL]. Dan, whom we jokingly refer to as our
>> "unofficial 5th resident", is just so damn good, we'd probably book
>> him every month if he'd let us.
>>
>>
>> and from Chicago:
>>
>> BILLY DALESSANDRO : LIVE
>>
>> ( SiteHolder . Harthouse . Force Inc . Resopal )
>>
>> SiteHolder Records' Billy Dallessandro has devastated the decks of SF
>> a few times in the last year, but he's never played here LIVE... until
>> now. In support of his third long player "Into The Atom" just released
>> on Harthouse, this talented and prolific artist is coming prepared to
>> give us a serious live set lashing
>>
>>
>> and [KONTROL] residents:
>>
>> SAMMY D ( Classic . Utensil )
>> CRAIG KUNA ( Concept SF . ESDJCO )
>> ALLAND BYALLO ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )
>> NIKOLA BAYTALA ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )
>>
>>
>> ________________________________________________
>>
>> The ENDUP
>> 401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
>> 10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
>> http://www.theendup.com
>>
>> FREE until 11pm!
>>
>> ____________________________________________________
>>
>>
>> Full bios, pics and FREE music:
>> http://www.kontrolsf.com
>>
>> [KONTROL] on MySpace:
>> http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf
>>
>> [ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
>> http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/
>>
>> Flyer front:
>> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28F.jpg
>>
>> Flyer back:
>> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28B.jpg
>>
>>
>> ____________________________________________________
>>
>>
>> DANIEL BELL (aka DBX)
>>
>> Born in Sacramento, California, Daniel Bell grew up outside of
>> Toronto, Canada, and then moved to Detroit where he collaborated with
>> Richie Hawtin as Cybersonik for three years on Plus 8 Records. In
>> 1991, he started his own label, Accelerate, on which he released his
>> influential releases as DBX. Based on nearby Chicago "track" records,
>> he reduced that sound further into funky, streamlined grooves. The
>> formula proved to be successful and helped launch a new aesthetic in
>> techno and house music known as "minimal".
>>
>> With the overwhelming success of his "Losing Control" single in 1994,
>> Daniel set up 7th City Distribution in order to assist smaller Midwest
>> labels to get distribution in overseas markets. He also created three
>> new labels - 7th City, Elevate and Harmonie Park. In 2000, he
>> relocated to Berlin, Germany, and released his first mix CD, "The
>> Button-Down Mind of Daniel Bell", on Tresor Records, followed in 2003
>> by "The Button-Down Mind Strikes Back!" He since has produced a series
>> of remixes for a diverse range of artists, includng John Tejada,
>> Pantytec, Akufen and John Thomas. He has spent the last 3 years
>> traveling and DJing around the world.
>>
>> Dan is playing a grand total of five gigs in North America in 2007.
>> We are truly honored to be able to say two of them are for us. To be
>> honest, we'll pretty much book this guy anytime he's available...he's
>> just that good! His last appearance in January (with Matthew
>> Dear/Audion live) was probably the craziest any of us had EVER seen
>> the Endup. What's in store this time? I guess we'll have to find out.
>>
>>
>> Daniel Bell's website:
>> http://www.daniel-bell.com/
>>
>> Daniel Bell's discography:
>> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Daniel%20Bell
>>
>> Daniel Bell interview @ InTheMix.com:
>> http://www.inthemix.com.au/features/23336/
>>
>>
>> MUSIC:
>>
>> DBX - Phreak (mp3 sample)
>> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Phreak.mp3
>>
>> DBX - Losing Control (mp3 sample)
>> http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Losing_Control.mp3
>>
>> Daniel Bell - Live @ Movement (DEMF) 2006 (real audio)
>> http://www.demf.com/sounds/2006/hmay/05-27-06_danielbell_movement06.ram
>>
>>
>> ________________________________________________
>>
>>
>> BILLY DALESSANDRO (aka Huge Hephner)
>>
>> Chicago native Billy Dalessandro first brought his unique production
>> style to the forefront of the electronic music community in 2002. The
>> five years since then have seen him release two full length albums,
>> nearly 20 original EPs, and a slew of remixes. His works have found
>> their way into the record bags of many respectable DJs, as well as
>> some of the most prestigious jocks' compilations.
>>
>> Recently he established his own labels Siteholder and UnCut with
>> friends Brian Ffar and Daniel Mnookin which have already gained
>> massive feedback on each of the 7 releases. Standouts include "Don`t
>> Sleep" on SH001 and "That Trick She Knows" on SH002, both of which
>> were charted and played by many top DJs. His latest release
>> "Blackjack" on Sonicutlure 006 is a jacking dancefloor bomb.
>>
>> Billy will be in Europe from mid October to early December in support
>> of his just-released LP on Harthouse, after which he'll make stops in
>> select US cities. "Into the Atom", Dalessandro's third full length
>> album, takes listeners on a voyage into the bits and pieces of what
>> separates the average tracks from the very best. Similar to the role
>> an atom plays in the molecular build up of all things on this planet,
>> the release exemplifies the minute twists and turns Dalessandro takes
>> with his music that help define him as among the true artists in the
>> production field. It separates those who build the bandwagon from
>> those who wait until its completion to hop aboard. Billy undeniably
>> belongs to the former of the two.
>>
>>
>> SiteHolder Records Website:
>> www.siteholder.net
>>
>> Billy Dalessandro's Discography:
>> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Billy%20Dalessandro
>>
>> Billy Dalessandro interview in ResidentAdviser.net:
>> http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature-read.aspx?id=3D734
>>
>> MySpace profiles:
>> www.myspace.com/billydalessandro
>> www.myspace.com/siteholder
>>
>> Music samples on Beatport.com
>> http://www.beatport.com/Billy%20Dalessandro
>>
>>
>> _____________________________________________________
>>
>> http://www.kontrolsf.com

and i'll hook it up. :)  i'm assuming you'll have a camera along then?
;)

should be a fun one.  dan's playing 1 - 4am, with billy's SF live set
debut to follow.  if you haven't heard billy, you're in for a treat!
he's bad ass.

for the rest of you po' folk.... the party is FREE until 11pm!

the always-stellar Nikola Baytala plays 10-11 too, followed by Craig,
then Sammy, so it's not like you're gonna have to sit thru a bunch of
crap.  come down early and spend those first $15 at the bar instead of
the door. beer is good for you.

> >> "Blackjack" on Sonicutlure 006 is a jacking dancefloor bomb.
> >>
> >> Billy will be in Europe from mid October to early December in support
> >> of his just-released LP on Harthouse, after which he'll make stops in
> >> select US cities. "Into the Atom", Dalessandro's third full length
> >> album, takes listeners on a voyage into the bits and pieces of what
> >> separates the average tracks from the very best. Similar to the role
> >> an atom plays in the molecular build up of all things on this planet,
> >> the release exemplifies the minute twists and turns Dalessandro takes
> >> with his music that help define him as among the true artists in the
> >> production field. It separates those who build the bandwagon from
> >> those who wait until its completion to hop aboard. Billy undeniably
> >> belongs to the former of the two.
> >>
> >>
> >> SiteHolder Records Website:
> >> www.siteholder.net
> >>
> >> Billy Dalessandro's Discography:
> >> http://www.discogs.com/artist/Billy%20Dalessandro
> >>
> >> Billy Dalessandro interview in ResidentAdviser.net:
> >> http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature-read.aspx?id=3D734
> >>
> >> MySpace profiles:
> >> www.myspace.com/billydalessandro
> >> www.myspace.com/siteholder

--0-1359321343-1191516991=:21965

+1 on all that. i had a lot of fun at this party. i had kinda just planned to stop by and drop off flyers to forest, but i ended up dancing my ass off and closing the place down! fortunately i missed the minimal/micro stuff (not really my style) and showed up in time to catch chel-c's super melodic all-hardware dopeness. those were some good tunes, almost proggy at times, but with enough of an edge to stay in the land of delicious techno beats. then forest came on and just blew the place up. *that* is dancefloor techno, imo. i bounced until the lights came up. 

fun night indeed, and a bit unexpected.

it was a sweet bonus running into nico, squelchy, covert, and the rest of the homies. see you all soon :)

love,
mo

nico <nico@viberation.com> wrote: What a fun night.

Was getting bummed about the minimal house.  Heard a few really great bass-heavy tracks and I started getting my hopes up.

Chel-C rocked it.  It was good beat-driven techno with melodic overlays.  Reminded me of the way Veanne would play her jungle.

Then Forrest came and threw it down.  I had to leave because my old bones need to be ready for tomorrow.  No way I can survive that onslaught if I pre-party too hard.

k, if that's how you girls do techno, do it all day and all night.  I had so much fun.

OH MY GOD SUCH A GOOD OMEN.

love always

n i c o

p.s. Some sensitive kid named Andy who goes by Toro Toro got all butthurt because I said minimal is not techno, and I said it was basically acid house, weak beat, or microhouse.  I'm not sure which set him off but he wasn't having it.

AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Where the First Amendment is implicated, the tie goes to the
speaker, not the censor"
- Chief Justice John Roberts, commenting on the McCain-Feingold
law, the same day the high court ruled 5-4 against student
Joseph Frederick in his suspension for showing a "Bong Hits
4 Jesus" banner.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

fun and enjoyed my music too.

weird. But great!  I'm trying not to question it.

exercise.  ;)

I have a strong interest in this area.  Specifically, I'm interested in using image processing and pattern recogntion tools generally employed in surveillance and security applications to drive projections and visualizations, lighting, or even robots or other stuff.

I also have access to some hi res cameras, computers, and related kit...but not as much free time too code stuff up as I'd like.  Anyone else interested in this sort of thing?

----- Original Message ----
From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>

A kissing booth filled with goth girls in latex
catsuits!!


But on a more serious note, interactive environmentals
are a neet-o thing -- they can be as simple a long
drapes with projections on them that the audience can
move, thusly creating a different appearance, or as
complex as stuff on this site:
http://www.interactivearchitecture.org/

It's hard to beat the wow factor of an interactive
environment.

We just added Fumiya Tanaka's set from April's Filter party at Fat
City to the Freqbox music player. It's been a long time coming, but
it's been definately worth the wait.

Check it out by visiting the Freqbox Music Feed on :: freqbox.net

Streams beautifully. No downloads necessary.

Enjoy!!

Their material is finally available in a digital format thanks to all
the global bridgebuilding going on in the techno world.

http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Where the First Amendment is implicated, the tie goes to the
speaker, not the censor"
- Chief Justice John Roberts, commenting on the McCain-Feingold
law, the same day the high court ruled 5-4 against student
Joseph Frederick in his suspension for showing a "Bong Hits
4 Jesus" banner.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Where the First Amendment is implicated, the tie goes to the

law, the same day the high court ruled 5-4 against student
Joseph Frederick in his suspension for showing a "Bong Hits
4 Jesus" banner.

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: I'm DJing at the Heat The Street Faire (SF's Burning Man
 Decompression Party) this Sunday

Hey lovelies!
I just wanted to inform you all that I will be DJing on the 19th Street Stage 
for this year's San Francisco Burning Man Decompression party (see 
http://www.burningman.com/blackrockcity_yearround/special_events/decompression/decom2007.html 
for the details.)  I promise to make you wanna shake it, probably keeping it 
funky and inspiring this time around, maybe with some breaks, house and electro 
in there (even though it's a pretty short set.)  I go on from 5:10p until 5:55p 
when The Evolution Control Committee (one of THE ORIGINAL mashup artists) takes 
over.

$10 donation in Black Rock Couture/Costume; $20 in streetwear.  All ages 
outdoors; kids under 12 absolutely free!  Outdoor sound ends at Mariposa Stage 
at 11pm; 10pm other outside areas.

Age 21+ inside Cocomo (club closes 1:30am.)

Looking forward to seeing you all there!!  Be sure to say Hi!  I'll be passing 
out some homemade gifts as well as Mix CDs too!  Be sure to introduce yourself 
if we haven't already met.

Be happy!!


http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php 
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Where the First Amendment is implicated, the tie goes to the
speaker, not the censor"
- Chief Justice John Roberts, commenting on the McCain-Feingold
law, the same day the high court ruled 5-4 against student
Joseph Frederick in his suspension for showing a "Bong Hits
4 Jesus" banner.

-- 
"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Moderation follow-up (from mr. moderator)

Hey everyone,

Following up from my message last friday...

Since late tuesday I put back in a daily post limit, 12 posts. I 
looked back over the last few months and virtually everyone 
doesn't exceed that regularly. You all probably haven't even 
noticed it so I'm assuming this isn't a problem.

What this will do is keep people from treating this list as 
their instant messenger, which tends to cause some of the 
problems. Since we are in a bit of an antiquated form of 
communication...an email list, it's appropriate to use a little 
bit of restraint and thought in posting, which most of you 
already do.

I've always said I draw the line at personal attacks. Calling 
random people "cunts", is an example of crossing that line. But 
I suspect we've all moved on from that now.

Hopefully you all are cool with what I've done.

So onto parties:

Not a lot of posts about lovefest, what did you all do? I 
actually had fun at the mega-kiddie massive, although it was a 
spectacle of Barnum & Bailey proportions. The production 
environment was spot-on and professional though. Would be a 
little nice if it were that easy for all the UG parties. 
Although, I guess it's alot more fun & rewarding to 
scrap shit together like Macguyver. ;-)

We got some good events coming up, Evil Breaks on Oct 20th @ 
DNA, Ambient Mafia's 8 year anniversary on Nov 10th. And a bunch of 
parties Halloween weekend. I'll be at Andrew Phelan's Tonal 
party on Oct 27th. And a little bird told me Meat Meat Manifesto 
is playing another UG on the same night.

Not sure about NYE, anyone got any plans?

take care,

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
SFRaves moderator | http://www.sfraves.org

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

SFravers / SFBay604 Listees

I'm hoping that yall could keep an eye out for me over the next days and 
weeks for some hot gear-- my home was broken into this last Tuesday and 
most of my audio equipment and dj studio was stolen.

If you see anyone selling a pair of Technics SL DZ-1200s (cjds), and or 
a Pioneer DJM800, please let me know.  I have the serial numbers and 
they have been reported to the police.  The mixer is less than a year 
old, pristine condition.  The CDJs are about 2 years old.  Please let me 
know if you see anyone selling these items in a used condition in the 
near future.

DJs-- take pictures of, and record your serial numbers!

my email is geoff_herbst@yahoo.com  if any of you come across any leads.

Thanks for listening!

Geoff

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Voting, Texas Style

So, I thought that usually when you break rules you end up experiencing 
the consequences of doing so.  Apparently this is not the case for the 
folks in the Texas Legislature.  Apparently they feel that they are 
above petty little rules and things.  (But isn't that how politicians 
seem to have felt for a LONG time??  And do you suppose this sort of 
view might have SOMETHING to do with the utter lack of faith in 
the political system?)

You tell me.  Or, actually, why not let the video do the talking:
http://www.joketribe.com/externalVids/Voting.Texas.Legislature.Style.php

Apparently this is why most empires don't last much more than 200 years.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Moderation follow-up (from mr. moderator)

my Lovefest review:

this was the first year since 2004 that Evil Breaks hasn't been
involved with a float AND afterparty, so i signed up as a float
monitor for the parade.  it was fun and i was assigned three awesome
floats:  Bay Area Drum and Bass, Kontrol/Auralism and The
Bounce/Bayraves.

BADNB had an incredible FSound sound system and if you went by their
float at the Civic Center, you saw just how rocking their float was.
Kontrol was a lot of fun to walk with/dance with as it went down
Market street and I finally met Greg (see photo of me with tan penis
man).  the Bounce/Bayraves float had several friends playing/dancing
on it and it was good to see them out, as well.

once we hit the Civic Center i quickly went about destroying the
beverages in my backpack.  i spent most of the time around the Space
Cowboys Unimog, which i hadn't expected...but so many friends were
there i just couldn't resist.

around sundown, Tim, Eva and Anat went over to eat some pho...and
halfway through my meal i realized i was way drunker than i thought.
i texted some friends and bounced over to an apartment in Russian Hill
and promptly passed out on a futon.

fast foward to 11pm and i quickly pulled myself together and ran over
to Eklectic at the Cat Club.  that party was AWESOME!  so many old
friends and an incredible vibe.  hands in the air type dnb party.  i
really miss that shit.  stayed there until it closed and then walked
over to the Experiement at Fat City.

ran into the breaks homies and hung out for a bit inside and chatting
outside.  around 6am we bounced to a friends house and then...off to
the daytime renegade in Hunter's Point!

that was another incredibly fun time and by this time...i was in a
very "festive" mood and probably got bammed harder than i have in a
very, very long time.

by the end of the day, i had lost my cell phone, jacket, hat AND
tshirt and was stranded at my buddy's place in the lower haight.

7am monday morning i woke up and had to walk back to my car in SOMA
because i remembered that i'd parked in a yellow tow-away zone.

it was a seriously fun weekend and i'm glad i got to see so many
friendly faces!  crazy times for sure!


On 10/4/07, Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> Hey everyone,
>
> Following up from my message last friday...
>
> Since late tuesday I put back in a daily post limit, 12 posts. I
> looked back over the last few months and virtually everyone
> doesn't exceed that regularly. You all probably haven't even
> noticed it so I'm assuming this isn't a problem.
>
> What this will do is keep people from treating this list as
> their instant messenger, which tends to cause some of the
> problems. Since we are in a bit of an antiquated form of
> communication...an email list, it's appropriate to use a little
> bit of restraint and thought in posting, which most of you
> already do.
>
> I've always said I draw the line at personal attacks. Calling
> random people "cunts", is an example of crossing that line. But
> I suspect we've all moved on from that now.
>
> Hopefully you all are cool with what I've done.
>
> So onto parties:
>
> Not a lot of posts about lovefest, what did you all do? I
> actually had fun at the mega-kiddie massive, although it was a
> spectacle of Barnum & Bailey proportions. The production
> environment was spot-on and professional though. Would be a
> little nice if it were that easy for all the UG parties.
> Although, I guess it's alot more fun & rewarding to
> scrap shit together like Macguyver. ;-)
>
> We got some good events coming up, Evil Breaks on Oct 20th @
> DNA, Ambient Mafia's 8 year anniversary on Nov 10th. And a bunch of
> parties Halloween weekend. I'll be at Andrew Phelan's Tonal
> party on Oct 27th. And a little bird told me Meat Meat Manifesto
> is playing another UG on the same night.
>
> Not sure about NYE, anyone got any plans?
>
> take care,
>
> -terry
>

threw was CLASSIC. I mean...seriously - pure genius. I have never seen Bam =
so bammed before.

 Fest had to offer. Mainly cuz I missed all the events that night, but also=
 because it was just a damn fun outdoor event with a shit-ton of REALLY coo=
l people hanging out and bonding. I think (or hope anyway) that I also mend=
ed some fences that my "bull in a china shop"  personality may have broken =
a while back.=20

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: my friend - Hawaiian Folk/Blues singer

so my friend Kevin Chang is coming to SF in early December and he's a
really awesome singer/songwriter/ukelele player.

no joke.  if you think hawaiian music and ukeleles equals cheesy
tourist bullshit, Kevin will make you think different.

his band, Kupa'aina plays contemporary hawaiian music, though Kevin's
solo stuff is really bluesy and soulful.

i'd like to try and hook him up with a gig or two while he's
here...but i know little to nothing about the live music scene in SF.
i'm just a silly DJ, you know.

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Oct.6th [KONTROL] w/ Daniel Bell and Billy Dalessandro (live)!

Saturday, October 6th, 2007

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


featuring from Detroit via Berlin:

DANIEL BELL aka DBX

( Accellerate . Tresor . Logistic . Peacefrog . 7th City . Perlon )

Rightfully considered to be one of the pioneers of the minimal
techno genre, the legendary Daniel Bell returns to SF for an
unprecedented fourth appearance at [KONTROL].  Dan, whom
we jokingly refer to as our "unofficial 5th resident", is just so
damn good, we'd probably book him every month if he'd let us.


and from Chicago:

BILLY DALESSANDRO  :  LIVE

( SiteHolder . Harthouse . Force Inc . Resopal )

SiteHolder Records' Billy Dallessandro has devastated the
decks of SF a few times in the last year, but he's never played
here LIVE... until now. In support of his third long player "Into
The Atom" just released on Harthouse, this talented and prolific
artist is coming prepared to give us a serious live set lashing


and [KONTROL] residents:

SAMMY D  ( Classic . Utensil )
CRAIG KUNA   ( Concept SF . ESDJCO )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )
NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )


________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

[ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28F.jpg

Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K28/K28B.jpg


____________________________________________________


DANIEL BELL (aka DBX)

Born in Sacramento, California, Daniel Bell grew up outside of
Toronto, Canada, and then moved to Detroit where he collaborated with
Richie Hawtin as Cybersonik for three years on Plus 8 Records. In
1991, he started his own label, Accelerate, on which he released his
influential releases as DBX. Based on nearby Chicago "track" records,
he reduced that sound further into funky, streamlined grooves. The
formula proved to be successful and helped launch a new aesthetic in
techno and house music known as "minimal".

With the overwhelming success of his "Losing Control" single in 1994,
Daniel set up 7th City Distribution in order to assist smaller Midwest
labels to get distribution in overseas markets. He also created three
new labels - 7th City, Elevate and Harmonie Park. In 2000, he
relocated to Berlin, Germany, and released his first mix CD, "The
Button-Down Mind of Daniel Bell", on Tresor Records, followed in 2003
by "The Button-Down Mind Strikes Back!" He since has produced a series
of remixes for a diverse range of artists, includng John Tejada,
Pantytec, Akufen and John Thomas. He has spent the last 3 years
traveling and DJing around the world.

Dan is playing a grand total of five gigs in North America in 2007.
We are truly honored to be able to say two of them are for us. To be
honest, we'll pretty much book this guy anytime he's available...he's
just that good!  His last appearance in January (with Matthew
Dear/Audion live) was probably the craziest any of us had EVER seen
the Endup.  What's in store this time? I guess we'll have to find out.


Daniel Bell's website:
http://www.daniel-bell.com/

Daniel Bell's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Daniel%20Bell

Daniel Bell interview @ InTheMix.com:
http://www.inthemix.com.au/features/23336/


MUSIC:

DBX - Phreak  (mp3 sample)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Phreak.mp3

DBX - Losing Control  (mp3 sample)
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K19/DBX_-_Losing_Control.mp3

Daniel Bell - Live @ Movement (DEMF) 2006  (real audio)
http://www.demf.com/sounds/2006/hmay/05-27-06_danielbell_movement06.ram


________________________________________________


BILLY DALESSANDRO (aka Huge Hephner)

Chicago native Billy Dalessandro first brought his unique production
style to the forefront of the electronic music community in 2002. The
five years since then have seen him release two full length albums,
nearly 20 original EPs, and a slew of remixes. His works have found
their way into the record bags of many respectable DJs, as well as
some of the most prestigious jocks' compilations.

Recently he established his own labels Siteholder and UnCut with
friends Brian Ffar and Daniel Mnookin which have already gained
massive feedback on each of the 7 releases. Standouts include "Don`t
Sleep" on SH001 and "That Trick She Knows" on SH002, both of which
were charted and played by many top DJs.  His latest release
"Blackjack" on Sonicutlure 006 is a jacking dancefloor bomb.

Billy will be in Europe from mid October to early December in support
of his just-released LP on Harthouse, after which he'll make stops in
select US cities. "Into the Atom", Dalessandro's third full length
album, takes listeners on a voyage into the bits and pieces of what
separates the average tracks from the very best.  Similar to the role
an atom plays in the molecular build up of all things on this planet,
the release exemplifies the minute twists and turns Dalessandro takes
with his music that help define him as among the true artists in the
production field.  It separates those who build the bandwagon from
those who wait until its completion to hop aboard.  Billy undeniably
belongs to the former of the two.


SiteHolder Records Website:
www.siteholder.net

Billy Dalessandro's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Billy%20Dalessandro

Billy Dalessandro interview in ResidentAdviser.net:
http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature-read.aspx?id=734

MySpace profiles:
www.myspace.com/billydalessandro
www.myspace.com/siteholder

Music samples on Beatport.com
http://www.beatport.com/Billy%20Dalessandro

http://www.kontrolsf.com

From: Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com>
User-Agent: Thunderbird 1.5.0.7 (Windows/20060909)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To:  sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top

http://www.numark.com/idj2

i'd much rather bring this to a party rather than a laptop or be 
concerned if there are cd decks there at the venue if i was playing cds. 
i think once they standardize this technology and put it into ranes, 
vestaxes, pioneers or an allan & heath. then i'm out there in oakland 
knocking on the leo's pro-audio front door.

i really think its the plug and play aspect that makes this technology 
so exciting. a dj can bring their collection with them on their keychain 
or bring their nano with them with a set playlist and just start 
jamming. you could even make a set of wav files and put it on your i-pod 
video. it may be possible to time stretch a live performance right into 
the mix from a laptop via usb (?) or if some one had a request to for a 
dj to bring a certain track they could bring their thumb drive with them 
to the party. it would be nice to see some usb ports on the front of 
this and with more effects. also would love to see more pioneer style cd 
or DVD VJ control.. maybe even a midi interface?

ain't TECHNOlogy wonderful?

sean
dj disconnect
DEF

--

Thursday

The totalitarian states can do great things, but there is one thing
they cannot do: they cannot give the factory-worker a rifle and tell
him to take it home and keep it in his bedroom.  That rifle hanging on
the wall of the working-class flat or labourer's cottage, is the
symbol of democracy. It is our job to see that it stays there.

- George Orwell

--

Friday

Gun bans don't disarm criminals, gun bans attract them.

- Walter Mondale


--

Special Saturday QOD and end of the gun quotes

Gun control?  It's the best thing you can do for crooks and gangsters.
   I want you to have nothing.  If I'm a bad guy, I'm always gonna have
a gun.  Safety locks?  You will pull the trigger with a lock on, and
I'll pull the trigger.  We'll see who wins.

- Sammy "The Bull" Gravano

> http://www.numark.com/idj2
>
> i'd much rather bring this to a party rather than a laptop or be
> concerned if there are cd decks there at the venue if i was playing cds.
> i think once they standardize this technology and put it into ranes,
> vestaxes, pioneers or an allan & heath. then i'm out there in oakland
> knocking on the leo's pro-audio front door.
>
> i really think its the plug and play aspect that makes this technology
> so exciting. a dj can bring their collection with them on their keychain
> or bring their nano with them with a set playlist and just start
> jamming. you could even make a set of wav files and put it on your i-pod
> video. it may be possible to time stretch a live performance right into
> the mix from a laptop via usb (?) or if some one had a request to for a
> dj to bring a certain track they could bring their thumb drive with them
> to the party. it would be nice to see some usb ports on the front of
> this and with more effects. also would love to see more pioneer style cd
> or DVD VJ control.. maybe even a midi interface?
>
> ain't TECHNOlogy wonderful?

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: BASSDROP @ Shine - Thursday - Free

Bassdrop
Thursday, October 11th, 2007
@ Shine
9pm-2am
FREE!!!
21+


Galen (Pacific Sound / Sunset)
Fascinated by music from an early age, Galen tried guitar, trumpet,
clarinet, flute, and singing before finally committing to keyboards at
the age of 18.

In 1992 Galen discovered the San Francisco house scene, and also
learned to dj the same year, which in turn triggered the creation of
The Pacific Sound System and the seminal Sunset Parties. Since 1994
San Francisco continues to be blessed with the legendary Sunset
Events...

Please help us welcome this local hero for his debut Evil Breaks appearance!


Almost Anonymous (Family Funktions / Urban Breaks)
This eclectic duo from Sacramento, Dave K and Malachi, will be digging
deep in their crates for this extended set. From the rough to the
smooth, expect to hear many styles of house represented.

Lync (Surround Underground)

M.O.D. (Evil Breaks/Strategik)

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

In-Reply-To: <47094A2A.1000908@defsf.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Message-ID: <450350.23455.qm@web52011.mail.re2.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top

Man it's been a loooong time since I posted here, this
thread has me wondering though... how common is it to
find CDJ 1000's or CDJ 800's at ug parties now? Is it
safe for a dj to show up to a party with a book of
cd's instead of a record bag these days? Obviousley
it's not an issue at the big clubs, and it seems even
most of the small bars/dj lounges etc have cought on
and have a pair of CDJ's now but I'm really wondering
about ug parties. Is it still mostly just a pair of
turntables or have the CDJ's become more common?

 I'm just wondering cuz to be honest I rarely make it
out to parties anymore but I went to a party this
weekend and was surprised because there was 2
turntables and 2 CDJ's set up and I literally didn't
see one record played... just CD's. I only stayed a
couple hours though, had to leave early cuz the
girlfriend was "tired" so maybe someone was playing
records after I left. 

 I'v been playing a mixture of records and cd's
probably about 75% vinyl 25% cd for the last 4 years
or so, and while it is VERY rare that I actually play
out anywhere I always have stuck to playing more vinyl
just because of the thought that if I actually DID get
booked to play at a party I'd probably be screwed if I
showed up with mostly cd's and little if any vinyl cuz
there wouldn't be any CDJ's. I always have and will
LOVE spinning vinyl... but It's  really began to hit
me latley that I've been playing more and more cd's
latley and maybee it's time to make the switch just
because I can carey tons more music on CD than vinyl,
plus the CDJ's eleviate all the problem associated
with vinyl such as warped records, scratched records
(cuz if its scratched you can burn a new copy),
bouncey floors making needles jump, needles feeding
back low end rummble from extreme sub bass etc. I'd
never go 100% cd... always have to have a little vinyl
on hand but its occureed to me that I'm probably
playing 75% cd's now and 25% vinyl. Most of the vinyl
I AM playing is just stuff that's brand new and isn't
available yet as a 320kbps MP3 yet. When it is
available I usually burn a cd and take the record out
of my bag to make space for other new stuff that I can
only get on vinyl.

So, in most situations would a dj be screwed if he
showed up to an ug with mostly cd's, or are CDJ's
pretty common now?

Kj

P.S. I haven't posted any mixes here in ages so if
anyone would like to check out some deep funky house
and tech house mixes here's a link to all my mixes new
and old. There not perfect, but who's live mixes are? 

www.musicv2.com/artist/dj_kevin_james


--- Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com> wrote:

> http://www.numark.com/idj2
> 
> i'd much rather bring this to a party rather than a
> laptop or be 
> concerned if there are cd decks there at the venue
> if i was playing cds. 
> i think once they standardize this technology and
> put it into ranes, 
> vestaxes, pioneers or an allan & heath. then i'm out
> there in oakland 
> knocking on the leo's pro-audio front door.
> 
> i really think its the plug and play aspect that
> makes this technology 
> so exciting. a dj can bring their collection with
> them on their keychain 
> or bring their nano with them with a set playlist
> and just start 
> jamming. you could even make a set of wav files and
> put it on your i-pod 
> video. it may be possible to time stretch a live
> performance right into 
> the mix from a laptop via usb (?) or if some one had
> a request to for a 
> dj to bring a certain track they could bring their
> thumb drive with them 
> to the party. it would be nice to see some usb ports
> on the front of 
> this and with more effects. also would love to see
> more pioneer style cd 
> or DVD VJ control.. maybe even a midi interface?
> 
> ain't TECHNOlogy wonderful?
> 
> sean
> dj disconnect
> DEF
> 
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top

it's always best to ask the promoter who booked you what the setup
will be.  this is just a good practice to get into so you have an idea
of what kind of mixer there will be, if you have to bring your own
needles, what to expect, etc.

that being said, most parties i go to do have CDJs of some sort.

> out to parties anymore but I went to a party this
> weekend and was surprised because there was 2
> turntables and 2 CDJ's set up and I literally didn't
> see one record played... just CD's. I only stayed a
> couple hours though, had to leave early cuz the
> girlfriend was "tired" so maybe someone was playing
> records after I left.
>
> I'v been playing a mixture of records and cd's
> probably about 75% vinyl 25% cd for the last 4 years
> or so, and while it is VERY rare that I actually play
> out anywhere I always have stuck to playing more vinyl
> just because of the thought that if I actually DID get
> booked to play at a party I'd probably be screwed if I
> showed up with mostly cd's and little if any vinyl cuz
> there wouldn't be any CDJ's. I always have and will
> LOVE spinning vinyl... but It's really began to hit
> me latley that I've been playing more and more cd's
> latley and maybee it's time to make the switch just
> because I can carey tons more music on CD than vinyl,
> plus the CDJ's eleviate all the problem associated
> with vinyl such as warped records, scratched records
> (cuz if its scratched you can burn a new copy),
> bouncey floors making needles jump, needles feeding
> back low end rummble from extreme sub bass etc. I'd
> never go 100% cd... always have to have a little vinyl
> on hand but its occureed to me that I'm probably
> playing 75% cd's now and 25% vinyl. Most of the vinyl
> I AM playing is just stuff that's brand new and isn't
> available yet as a 320kbps MP3 yet. When it is
> available I usually burn a cd and take the record out
> of my bag to make space for other new stuff that I can
> only get on vinyl.
>
> So, in most situations would a dj be screwed if he
> showed up to an ug with mostly cd's, or are CDJ's
> pretty common now?
>
> Kj
>
> P.S. I haven't posted any mixes here in ages so if
> anyone would like to check out some deep funky house
> and tech house mixes here's a link to all my mixes new
> and old. There not perfect, but who's live mixes are?
>
> www.musicv2.com/artist/dj_kevin_james
>
>
> --- Sean Ocean  wrote:
>

>> laptop or be
>> concerned if there are cd decks there at the venue
>> if i was playing cds.
>> i think once they standardize this technology and
>> put it into ranes,
>> vestaxes, pioneers or an allan & heath. then i'm out
>> there in oakland
>> knocking on the leo's pro-audio front door.
>>
>> i really think its the plug and play aspect that
>> makes this technology
>> so exciting. a dj can bring their collection with
>> them on their keychain
>> or bring their nano with them with a set playlist
>> and just start
>> jamming. you could even make a set of wav files and
>> put it on your i-pod
>> video. it may be possible to time stretch a live
>> performance right into
>> the mix from a laptop via usb (?) or if some one had
>> a request to for a
>> dj to bring a certain track they could bring their
>> thumb drive with them
>> to the party. it would be nice to see some usb ports
>> on the front of

>> more pioneer style cd

From: Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com>
To: electrofunk138@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
