Subject: RE: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top

You've actually had promotors get angry or offended
for requesting CD decks? Thats rediculouse, its easy
enough to say "sorry, we don't have access to any".
Why get bitchy about it?

Man Serato's a whole nother deal. If CDJ's haven't
even totally cought on in the ug scene I would think
you would NEVER find Serato at a party.

I never got into Serato cuz what if you show up with
your own unit and can't plug it in? 

For example, I have a pretty decent mid size sound
system that I'm just about finished building and is
almost ready to debut(6 custom designed and custom
built horn loaded subs (soon to be 8) 6 JBL SR47
series 3 way tops, all Crown and QSC amps and DBX
processing, 3 1200's 2 CDJ's and your choice of 3
mixers). If a dj showed up in the middle of a show and
wanted to plug in a Serato unit both he and I would
have a big problem. I have three mixers available to
promotors depending what they want, a Rane MP/XP 2016a
rotary, a Urei 1620LE rotary (my favorite), and a Rane
MP 44. All three mixers have there inputs and
connection on the bottom NOT the back..... so the
whole mixer would need to be pulled out to plug Serato
in. Now if that same dj let me know BEFORE the show
then no problem, show up at sound check and we'll get
it patched in and sorted... or at least just let me
know before the show starts and I can run cables so
you can just plug in when you DO get there..... but
show up in the middle of the show with no notice that
you need to run Serato and it's all bad. 

So what do you do then if you can't get to the
connections of the mixer to plug your Serato in? THAT
is why I don't like Serato, cuzz the mixers I prefer
to spin on are not very Serato friendly at all.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top


People are surprisingly becoming more Seratio friendly - although I do find=
 CDJ's more commonly available, as opposed to mixers that can accomodate Se=
rato - I am sure that will change soon enough.=20

And no - I haven't necessarily run into any promoters who refuse to have CD=
J's - they just don't always think of them in terms of being something DJ's=
 need. And of course, you get all sorts of folks in the peanut gallery tell=
ing you you're not a real DJ if you use them.=20

But that is also changing as digital format becomes more and more prevalent=
.

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: sound activating lights

lights that are plugged into the power strip on and off depending on
the level of sound?

played music...the x-mas lights would flicker with the sound?

i'm sure something like this exists, just not sure how to search for it?

Subject: RE: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top

--0-711323202-1191870189=:93641
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

most of the issues mentioned below can be mitigated by simple communication. i use serato for probably 80%+ of my gigs now, and if you talk to the promoter beforehand as well as talk to the DJ playing right before you, it's really not that difficult to set up. in friendly situations, i can get all set up and ready in less than five minutes and with no audible break in the music. in more difficult situations, i can always play my backup records which i bring with me to every gig just to be safe. i think i've only gone to my backup records two or three times so far.

with all the different things people are using to play tunes these days - vinyl decks, cd decks, midi boards, live PA hardware, laptops, etc. - some plugging/unplugging of cables as the lineup progresses is becoming par for the course. a setup where the inputs on the mixer are inaccessible just isn't very practical, imo. and any DJ who acts like a dick because you need to mess with some cables (i've only encountered one) can either learn to adapt or most likely get left behind as the rest of us continue to experiment with new technology.

long live serato!

love,
mo


Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com> wrote: You've actually had promotors get angry or offended
for requesting CD decks? Thats rediculouse, its easy
enough to say "sorry, we don't have access to any".
Why get bitchy about it?

Man Serato's a whole nother deal. If CDJ's haven't
even totally cought on in the ug scene I would think
you would NEVER find Serato at a party.

I never got into Serato cuz what if you show up with
your own unit and can't plug it in? 

For example, I have a pretty decent mid size sound
system that I'm just about finished building and is
almost ready to debut(6 custom designed and custom
built horn loaded subs (soon to be 8) 6 JBL SR47
series 3 way tops, all Crown and QSC amps and DBX
processing, 3 1200's 2 CDJ's and your choice of 3
mixers). If a dj showed up in the middle of a show and
wanted to plug in a Serato unit both he and I would
have a big problem. I have three mixers available to
promotors depending what they want, a Rane MP/XP 2016a
rotary, a Urei 1620LE rotary (my favorite), and a Rane
MP 44. All three mixers have there inputs and
connection on the bottom NOT the back..... so the
whole mixer would need to be pulled out to plug Serato
in. Now if that same dj let me know BEFORE the show
then no problem, show up at sound check and we'll get
it patched in and sorted... or at least just let me
know before the show starts and I can run cables so
you can just plug in when you DO get there..... but
show up in the middle of the show with no notice that
you need to run Serato and it's all bad. 

So what do you do then if you can't get to the
connections of the mixer to plug your Serato in? THAT
is why I don't like Serato, cuzz the mixers I prefer
to spin on are not very Serato friendly at all.

> > back low end rummble from extreme sub bass etc.

> > never go 100% cd... always have to have a little
> vinyl
> > on hand but its occureed to me that I'm probably
> > playing 75% cd's now and 25% vinyl. Most of the
> vinyl
> > I AM playing is just stuff that's brand new and
> isn't
> > available yet as a 320kbps MP3 yet. When it is
> > available I usually burn a cd and take the record
> out
> > of my bag to make space for other new stuff that I
> can
> > only get on vinyl.
> >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: sound activating lights

If your in the Southbay you can go to Halted Computers on central Expressway and pick up an inexpensive sound trigger for about 10bucks.  You will have to solder about 10 components together.  Voila' You can now have this trigger control a standard 110v power relay.  Radio shack might have something like this too.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top

We did a party once that involved two Djs using vinyl (one of them 3
turntables and a CD player), 1 using Serrato and two using laptop
mixing software.

The Serrato Dj was on first, then the two laptop Djs, then the two
turntable vinylist, then the 3 turntable + cd Dj.

Our solution was to have four turntables with two mixers laid out
ahead of time. The digital Djs used one mixer and the vinyl/cd Djs
used the other. We did this to avoid any cable clusterfucks, traffic
interference and general disturbance of artists while performing.

This may have been overkill, but this solution worked out beautifully,
but only because we used identical mixers (Xone:92s) and connected
both to the house mixer.

-Solekandi

On 10/8/07, mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com> wrote:
> most of the issues mentioned below can be mitigated by simple communication. i use serato for probably 80%+ of my gigs now, and if you talk to the promoter beforehand as well as talk to the DJ playing right before you, it's really not that difficult to set up. in friendly situations, i can get all set up and ready in less than five minutes and with no audible break in the music. in more difficult situations, i can always play my backup records which i bring with me to every gig just to be safe. i think i've only gone to my backup records two or three times so far.
>
> with all the different things people are using to play tunes these days - vinyl decks, cd decks, midi boards, live PA hardware, laptops, etc. - some plugging/unplugging of cables as the lineup progresses is becoming par for the course. a setup where the inputs on the mixer are inaccessible just isn't very practical, imo. and any DJ who acts like a dick because you need to mess with some cables (i've only encountered one) can either learn to adapt or most likely get left behind as the rest of us continue to experiment with new technology.
>
> long live serato!
>
> love,
> mo
>
>
> Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com> wrote: You've actually had promotors get angry or offended
> for requesting CD decks? Thats rediculouse, its easy

> even totally cought on in the ug scene I would think

> I never got into Serato cuz what if you show up with
> your own unit and can't plug it in?
>
> For example, I have a pretty decent mid size sound
> system that I'm just about finished building and is
> almost ready to debut(6 custom designed and custom
> built horn loaded subs (soon to be 8) 6 JBL SR47
> series 3 way tops, all Crown and QSC amps and DBX
> processing, 3 1200's 2 CDJ's and your choice of 3
> mixers). If a dj showed up in the middle of a show and
> wanted to plug in a Serato unit both he and I would
> have a big problem. I have three mixers available to
> promotors depending what they want, a Rane MP/XP 2016a
> rotary, a Urei 1620LE rotary (my favorite), and a Rane
> MP 44. All three mixers have there inputs and
> connection on the bottom NOT the back..... so the
> whole mixer would need to be pulled out to plug Serato
> in. Now if that same dj let me know BEFORE the show
> then no problem, show up at sound check and we'll get
> it patched in and sorted... or at least just let me
> know before the show starts and I can run cables so
> you can just plug in when you DO get there..... but
> show up in the middle of the show with no notice that
> you need to run Serato and it's all bad.
>
> So what do you do then if you can't get to the
> connections of the mixer to plug your Serato in? THAT
> is why I don't like Serato, cuzz the mixers I prefer
> to spin on are not very Serato friendly at all.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] why i haven't switched to cds or a lap top

--- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:

> so when will you be debuting your system?  sounds
> like a good mid-sized rig.


Building this system has been a looong process. I did
a ton of research, and I have hand selected each and
every piece in this rig based on obtaining only the
best sound quality. I started the project almost two
years ago but at this point I have one amp (a QSC PLX
3602) and some more cables I need to buy and then its
100% ready to go. 

I would LIKE to find a nice rehearsal space to rent
for a weekend to fully test the rig out and dial it in
before I rent it out, but I'm not having much luck
finding anywhere in the south bay where I can do that.
All the individual components of the system have been
extensivley tested (at low volumes) and everything is
functioning 100% as it should with no problems, I just
haven't been able to fire the whole system up together
yet. 
 
Without rushing it I'd say by December it should be
ready. However if a reasonable offer came up now for a
rental gig, and I had at least a months notice before
the event (time needed to pick up that last amp, the
rest of the cables and a few other odds and ends), and
providing I was able to spend a good 3 hours or so
post setup and pre-show on sound check dialing the rig
in I could accept a booking now. 



Kj



 On 10/8/07, Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com>
> wrote:
> > You've actually had promotors get angry or
> offended
> > for requesting CD decks? Thats rediculouse, its

> > Man Serato's a whole nother deal. If CDJ's haven't
> > even totally cought on in the ug scene I would
> think
> > you would NEVER find Serato at a party.
> >
> > I never got into Serato cuz what if you show up
> with
> > your own unit and can't plug it in?
> >
> > For example, I have a pretty decent mid size sound
> > system that I'm just about finished building and
> is
> > almost ready to debut(6 custom designed and custom
> > built horn loaded subs (soon to be 8) 6 JBL SR47
> > series 3 way tops, all Crown and QSC amps and DBX
> > processing, 3 1200's 2 CDJ's and your choice of 3
> > mixers). If a dj showed up in the middle of a show
> and
> > wanted to plug in a Serato unit both he and I
> would
> > have a big problem. I have three mixers available
> to
> > promotors depending what they want, a Rane MP/XP
> 2016a
> > rotary, a Urei 1620LE rotary (my favorite), and a
> Rane
> > MP 44. All three mixers have there inputs and
> > connection on the bottom NOT the back..... so the
> > whole mixer would need to be pulled out to plug
> Serato
> > in. Now if that same dj let me know BEFORE the
> show
> > then no problem, show up at sound check and we'll
> get
> > it patched in and sorted... or at least just let
> me
> > know before the show starts and I can run cables
> so
> > you can just plug in when you DO get there.....
> but
> > show up in the middle of the show with no notice
> that
> > you need to run Serato and it's all bad.
> >
> > So what do you do then if you can't get to the

> > > a

> > > play

> > > vinyl
> > > > just because of the thought that if I actually
> DID
> > > get
> > > > booked to play at a party I'd probably be

> > > if I
> > > > showed up with mostly cd's and little if any

> > > > there wouldn't be any CDJ's. I always have and
> > > will

> to
> > > hit
> > > > me latley that I've been playing more and more

> > > just
> > > > because I can carey tons more music on CD than
> > > vinyl,
> > > > plus the CDJ's eleviate all the problem
> associated
> > > > with vinyl such as warped records, scratched
> > > records
> > > > (cuz if its scratched you can burn a new

> > > > bouncey floors making needles jump, needles
> > > feeding
> > > > back low end rummble from extreme sub bass

> > > I'd
> > > > never go 100% cd... always have to have a
> little
> > > vinyl
> > > > on hand but its occureed to me that I'm
> probably
> > > > playing 75% cd's now and 25% vinyl. Most of
> the
> > > vinyl
> > > > I AM playing is just stuff that's brand new
> and
> > > isn't
> > > > available yet as a 320kbps MP3 yet. When it is

> > > out
> > > > of my bag to make space for other new stuff

> > > can
> > > > only get on vinyl.

> > > > So, in most situations would a dj be screwed

> If your in the Southbay you can go to Halted Computers on central Expressway and pick up an inexpensive sound trigger for about 10bucks.  You will have to solder about 10 components together.  Voila' You can now have this trigger control a standard 110v power relay.  Radio shack might have something like this too.

From: "Nyc W. Alberts" <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: sound activating lights

My Dad in the late 1970s designed a prototype pair of glasses for deaf 
people that incorporated his red and green LEDs into them that would 
flash on and off whenever they were spoken t,o or there was some other 
sound in the environment, like an oncoming car, that they should be 
aware of.

Like the electronic jewelry he designed and tried to sell at around the 
same time as those glasses, it was about 20 years too soon to attract 
any VC money so it never went anywhere.

For what you're looking to do, RadioShack isn't a bad place to start.

..

Bam wrote:
> is there some kind of power strip with a sound sensor that would turn
> lights that are plugged into the power strip on and off depending on
> the level of sound?
>
> not like the clapper, but say if you plugged x-mas lights in and you
> played music...the x-mas lights would flicker with the sound?
>
> i'm sure something like this exists, just not sure how to search for it?

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY @ DNA Lounge - Oct. 20th

DIRTY
October 20th, 2007
DNA Lounge - 375 11th St.
$10 presales @ groovetickets.com
$10 b4 11pm / $15 after
10pm - 4am
21+

It's been a few months since Evil Breaks has done a bigger party, and
we figured we'd come back with something HUGE!!! We can't wait to see
what these guys sound like on DNA's amazing sound system, and along
with the amazing local support, Visuals by Viberation, and a special
surprise guest upstairs, I really don't think you're going to want to
miss this.


E.B.'s Dirty little room w/visuals by Viberation:

Lawgiverz (Trigger/Botchit) - UK

Lawgiverz, a.k.a. R-Kidz and Noize, have been dropping audio bombs for
the last five years on Botchit & Scarper, Trigger Recordings and more.
Lawgiverz have produced, programmed and remixed with a bizarre
selection of artists such as Jeff Beck, Dave Stewart and The Human
League. They would like you to know that none of this really matters.
Just that if you find yourself in front of the Trigger sound system or
at DNA during their laptop and turntable set, prepare to be destroyed
with a helping of alien love in the Electrobreaks style.


Fine Cut Bodies (Chi Recordings/Record Records) - Budapest

Even though the name Fine Cut Bodies implies more than one person,
behind the FCB letters is only one man, Kevin aka Attila Fodor. His
musical tastes are extremely broad which is reflected in the musical
preferences of *Chi Recordings*, the label he co-founded in 2000. One
of the most important taste-maker DJs in Hungary, he has been one of
the key DJs/promoters that built up the huge breaks scene in Hungary
and he is now starting to build up the world class underground minimal
and tech-house scene in Budapest.

As a DJ, Kevin's taste is determined more by his musical attitude than
by any specific genre: he looks for music that's experimental but not
selfish, interesting but not unlistenable. As a producer, he has
released tracks in many genres and is always looking for new sonic
adventures. Kevin's tracks have been licensed for numerous
compilations and he has collaborated with and remixed for some of the
hottest names in electronic music.

Aaron Jae (E.B./XM Radio/Space Cowboys)
Bam (Evil Breaks/ABN)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)
Raydeus (Pronoia)


Beat Church hosting the upstairs room:

Lawgiverz (A 2nd Mid-tempo set)

Kitty-D (The Glitch Mob/Beat Church)
Hookerz & Blow (Mozaic vs EPROM)
Benchun(False Profit)


-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

References: <BAY110-W40118F82C2A727DC422AD85A50@phx.gbl>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Converting m4a to MP3 w/o loss....

In iTunes, change the default file format to mp3, then right click on the 
track you want to convert, and select "convert to mp3".

Converting between lossy formats is always going to degrade the sound 
quality, there's no way around it.


On Tue, 9 Oct 2007, electrofunk138@hotmail.com wrote:

> Anyone know a good way or a good program to convert m4a file format to 
> MP3 - w/o a whole lot of loss - like, preferrably close to a 320kbps 
> quality, but 192 will do....

Subject: [sfraves] Re: why i haven't switched to cds or a laptop cont'd

----------MB_8C9D8C3FCDDD0C8_83C_DA6F_FWM-M43.sysops.aol.com
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"


 i think if you're saying why be a dick when it comes to cabling i think if you look at this mixer it can do cds laptops vinyl, wav and mp3s from a hard drive or an ipod... but why carry around a laptop when you can carry a thumbdrive? i just think serrato is a little too ahead of its time and tried to do something that bridged the gap between digital and analog for analog djs a couple of years ago. i myself am still an analog dj and i love it. but i am now buying new tracks for a couple of dollars and giving the artist props for what they do, with my money.. i.e. supporting their work. but i see a new frontier for djing, in this, what seems like a missing link for all these splintered offshoots of djing. which in my view is just killing djing

this mixer is a standardised platform for djing as a universal concept instead of fragmenting djs into just vinyl or just serrato or just cd-jing. now you have an efficient mixer that takes on the past and the future and makes it efficient. and it adds a thing most of us already own and does not cost 3,000 dollars as does a laptop (which we don't all own). possibly it will be a standard feature on all mixers to have a hard drive built in? plug and play is great thing i think that's what makes this mixer great. like djing in the past you just won't have to worry about what's there at the gig or 'call the promoter up' cause its already there for you. its less of a headache on the dj, the promoter, and the audience who has to watch you fumble with a flashlight while you bust out your serrato for five minutes. but i'd wait on this product until it has been tested out and once the successor takes its place , then finally gets all the kinks out. that's when i would say you should go out and get one.. at least that's what i'd do, especially if the big companies start making hard drive mixers.

like wouldn't it be great to call up your song from a small 400 gig usb hard drive that is smaller than your actual thumb, have it looped and sampled already and you can do sample hits on the fly, have your re-edit effected and quantized to the beat live.. all the while playing some cool assed MP4 video made by your vj friend? when's that mixer coming out? that's like a plug and play ableton live with video and without any excess baggage. think of the awesomeness.. maybe that's pioneer's version. `;)





On 10/8/07, mo corleone <mo_corleone2@yahoo.com> wrote:
> most of the issues mentioned below can be mitigated by simple communication. i 
use serato for probably 80%+ of my gigs now, and if you talk to the promoter 
beforehand as well as talk to the DJ playing right before you, it's really not 
that difficult to set up. in friendly situations, i can get all set up and ready 
in less than five minutes and with no audible break in the music. in more 
difficult situations, i can always play my backup records which i bring with me 
to every gig just to be safe. i think i've only gone to my backup records two or 
three times so far.
>
> with all the different things people are using to play tunes these days - 
vinyl decks, cd decks, midi boards, live PA hardware, laptops, etc. - some 
plugging/unplugging of cables as the lineup progresses is becoming par for the 
course. a setup where the inputs on the mixer are inaccessible just isn't very 
practical, imo. and any DJ who acts like a dick because you need to mess with 
some cables (i've only encountered one) can either learn to adapt or most likely 
get left behind as the rest of us continue to experiment with new technology.
>


 


 whee! respect to all and mo for the replay.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - Ambient Mafia 8-year - 11/10/07

A lot has changed in the Bay Area in the last eight years, but
one thing has remained constant.

The economy? Hell, no, where were you in 2002?!

The rave scene? Huh? Raves? Wotsat?

No, were talking about the Ambient Mafia!

Thats right, on Nov. 10 the Bay Areas premiere chill crew is
celebrating our eighth year of giving San Francisco (and
beyond) the finest in downtempo and electronic beats...as well
as founder Redstickmans birthday! Come out and help us
commemorate these major milestones the only way we know how 
with a big ass party of biblical proportions! (We are not
responsible for those turned to salt in the aftermath.)

Well be rockin a top-notch brand new underground location in
San Francisco, and all your favorite Mafia DJs will be on hand
in two rooms of mind-bending mayhem and merriment. With visuals
by Viberation and Junktronix and audio by Sound of Mind and
:am, the Ambient Mafia 8-Year Anniversary party will make you
think its 1999 all over again! 

Actually, is that such a good thing? No, this will be a party
that reminds you that this is 2007 and after eight years, the
song remains the same... nobody does it like the Ambient Mafia!

Stay tuned for more demented details and lineup, and as always,
thanks for your continued support. We couldnt do it without
you! Okay, we could, but it would kinda suck.

---

11.10.07 :: 9pm - 6am
Brand Fikkin New UG Location, SF

www.ambientmafia.com


-----------------------------------------------------
 www.redstickman.com

 new downtempo mix online, you should check it out.

Cristal

Plantfunk

White Lotus Society 
14.	Disco Mania  Stacy Kidd ft. Melvin Weeks 
15.	U Know  Will Bailey 
16.	Electro Express (Hi_Tack Voxless Fleishmann Mix) 
Johnny Crockett 
17.	Now That Love Has Gone  We In Music

>>> celebrating our eighth year of giving San Francisco (and
>>> beyond) the finest in downtempo and electronic beats...as well
>>> as founder Redstickmans birthday! Come out and help us
>>> commemorate these major milestones the only way we know how 
>>> with a big ass party of biblical proportions! (We are not
>>> responsible for those turned to salt in the aftermath.)
>>>
>>> Well be rockin a top-notch brand new underground location in
>>> San Francisco, and all your favorite Mafia DJs will be on hand
>>> in two rooms of mind-bending mayhem and merriment. With visuals
>>> by Viberation and Junktronix and audio by Sound of Mind and
>>> :am, the Ambient Mafia 8-Year Anniversary party will make you
>>> think its 1999 all over again!
>>>
>>> Actually, is that such a good thing? No, this will be a party
>>> that reminds you that this is 2007 and after eight years, the
>>> song remains the same... nobody does it like the Ambient Mafia!
>>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?

this is in reference to Anon Salon.

i would say "no" to a general increased monitoring because i know of
one UG spot that has done 3 events in the last 5 weeks and each
attracted several hundreds of people and the music could be heard
outside for atleast a block away.

also, last weekend there was a party near Cesar Chavez that went late
night and had upwards of 20 people smoking and talking outside the
front doors.  i was outside when a cop car rolled by and though one
cop did peer out to look...they just kept driving.

i haven't heard of any events being broken up recently.  has anyone else?

Beetle Juice is being thrown by Lite-Brite, a long-time 
lighting/sound crew from Sac, worked with them on Space Girls 2. 
They're not so much a party crew as a technical production 
crew, but technical can go a long way I suppose.

So I have no doubt the production levels will be very good 
(since all his sound and lighting is essentially free). The 
promotions and lineup promise a younger 18-25 crowd. A bowling 
alley for the venue is...well, a bowling alley for what it's 
worth.

The bigger question is, Trista...what are you looking for in a 
party? While many of us on this list are *well* over 18, 21+, we 
have some good experience to point you towards what's crackin' 
:-)

If you're daring and down for SFR's style of parties there are a 
bunch of other rockin' Halloween parties people are talking 
about.

Welcome to SFR :-)

-terry

Subject: RE: [sfraves] beetle juice

Hi Trista.

Lite Brite has been doing sound/visual support for some of the largest
parties around for years now (the Lovefest aferparty included), so on an
environment level, I anticipate nothing less than stellar.  As a party =
crew,
like most old timers, they were more active in throwing their own events
years & years ago... But they've only gotten bigger & better over time, =
so
I'm looking forward to seeing what they have in store for this Halloween
bash.

As for the venue, the party isn't going on in just the bowling alley
portion... But through the entire building... Which with it's separate =
rooms
and multiple levels, makes for a great place to throw an event.  Being =
one
of those venues that brings back memories of years past, I expect to see =
a
much more diverse crowd agewise with "old skoolers" and "nu skoolers" in =
a
good mix.  Sure, any "rave" inspired event these days attracts a =
"younger
crowd" but I don't expect the attendees to be any younger of average =
than
most other events of this nature in the Bay.  (in fact, I've come to see =
the
average Bay crowd as being even younger at these types of parties these =
days
with all the happy hardcore that still goes on down there - yowza!) As =
for
the lineup at this event, it's pretty diverse as well with techno, =
electro,
breaks, house, dnb, downtempo+++ and yeah even some trance in there from =
the
looks of it...=20

I especially like the idea that costumes are required and that dressing =
as a
candy kid doesn=92t count.  Ha ha.  Forcing creativity is GRATE!=20

Depending on what you're looking for in a party,this might or might not =
be
the one for you.  Being one of the busiest (and oldest) DJs around and =
while
still living in Sacramento, I can give you some honest input from =
someone
who's experienced much of what the Sac scene does (or doesn't) have to =
offer
to your particular tastes. So feel free to hit me up privately if you
want...=20

~dina

> Hi Trista.
>
> Lite Brite has been doing sound/visual support for some of the largest
> parties around for years now (the Lovefest aferparty included), so =20
> on an
> environment level, I anticipate nothing less than stellar.  As a =20
> party crew,
> like most old timers, they were more active in throwing their own =20
> events
> years & years ago... But they've only gotten bigger & better over =20
> time, so
> I'm looking forward to seeing what they have in store for this =20
> Halloween
> bash.
>
> As for the venue, the party isn't going on in just the bowling alley
> portion... But through the entire building... Which with it's =20
> separate rooms
> and multiple levels, makes for a great place to throw an event.  =20
> Being one
> of those venues that brings back memories of years past, I expect to =20=

> see a
> much more diverse crowd agewise with "old skoolers" and "nu =20
> skoolers" in a
> good mix.  Sure, any "rave" inspired event these days attracts a =20
> "younger
> crowd" but I don't expect the attendees to be any younger of average =20=

> than
> most other events of this nature in the Bay.  (in fact, I've come to =20=

> see the
> average Bay crowd as being even younger at these types of parties =20
> these days
> with all the happy hardcore that still goes on down there - yowza!) =20=

> As for
> the lineup at this event, it's pretty diverse as well with techno, =20
> electro,
> breaks, house, dnb, downtempo+++ and yeah even some trance in there =20=

> from the
> looks of it...
>
> I especially like the idea that costumes are required and that =20
> dressing as a
> candy kid doesn=E2=80=99t count.  Ha ha.  Forcing creativity is GRATE!
>
> Depending on what you're looking for in a party,this might or might =20=

> not be
> the one for you.  Being one of the busiest (and oldest) DJs around =20
> and while
> still living in Sacramento, I can give you some honest input from =20

 <347df33a0710110843q171892baq3863116b60066f5f@mail.gmail.com>
 <f18c77450710111040xe522e4bs80e855a968e28c73@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?

Cops are territorial, and different cities have different 
instructions/procedures.

In general they don't come around unless you have a complaint, 
so sound-proofing and curbing loitering is the number one ally.

I also suspect most departments are more concerned with violent 
crime, which they have plenty to to deal with.

If shit's under control, and the party doesn't look like a 
complete circus, and there aren't problems outside the venue, a 
reasonable party representative should be able to get the cops 
on their way.

However, might be interesting to know more of the "insides". For 
a while one of my clients was the Salinas Police Dept., so I got 
to see their interaction to crime with candor. But there 
weren't many "raves" in Salinas at that time.

9 out of 10 of my personal dealings w/ the PO were cordial, and 
we took care of the problem or shut it down. The renegade 
locations though, were shut-down for sure, with the exception 
of some beach parties.

Anyone else got some experience/knowledge with this??

-t

Cool, thanks! Although, I'd love to check out other events too. Breaks and 
techno are up in my alley as well. I don't buy into that whole elitist, 
genre culture. Not to mention, psytrance parties are often, you know, 
difficult to get to because they're frequently in the middle of no where. 
It'd be great if I could get somewhere by taking the BART, then maybe a bus 
and I can even handle that primitive walking thing that I sometimes hear 
about. I wince at the pain that my car has taken whenever I think of those 4 
hours drives out into the middle of the desert for a Moontribe gathering...

 <347df33a0710110843q171892baq3863116b60066f5f@mail.gmail.com>
 <f18c77450710111040xe522e4bs80e855a968e28c73@mail.gmail.com>

X-Virus-Scanned: ClamAV 0.91.2/4529/Wed Oct 10 23:54:06 2007 on paz.well.com
X-Virus-Status: Clean
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?


>
>Anyone else got some experience/knowledge with this??


Tips on dealing with "authorities" - all based on personal experience.

1)  If you are doing an event, and you are not sure how entirely 
'legal' such an event might be -
have at least one partner - and have a designated role for each 
partner for the evening - one partner
should be the 'spokesperson' for the event and be ready to say things 
like "yes, officer, this is my event -
what can i do to help you ?" . . . the other partner, should stay out 
of it - entirely - that way, if a trip
to the station is the end result, one of you is free, has access to 
phones and bail money, etc.

2)  Do not try to bullshit the officer, do not try to make the 
officer your "buddy" or new best friend,
do not LIE to the officer, carry valid and current ID and let the 
officer see it as soon as he asks to
see it - though one time, I had left my ID in the car, because, as I 
explained, I had not wanted to
risk losing it on the beach at night where we were doing our 
questionably legal event - the officer
in that case was willing to accompany me to my car to inspect my ID - 
this served the additional
purpose of getting the officer away from the party.

Additional tip - being able to honestly look the officer in the eye 
helps a lot.  Taking responsibility
for what is going on helps a lot.

3)  Do your own "policing" as the event goes on - it really isn't as 
much fun, but somebody has to
stay completely sober (one or two of the people RESPONSIBLE for 
putting on the event) for the
duration of the event - this allows the sober person to be ready to 
deal with any authorities and/or
any real emergency situations. - By doing your own "policing"  I 
mean, walking around and being
aware of any situations that might be threatening to get out of 
control - like the arrival of a posse
that is already beyond socially acceptable drunk, or the arrival of 
people intent on setting off a lot
of fireworks - believe it or not, fireworks draw the attention of 
authorities - even more than a thumping
bass.  Once you become aware of a potential problem, recruit your 
friends and the people you know
to 'keep an eye' on the potential problem situation - surprisingly 
often, one of your friends might
know someone in the "drunk posse" and the friend just saying hi, will 
chill the whole situation down.

4)  I know it is a "downer" but do not be afraid to turn the music 
down or off if you have good
reason to - ie authorities seem to be cruising the area, or a drunken 
posse is getting out of hand -
the people who you want at your event understand - they do not want 
to be sent out into the street
or on the way home earlier than expected - 20 minutes of quiet, or 
the focus of the entire crowd
on a threatening posse and really chill things out - allowing you to 
get back on track for the rest
of the evening.

5)  Be careful not to admit to any more than you have to - remember, 
don't lie - but you don't have
to volunteer a lot, either.  I was once asked if what was going on 
was "a rave" - I answered it was a gathering
of friends who liked to get together and dance all night once and a 
while.  Rave was the buzzword
that generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled 
at my answer and said -
OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let 
you and your friends dance until sunrise -
but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then 
showed the officer all of
the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took 
all of the information from my ID
and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone 
there, I would be arrested, and
if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested - He 
gave me his card - and left.

I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had 
handled the situation
and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he 
said - if you and your friends
ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know 
beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
won't have any problems.

6)  Sometimes the officers will make a couple of small requests to 
test the situation - such as,
could you turn the bass down a bit - I think that is why we got a 
complaint from the neighbors -
by complying immediately you give the officer a sense that the 
situation IS under your control and that
he is dealing with a reasonable human being.

7)  Getting argumentative never works - getting indignant never works 
- personally knowing some of
the officer's fellow officers and being able to name drop - that 
works - but be sure of your relationship
with the officer who's name you are dropping.

8)  Getting the name of the officers, and their cards if possible is 
hugely helpful - especially if
you have already dealt with one officer situation that evening - it 
is not uncommon for DIFFERENT
officers to drop by - the sheriff, the local police, the state 
police, the park police ALL might have
some jurisdiction over your location - it is helpful to be able to 
say Officer so and so of the sheriff's
dept was already here this evening, here is his card - this is what 
we discussed . . . .

9)  Finally, if the word is NO - yield and get you, your stuff and 
all of the people out of there
as quickly and quietly as possible - IF you have a back-up location, 
that helps a lot - but do NOT
distribute ANYTHING with that information written down - telling 
people to head in whatever direction
signaling "everyone's going home now" and pay special attention to 
driving carefully !!!
Use your info line for the back-up location info (if you can trust 
it) or word of mouth, only.

I hope this helps . . . . . 


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

That's a lot of excellent advice, one thing not mentioned though: If you're
lucky enough to know a lawyer who would be kind enough to attend the event
and stay sober for it, take that opportunity.

There is nothing that will take the wind out of a cop's sails than hearing,
"Hello officer, I am attorney so and so, what's the problem here?"

I've seen that one little sentence take what would have surely been a busted
party and a ruined night for all and turn it into a *very* apologetic police
officer and a banging party that got to go until it was finished.

> but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then
> showed the officer all of
> the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took
> all of the information from my ID
> and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone
> there, I would be arrested, and
> if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested - He
> gave me his card - and left.
>
> I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had
> handled the situation
> and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he
> said - if you and your friends
> ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know
> beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
> won't have any problems.
>

> test the situation - such as,

Friends in high places definitely make it easier to pull off a proper party.

On 10/11/07, Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote:
>
> At 01:31 PM 10/11/2007, you wrote:
> >That's a lot of excellent advice, one thing not mentioned though: If
> you're
> >lucky enough to know a lawyer who would be kind enough to attend the
> event
> >and stay sober for it, take that opportunity.
>
> yeah, unfortunately most of my lawyer friends are usually the most wasted
> etards in attendence
>
>
> >There is nothing that will take the wind out of a cop's sails than
> hearing,
> >"Hello officer, I am attorney so and so, what's the problem here?"
> >
> >I've seen that one little sentence take what would have surely been a
> busted
> >party and a ruined night for all and turn it into a *very* apologetic
> police
> >officer and a banging party that got to go until it was finished.
>
> i've actually had the sheriff - on hand, as a guest at the party -
> the officers practically browned their underwear - still wish I'd had
> a camera -
>
> on another occasion, when the police came to the door - the space owner
> greeted them - he was jerry brown, then mayor of oakland, now attorney
> general of california . . . needless to say . . . .
>
>

From sfraves-return-142216-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Oct 11 21:18:47 2007

Subject: RE: [sfraves] fact or fiction?


You don't have to say SHIT to a cop. In fact - anything you say is likely t=
o hang you out to dry when court time comes around, so mums the word. Only =
give them your ID. You honestly dont have to say anything beyond that.=20


> Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 13:21:19 -0700
> To: terry@hyperreal.org; rationalhatter@gmail.com
> From: surfpunk@well.com
> CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?
>
>
>>
>>Anyone else got some experience/knowledge with this??
>
>
> Tips on dealing with "authorities" - all based on personal experience.
>
> 1) If you are doing an event, and you are not sure how entirely
> 'legal' such an event might be -
> have at least one partner - and have a designated role for each
> partner for the evening - one partner
> should be the 'spokesperson' for the event and be ready to say things
> like "yes, officer, this is my event -
> what can i do to help you ?" . . . the other partner, should stay out
> of it - entirely - that way, if a trip
> to the station is the end result, one of you is free, has access to
> phones and bail money, etc.
>
> 2) Do not try to bullshit the officer, do not try to make the
> officer your "buddy" or new best friend,
> do not LIE to the officer, carry valid and current ID and let the
> officer see it as soon as he asks to
> see it - though one time, I had left my ID in the car, because, as I
> explained, I had not wanted to
> risk losing it on the beach at night where we were doing our
> questionably legal event - the officer
> in that case was willing to accompany me to my car to inspect my ID -
> this served the additional
> purpose of getting the officer away from the party.
>
> Additional tip - being able to honestly look the officer in the eye
> helps a lot. Taking responsibility
> for what is going on helps a lot.
>
> 3) Do your own "policing" as the event goes on - it really isn't as
> much fun, but somebody has to
> stay completely sober (one or two of the people RESPONSIBLE for
> putting on the event) for the
> duration of the event - this allows the sober person to be ready to
> deal with any authorities and/or
> any real emergency situations. - By doing your own "policing" I
> mean, walking around and being
> aware of any situations that might be threatening to get out of
> control - like the arrival of a posse
> that is already beyond socially acceptable drunk, or the arrival of
> people intent on setting off a lot
> of fireworks - believe it or not, fireworks draw the attention of
> authorities - even more than a thumping
> bass. Once you become aware of a potential problem, recruit your
> friends and the people you know
> to 'keep an eye' on the potential problem situation - surprisingly
> often, one of your friends might
> know someone in the "drunk posse" and the friend just saying hi, will
> chill the whole situation down.
>
> 4) I know it is a "downer" but do not be afraid to turn the music
> down or off if you have good
> reason to - ie authorities seem to be cruising the area, or a drunken
> posse is getting out of hand -
> the people who you want at your event understand - they do not want
> to be sent out into the street
> or on the way home earlier than expected - 20 minutes of quiet, or
> the focus of the entire crowd
> on a threatening posse and really chill things out - allowing you to
> get back on track for the rest
> of the evening.
>
> 5) Be careful not to admit to any more than you have to - remember,
> don't lie - but you don't have
> to volunteer a lot, either. I was once asked if what was going on
> was "a rave" - I answered it was a gathering
> of friends who liked to get together and dance all night once and a
> while. Rave was the buzzword
> that generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled
> at my answer and said -
> OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let
> you and your friends dance until sunrise -
> but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then
> showed the officer all of
> the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took
> all of the information from my ID
> and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone
> there, I would be arrested, and
> if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested - He
> gave me his card - and left.
>
> I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had
> handled the situation
> and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he
> said - if you and your friends
> ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know
> beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
> won't have any problems.
>
> 6) Sometimes the officers will make a couple of small requests to
> test the situation - such as,
> could you turn the bass down a bit - I think that is why we got a
> complaint from the neighbors -
> by complying immediately you give the officer a sense that the
> situation IS under your control and that
> he is dealing with a reasonable human being.
>
> 7) Getting argumentative never works - getting indignant never works
> - personally knowing some of
> the officer's fellow officers and being able to name drop - that
> works - but be sure of your relationship
> with the officer who's name you are dropping.
>
> 8) Getting the name of the officers, and their cards if possible is
> hugely helpful - especially if
> you have already dealt with one officer situation that evening - it
> is not uncommon for DIFFERENT
> officers to drop by - the sheriff, the local police, the state
> police, the park police ALL might have
> some jurisdiction over your location - it is helpful to be able to
> say Officer so and so of the sheriff's
> dept was already here this evening, here is his card - this is what
> we discussed . . . .
>
> 9) Finally, if the word is NO - yield and get you, your stuff and
> all of the people out of there
> as quickly and quietly as possible - IF you have a back-up location,
> that helps a lot - but do NOT
> distribute ANYTHING with that information written down - telling
> people to head in whatever direction
> signaling "everyone's going home now" and pay special attention to
> driving carefully !!!
> Use your info line for the back-up location info (if you can trust
> it) or word of mouth, only.
>
> I hope this helps . . . . .
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

        b=sS3+b2b0ov3t+AEmIeRkLf74uvLU3IrVQjN5AbXBMsMNqFafH9Pe4K3RA9K0iXtU9al/YpUEBmhO74MuJfBvBXyXSK0oECroY4UaWWHniDiOP0S7m8q9+HuZiPz/trCc28Eo3/3R8LY/CckyfrYRoKYpiLdphI8k/FmzTAEHhsE=
Message-ID: <49fc3ffd0710111424k7b7be6a7jf3f61b726e1790ba@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 14:24:51 -0700
From: pinkko <ealaughlin@gmail.com>
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <BAY110-W28A879E4AB517CF70BA74D85A70@phx.gbl>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?

------=_Part_20441_1071356.1192137891459
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

The quickest way to get arrested is to treat a cop like he's the enemy.

On 10/11/07, electrofunk138@hotmail.com <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
>
> You don't have to say SHIT to a cop. In fact - anything you say is likely
> to hang you out to dry when court time comes around, so mums the word. On=
ly
> give them your ID. You honestly dont have to say anything beyond that.
>
>
> > Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 13:21:19 -0700
> > To: terry@hyperreal.org; rationalhatter@gmail.com
> > From: surfpunk@well.com
> > CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?
> >
> >
> >>
> >>Anyone else got some experience/knowledge with this??
> >
> >
> > Tips on dealing with "authorities" - all based on personal experience.
> >
> > 1) If you are doing an event, and you are not sure how entirely
> > 'legal' such an event might be -
> > have at least one partner - and have a designated role for each
> > partner for the evening - one partner
> > should be the 'spokesperson' for the event and be ready to say things
> > like "yes, officer, this is my event -
> > what can i do to help you ?" . . . the other partner, should stay out
> > of it - entirely - that way, if a trip
> > to the station is the end result, one of you is free, has access to
> > phones and bail money, etc.
> >
> > 2) Do not try to bullshit the officer, do not try to make the
> > officer your "buddy" or new best friend,
> > do not LIE to the officer, carry valid and current ID and let the
> > officer see it as soon as he asks to
> > see it - though one time, I had left my ID in the car, because, as I
> > explained, I had not wanted to
> > risk losing it on the beach at night where we were doing our
> > questionably legal event - the officer
> > in that case was willing to accompany me to my car to inspect my ID -
> > this served the additional
> > purpose of getting the officer away from the party.
> >
> > Additional tip - being able to honestly look the officer in the eye
> > helps a lot. Taking responsibility
> > for what is going on helps a lot.
> >
> > 3) Do your own "policing" as the event goes on - it really isn't as
> > much fun, but somebody has to
> > stay completely sober (one or two of the people RESPONSIBLE for
> > putting on the event) for the
> > duration of the event - this allows the sober person to be ready to
> > deal with any authorities and/or
> > any real emergency situations. - By doing your own "policing" I
> > mean, walking around and being
> > aware of any situations that might be threatening to get out of
> > control - like the arrival of a posse
> > that is already beyond socially acceptable drunk, or the arrival of
> > people intent on setting off a lot
> > of fireworks - believe it or not, fireworks draw the attention of
> > authorities - even more than a thumping
> > bass. Once you become aware of a potential problem, recruit your
> > friends and the people you know
> > to 'keep an eye' on the potential problem situation - surprisingly
> > often, one of your friends might
> > know someone in the "drunk posse" and the friend just saying hi, will
> > chill the whole situation down.
> >
> > 4) I know it is a "downer" but do not be afraid to turn the music
> > down or off if you have good
> > reason to - ie authorities seem to be cruising the area, or a drunken
> > posse is getting out of hand -
> > the people who you want at your event understand - they do not want
> > to be sent out into the street
> > or on the way home earlier than expected - 20 minutes of quiet, or
> > the focus of the entire crowd
> > on a threatening posse and really chill things out - allowing you to
> > get back on track for the rest
> > of the evening.
> >
> > 5) Be careful not to admit to any more than you have to - remember,
> > don't lie - but you don't have
> > to volunteer a lot, either. I was once asked if what was going on
> > was "a rave" - I answered it was a gathering
> > of friends who liked to get together and dance all night once and a
> > while. Rave was the buzzword
> > that generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled
> > at my answer and said -
> > OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let
> > you and your friends dance until sunrise -
> > but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then
> > showed the officer all of
> > the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took
> > all of the information from my ID
> > and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone
> > there, I would be arrested, and
> > if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested - He
> > gave me his card - and left.
> >
> > I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had
> > handled the situation
> > and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he
> > said - if you and your friends
> > ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know
> > beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
> > won't have any problems.
> >
> > 6) Sometimes the officers will make a couple of small requests to
> > test the situation - such as,
> > could you turn the bass down a bit - I think that is why we got a
> > complaint from the neighbors -
> > by complying immediately you give the officer a sense that the
> > situation IS under your control and that
> > he is dealing with a reasonable human being.
> >
> > 7) Getting argumentative never works - getting indignant never works
> > - personally knowing some of
> > the officer's fellow officers and being able to name drop - that
> > works - but be sure of your relationship
> > with the officer who's name you are dropping.
> >
> > 8) Getting the name of the officers, and their cards if possible is
> > hugely helpful - especially if
> > you have already dealt with one officer situation that evening - it
> > is not uncommon for DIFFERENT
> > officers to drop by - the sheriff, the local police, the state
> > police, the park police ALL might have
> > some jurisdiction over your location - it is helpful to be able to
> > say Officer so and so of the sheriff's
> > dept was already here this evening, here is his card - this is what
> > we discussed . . . .
> >
> > 9) Finally, if the word is NO - yield and get you, your stuff and
> > all of the people out of there
> > as quickly and quietly as possible - IF you have a back-up location,
> > that helps a lot - but do NOT
> > distribute ANYTHING with that information written down - telling
> > people to head in whatever direction
> > signaling "everyone's going home now" and pay special attention to
> > driving carefully !!!
> > Use your info line for the back-up location info (if you can trust
> > it) or word of mouth, only.
> >
> > I hope this helps . . . . .
> >
> >
> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> >
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] fact or fiction?



I am not advocating that - but you have every right to "remain slient". The=
re's a whole reason that they have the "anything you say cand and will be u=
sed against you" in the Miranda - that's cuz that's how they convict people=
!!!

9 times out of 10, unless you are caught red-handed doing something (and ev=
en still, maintaining your silence can still help) you get yourself locked =
up by talking too much. You offer up only your identity, and basic informat=
ion - nothing else.=20

This is advice from my lawyer, who was an ex cop...


> Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 14:24:51 -0700

>>> Tips on dealing with "authorities" - all based on personal experience.
>>>
>>> 1) If you are doing an event, and you are not sure how entirely
>>> 'legal' such an event might be -
>>> have at least one partner - and have a designated role for each
>>> partner for the evening - one partner
>>> should be the 'spokesperson' for the event and be ready to say things
>>> like "yes, officer, this is my event -
>>> what can i do to help you ?" . . . the other partner, should stay out
>>> of it - entirely - that way, if a trip
>>> to the station is the end result, one of you is free, has access to
>>> phones and bail money, etc.
>>>
>>> 2) Do not try to bullshit the officer, do not try to make the
>>> officer your "buddy" or new best friend,
>>> do not LIE to the officer, carry valid and current ID and let the
>>> officer see it as soon as he asks to
>>> see it - though one time, I had left my ID in the car, because, as I
>>> explained, I had not wanted to
>>> risk losing it on the beach at night where we were doing our
>>> questionably legal event - the officer
>>> in that case was willing to accompany me to my car to inspect my ID -
>>> this served the additional
>>> purpose of getting the officer away from the party.
>>>
>>> Additional tip - being able to honestly look the officer in the eye
>>> helps a lot. Taking responsibility
>>> for what is going on helps a lot.
>>>
>>> 3) Do your own "policing" as the event goes on - it really isn't as
>>> much fun, but somebody has to
>>> stay completely sober (one or two of the people RESPONSIBLE for
>>> putting on the event) for the
>>> duration of the event - this allows the sober person to be ready to
>>> deal with any authorities and/or
>>> any real emergency situations. - By doing your own "policing" I
>>> mean, walking around and being
>>> aware of any situations that might be threatening to get out of
>>> control - like the arrival of a posse
>>> that is already beyond socially acceptable drunk, or the arrival of
>>> people intent on setting off a lot
>>> of fireworks - believe it or not, fireworks draw the attention of
>>> authorities - even more than a thumping
>>> bass. Once you become aware of a potential problem, recruit your
>>> friends and the people you know
>>> to 'keep an eye' on the potential problem situation - surprisingly
>>> often, one of your friends might
>>> know someone in the "drunk posse" and the friend just saying hi, will
>>> chill the whole situation down.
>>>
>>> 4) I know it is a "downer" but do not be afraid to turn the music
>>> down or off if you have good
>>> reason to - ie authorities seem to be cruising the area, or a drunken
>>> posse is getting out of hand -
>>> the people who you want at your event understand - they do not want
>>> to be sent out into the street
>>> or on the way home earlier than expected - 20 minutes of quiet, or
>>> the focus of the entire crowd
>>> on a threatening posse and really chill things out - allowing you to
>>> get back on track for the rest
>>> of the evening.
>>>
>>> 5) Be careful not to admit to any more than you have to - remember,
>>> don't lie - but you don't have
>>> to volunteer a lot, either. I was once asked if what was going on
>>> was "a rave" - I answered it was a gathering
>>> of friends who liked to get together and dance all night once and a
>>> while. Rave was the buzzword
>>> that generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled
>>> at my answer and said -
>>> OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let
>>> you and your friends dance until sunrise -
>>> but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then
>>> showed the officer all of
>>> the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took
>>> all of the information from my ID
>>> and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone
>>> there, I would be arrested, and
>>> if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested - He
>>> gave me his card - and left.
>>>
>>> I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had
>>> handled the situation
>>> and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he
>>> said - if you and your friends
>>> ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know
>>> beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
>>> won't have any problems.
>>>
>>> 6) Sometimes the officers will make a couple of small requests to
>>> test the situation - such as,
>>> could you turn the bass down a bit - I think that is why we got a
>>> complaint from the neighbors -
>>> by complying immediately you give the officer a sense that the
>>> situation IS under your control and that
>>> he is dealing with a reasonable human being.
>>>
>>> 7) Getting argumentative never works - getting indignant never works
>>> - personally knowing some of
>>> the officer's fellow officers and being able to name drop - that
>>> works - but be sure of your relationship
>>> with the officer who's name you are dropping.
>>>
>>> 8) Getting the name of the officers, and their cards if possible is
>>> hugely helpful - especially if
>>> you have already dealt with one officer situation that evening - it
>>> is not uncommon for DIFFERENT
>>> officers to drop by - the sheriff, the local police, the state
>>> police, the park police ALL might have
>>> some jurisdiction over your location - it is helpful to be able to
>>> say Officer so and so of the sheriff's
>>> dept was already here this evening, here is his card - this is what
>>> we discussed . . . .
>>>
>>> 9) Finally, if the word is NO - yield and get you, your stuff and
>>> all of the people out of there
>>> as quickly and quietly as possible - IF you have a back-up location,
>>> that helps a lot - but do NOT
>>> distribute ANYTHING with that information written down - telling
>>> people to head in whatever direction
>>> signaling "everyone's going home now" and pay special attention to
>>> driving carefully !!!
>>> Use your info line for the back-up location info (if you can trust
>>> it) or word of mouth, only.
>>>
>>> I hope this helps . . . . .
>>>

Sound advice.

On 10/11/07, electrofunk138@hotmail.com <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
>
>
> I am not advocating that - but you have every right to "remain slient".
> There's a whole reason that they have the "anything you say cand and will=
 be
> used against you" in the Miranda - that's cuz that's how they convict
> people!!!
>
> 9 times out of 10, unless you are caught red-handed doing something (and
> even still, maintaining your silence can still help) you get yourself loc=
ked
> up by talking too much. You offer up only your identity, and basic
> information - nothing else.
>
> This is advice from my lawyer, who was an ex cop...
>
>
> > Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 14:24:51 -0700
> > From: ealaughlin@gmail.com
> > To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?
> >
> > The quickest way to get arrested is to treat a cop like he's the enemy.
> >
> > On 10/11/07, electrofunk138@hotmail.com  wrote:
> >>
> >>
> >> You don't have to say SHIT to a cop. In fact - anything you say is
> likely
> >> to hang you out to dry when court time comes around, so mums the word.
> Only
> >> give them your ID. You honestly dont have to say anything beyond that.
> >>
> >>
> >>> Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 13:21:19 -0700
> >>> To: terry@hyperreal.org; rationalhatter@gmail.com
> >>> From: surfpunk@well.com
> >>> CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>>
> >>>>Anyone else got some experience/knowledge with this??
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> Tips on dealing with "authorities" - all based on personal experience=
.
> >>>
> >>> 1) If you are doing an event, and you are not sure how entirely
> >>> 'legal' such an event might be -
> >>> have at least one partner - and have a designated role for each
> >>> partner for the evening - one partner
> >>> should be the 'spokesperson' for the event and be ready to say things
> >>> like "yes, officer, this is my event -
> >>> what can i do to help you ?" . . . the other partner, should stay out
> >>> of it - entirely - that way, if a trip
> >>> to the station is the end result, one of you is free, has access to
> >>> phones and bail money, etc.
> >>>
> >>> 2) Do not try to bullshit the officer, do not try to make the
> >>> officer your "buddy" or new best friend,
> >>> do not LIE to the officer, carry valid and current ID and let the
> >>> officer see it as soon as he asks to
> >>> see it - though one time, I had left my ID in the car, because, as I
> >>> explained, I had not wanted to
> >>> risk losing it on the beach at night where we were doing our
> >>> questionably legal event - the officer
> >>> in that case was willing to accompany me to my car to inspect my ID -
> >>> this served the additional
> >>> purpose of getting the officer away from the party.
> >>>
> >>> Additional tip - being able to honestly look the officer in the eye
> >>> helps a lot. Taking responsibility
> >>> for what is going on helps a lot.
> >>>
> >>> 3) Do your own "policing" as the event goes on - it really isn't as
> >>> much fun, but somebody has to
> >>> stay completely sober (one or two of the people RESPONSIBLE for
> >>> putting on the event) for the
> >>> duration of the event - this allows the sober person to be ready to
> >>> deal with any authorities and/or
> >>> any real emergency situations. - By doing your own "policing" I
> >>> mean, walking around and being
> >>> aware of any situations that might be threatening to get out of
> >>> control - like the arrival of a posse
> >>> that is already beyond socially acceptable drunk, or the arrival of
> >>> people intent on setting off a lot
> >>> of fireworks - believe it or not, fireworks draw the attention of
> >>> authorities - even more than a thumping
> >>> bass. Once you become aware of a potential problem, recruit your
> >>> friends and the people you know
> >>> to 'keep an eye' on the potential problem situation - surprisingly
> >>> often, one of your friends might
> >>> know someone in the "drunk posse" and the friend just saying hi, will
> >>> chill the whole situation down.
> >>>
> >>> 4) I know it is a "downer" but do not be afraid to turn the music
> >>> down or off if you have good
> >>> reason to - ie authorities seem to be cruising the area, or a drunken
> >>> posse is getting out of hand -
> >>> the people who you want at your event understand - they do not want
> >>> to be sent out into the street
> >>> or on the way home earlier than expected - 20 minutes of quiet, or
> >>> the focus of the entire crowd
> >>> on a threatening posse and really chill things out - allowing you to
> >>> get back on track for the rest
> >>> of the evening.
> >>>
> >>> 5) Be careful not to admit to any more than you have to - remember,
> >>> don't lie - but you don't have
> >>> to volunteer a lot, either. I was once asked if what was going on
> >>> was "a rave" - I answered it was a gathering
> >>> of friends who liked to get together and dance all night once and a
> >>> while. Rave was the buzzword
> >>> that generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled
> >>> at my answer and said -
> >>> OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let
> >>> you and your friends dance until sunrise -
> >>> but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then
> >>> showed the officer all of
> >>> the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took
> >>> all of the information from my ID
> >>> and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone
> >>> there, I would be arrested, and
> >>> if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested - He
> >>> gave me his card - and left.
> >>>
> >>> I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had
> >>> handled the situation
> >>> and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he
> >>> said - if you and your friends
> >>> ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know
> >>> beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
> >>> won't have any problems.
> >>>
> >>> 6) Sometimes the officers will make a couple of small requests to
> >>> test the situation - such as,
> >>> could you turn the bass down a bit - I think that is why we got a
> >>> complaint from the neighbors -
> >>> by complying immediately you give the officer a sense that the
> >>> situation IS under your control and that
> >>> he is dealing with a reasonable human being.
> >>>
> >>> 7) Getting argumentative never works - getting indignant never works
> >>> - personally knowing some of
> >>> the officer's fellow officers and being able to name drop - that
> >>> works - but be sure of your relationship
> >>> with the officer who's name you are dropping.
> >>>
> >>> 8) Getting the name of the officers, and their cards if possible is
> >>> hugely helpful - especially if
> >>> you have already dealt with one officer situation that evening - it
> >>> is not uncommon for DIFFERENT
> >>> officers to drop by - the sheriff, the local police, the state
> >>> police, the park police ALL might have
> >>> some jurisdiction over your location - it is helpful to be able to
> >>> say Officer so and so of the sheriff's
> >>> dept was already here this evening, here is his card - this is what
> >>> we discussed . . . .
> >>>
> >>> 9) Finally, if the word is NO - yield and get you, your stuff and
> >>> all of the people out of there
> >>> as quickly and quietly as possible - IF you have a back-up location,
> >>> that helps a lot - but do NOT
> >>> distribute ANYTHING with that information written down - telling
> >>> people to head in whatever direction
> >>> signaling "everyone's going home now" and pay special attention to
> >>> driving carefully !!!
> >>> Use your info line for the back-up location info (if you can trust
> >>> it) or word of mouth, only.
> >>>
> >>> I hope this helps . . . . .
> >>>
> >>>
> >>> ---------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Saturday! [KONTROL] vs. Surefire w/ Germany's amazing D.DIGGLER!

So, let me tell you a quick little story.

Back around 2001, I was chatting with a bona fide music freak online
and asking him what were some of his favorite sets ever.  He hooked me
up with this 4 hour set by a German guy named, amusingly enough, Dirk
Diggler .  It started off with some of the deepest, most sparse dub
techno imaginable, then gradually gained steam, expertly covering
every style and tempo of minimal/techno until the last couple hours
were just straight up slamming dancefloor killers.  In the years since
then, I'd have to say this set has become like an old friend to me,
and the DJ responsible for it has become one of my all-time favorites,
sparking an ongoing interest in the minimal techno genre which
eventually led to the founding of the [KONTROL] parties.

After religiously following (and loving) his sets and productions in
the 6 years since then, this year at the Detroit Electronic Music
Festival I finally got to see him play in person, where he dropped an
amazing 2 hour live/dj set on the main stage.  If you talk to any
techno fan that was there, you'll find a bunch of people ready to
assert that his set was one of the highlights of the entire festival,
hands down. And this year's fest had some sizzling sets indeed, by the
likes of Richie Hawtin, Luciano, Marco Carola, Steve Bug, Jeff Mills,
and many more. This guy is good. Really good.

So, when [KONTROL] was approached by SUREFIRE (SF's illest dubstep
crew) about wanting to collaborate on a show at the beautiful new
Temple nightclub, we thought about who we'd really like to hear on
that ridiculous thumping sound system, and the choice was clear...
Diggler!  We shot his agent an email, crunched the numbers, and
decided to make it happen!  Hot on the release of his brand new studio
album EM.Pulse, he's flying over all the way from Frankfurt just for
this one gig, and we're certain it's going to be one not soon
forgotten!

And for you dubstep fans out there, Surefire is bringing out no less
than 3 huge headliners representing some of the hottest names in the
genre.  Even if you're unfamiliar with this rapidly growing style of
music, there's no better place to indulge your curiosity than at this
show.  We have a strong feeling there are going to be plenty of
dubstep fans leaving with a new appreciation for minimal, and likewise
techno heads feelin' the dubstep vibe!

We hope you can join us for this fantastic night of music for the
mind, body, and spirit.  We promise you won't be disappointed.


-----> Greg and the [KONTROL] crew

_______________________________________________________


Saturday, October 13, 2007

[KONTROL] vs. SUREFIRE

TECHNO vs. DUBSTEP



featuring in the TECHNO main room:

<<< D.DIGGLER >>>

(Resopal Schallware, Force Tracks, Cocoon, Raum...musik | Frankfurt)

Craig Kuna  (ESDJCO, Concept SF)

>From this week's SF Bay Guardian:

Give props to these two DJ-promotion groups, which have teamed up to
organize a unique event: a face-off between dubstep and techno DJs. In
a sense, this could be like one of those family reunions at which
estranged half brothers first meet. Dubstep would be the loud
youngster, a hip descendant of dub, garage, and drum 'n' bass (it's
complicated). Techno would be the elder and moodier teenager, the one
who's been around the block but doesn't flaunt it. With German techno
talent D.Diggler and Brit dubstep mixers Benga and Hatcha, there'll be
small moments of transitional awkwardness overshadowed by an impulse
to enjoy the camaraderie and dance to deep beats.
--Kevin Lee

On Thu, 11 Oct 2007, Jim Cyr wrote:

> OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let you and

Thanks Jim for the knowledge bomb :-)

A related anecdote...

At a Cloudfactory at the "pit" in Monterey 2004, we cleaned up 
the spot, A LOT. Brought up about 14 trash bags and some shopping 
carts and a toilet. Left them at the trailhead for pickup.

We did this BEFORE starting to setup sound or anything.
Authorities came for an unrelated incident, but they were 
appreciative of our efforts. Didn't even question the party 
while in full view at all.

Beach clean-up raves are GRATE!

-terry

 rave" - I answered it was a gathering=0A> of friends who liked to get toge=
ther and dance all night once and a while. =0A> Rave was the buzzword=0A> t=
hat generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled at my =
=0A> answer and said -=0A> OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean =
- I'm going to let you and =0A> your friends dance until sunrise -=0A=0ATha=
nks Jim for the knowledge bomb :-)=0A=0AA related anecdote...=0A=0AAt a Clo=
udfactory at the "pit" in Monterey 2004, we cleaned up =0Athe spot, A LOT. =
Brought up about 14 trash bags and some shopping =0Acarts and a toilet. Lef=
t them at the trailhead for pickup.=0A=0AWe did this BEFORE starting to set=
up sound or anything.=0AAuthorities came for an unrelated incident, but the=
y were =0Aappreciative of our efforts. Didn't even question the party =0Awh=
ile in full view at all.=0A=0ABeach clean-up raves are GRATE!=0A=0A-terry=
