Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Ann Coulter now hates Jews....

Not that anyone needs ANOTHER reason to hate Ann
Coulter, but just in case you do, read the transcript
from her interview with Donny Deutsch today...

Seriously, what percentage of people agree with the
things she says, writes, and does? I know no one, do
you?

E



DEUTSCH: Let me ask you a question. Were going to get
off strengths and weakness for a second. If you had
your way, and all of your  forget that any of them 

COULTER: I like this.

DEUTSCH:  are calculated marketing teases, and your
dreams, which are genuine, came true having to do with
immigration, having to do with womens  with abortion
 what would this country look like?

COULTER: UMMMMM (pause)  It would look like New York
City during the Republican National Convention. In
fact, thats what I think heaven is going to look
like.

DEUTSCH: And what did that look like?

COULTER: Happy, joyful Republicans in the greatest
city in the world.

DEUTSCH: No, no, no, no, but Im talking about this
country. You dont want to make this country  its
not about Republicans. Im saying, what would the
fabric of this country look like? Forget that the
Republicans would be running the show.

COULTER: Well, everyone would root for America, the
Democratic Party would look like Joe Lieberman, the
Republican Party would look like Duncan Hunter 

DEUTSCH: No, no, no, I dont want  Im not talking
about politically the landscape. What would our 
would we be safer? Would people be happier? Would they
be more 

COULTER: We would be a lot safer.

DEUTSCH: Would there be more tolerance? Would there be
 would women be happier, would the races get along
better? The Ann Coulter subscription  prescription.
What  tell me what would be different in our fabric
of country, because 

COULTER: Well, all of those things.

DEUTSCH: I can give  I can give you an argument there
would be more divisiveness, that there would be more
hate 

COULTER: Oh, no.

DEUTSCH: That there would be a bigger difference
between the rich and the poor, a lot of other  tell
me what  why this would be a better world? Lets give
you  Im going to give you  say this is your show.

COULTER: Well, OK, take the Republican National
Convention. People were happy. Theyre Christian.
Theyre tolerant. They defend America, they 

DEUTSCH: Christian  so we should be Christian? It
would be better if we were all Christian?

COULTER: Yes.

DEUTSCH: We should all be Christian?

COULTER: Yes. Would you like to come to church with
me, Donny?

DEUTSCH: So I should not be a Jew, I should be a
Christian, and this would be a better place?

COULTER: Well, you could be a practicing Jew, but
youre not.

DEUTSCH: I actually am. Thats not true. I really am.
But  so we would be better if we were  if people 
if there were no Jews, no Buddhists 

COULTER: Whenever Im harangued by 

DEUTSCH:  in this country? You cant believe that.

COULTER:  you know, liberals on diversity 

DEUTSCH: Here you go again.

COULTER: No, its true. I give all of these speeches
at megachurches across America, and the one thing
thats really striking about it is how utterly,
completely diverse they are, and completely
unself-consciously. You walk past a mixed-race couple
in New York, and its like they have a chip on their
shoulder. Theyre just waiting for somebody to say
something, as if anybody would. And 

DEUTSCH: I dont agree with that. I dont agree with
that at all. Maybe you have the chip looking at them.
I see a lot of interracial couples, and I dont see
any more or less chips there either way. Thats
erroneous.

COULTER: No. In fact, there was an entire Seinfeld
episode about Elaine and her boyfriend dating because
they wanted to be a mixed-race couple, so youre
lying.

DEUTSCH: Oh, because of some Seinfeld episode? OK.

COULTER: But yeah, I think thats reflective of whats
going on in the culture, but it is completely striking
that at these huge megachurches  the idea that, you
know, the more Christian you are, the less tolerant
you would be is preposterous.

DEUTSCH: That isnt what I said, but you said I should
not  we should just throw Judaism away and we should
all be Christians, then, or 

COULTER: Yeah.

DEUTSCH: Really?

COULTER: Well, its a lot easier. Its kind of a fast
track.

DEUTSCH: Really?

COULTER: Yeah. You have to obey.

DEUTSCH: You cant possibly believe that.

COULTER: Yes.

DEUTSCH: You cant possibly  youre too educated, you
cant  youre like my friend in 

COULTER: Do you know what Christianity is? We believe
your religion, but you have to obey.

DEUTSCH: No, no, no, but I mean 

COULTER: We have the fast-track program.

DEUTSCH: Why dont I put you with the head of Iran? I
mean, come on. You cant believe that.

COULTER: The head of Iran is not a Christian.

DEUTSCH: No, but in fact, Lets wipe Israel 

COULTER: I dont know if youve been paying attention.

DEUTSCH: Lets wipe Israel off the earth. I mean,
what, no Jews?

COULTER: No, we think  we just want Jews to be
perfected, as they say.

DEUTSCH: Wow, you didnt really say that, did you?

COULTER: Yes. That is what Christianity is. We believe
the Old Testament, but ours is more like Federal
Express. You have to obey laws. We know were all
sinners 

DEUTSCH: In my old days, I would have argued  when
you say something absurd like that, theres no 

COULTER: Whats absurd?

DEUTSCH: Jews are going to be perfected. Im going to
go off and try to perfect myself 

COULTER: Well, thats what the New Testament says.

DEUTSCH: Ann Coulter, author of If Democrats Had Any
Brains, Theyd Be Republicans, and if Ann Coulter had
any brains, she would not say Jews need to be
perfected. Im offended by that personally. And well
have more Big Idea when we come back.

(BREAK)

DEUTSCH: Welcome back to The Big Idea. During the
break, Ann said she wanted to explain her last
comment. So Im going to give her a chance. So you
dont think that was offensive?

COULTER: No. Im sorry. It is not intended to be. I
dont think you should take it that way, but that is
what Christians consider themselves: perfected Jews.
We believe the Old Testament. As you know from the Old
Testament, God was constantly getting fed up with
humans for not being able to, you know, live up to all
the laws. What Christians believe  this is just a
statement of what the New Testament is  is that
thats why Christ came and died for our sins.
Christians believe the Old Testament. You dont
believe our testament.

DEUTSCH: You said  your exact words were, Jews need
to be perfected. Those are the words out of your
mouth.

COULTER: No, Im saying thats what a Christian is.

DEUTSCH: But thats what you said  dont you see how
hateful, how anti-Semitic 

COULTER: No!

DEUTSCH: How do you not see? Youre an educated woman.
How do you not see that?

COULTER: That isnt hateful at all.

DEUTSCH: But thats even a scarier thought. OK 

COULTER: No, no, no, no, no. I dont want you being
offended by this. This is what Christians consider
themselves, because our testament is the continuation
of your testament. You know that. So we think Jews go
to heaven. I mean (Jerry) Falwell himself said that,
but you have to follow laws. Ours is Christ died for
our sins. We consider ourselves perfected Christians.
For me to say that for you to become a Christian is to
become a perfected Christian is not offensive at all.

DEUTSCH: We will let the audience decide then, wont
we? Ann Coulter. New book. More Big Idea straight ahead.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp: Saturday! [KONTROL] vs. Surefire w/ Germany's amazing D.DIGGLER!

Any German techno producer who goes by the moniker Dirk Diggler is
obviously one cheeky monkey - but his material has consistantly been
some of the true-est shit out there.

Should be a fun night with all the heads and dubstep crews giving
Temple the right vibe.

-SK


On 10/11/07, Greg Bird <bird415@gmail.com> wrote:
> So, let me tell you a quick little story.
>
> Back around 2001, I was chatting with a bona fide music freak online
> and asking him what were some of his favorite sets ever.  He hooked me
> up with this 4 hour set by a German guy named, amusingly enough, Dirk
> Diggler .  It started off with some of the deepest, most sparse dub
> techno imaginable, then gradually gained steam, expertly covering
> every style and tempo of minimal/techno until the last couple hours
> were just straight up slamming dancefloor killers.  In the years since
> then, I'd have to say this set has become like an old friend to me,
> and the DJ responsible for it has become one of my all-time favorites,
> sparking an ongoing interest in the minimal techno genre which
> eventually led to the founding of the [KONTROL] parties.
>
> After religiously following (and loving) his sets and productions in
> the 6 years since then, this year at the Detroit Electronic Music
> Festival I finally got to see him play in person, where he dropped an
> amazing 2 hour live/dj set on the main stage.  If you talk to any
> techno fan that was there, you'll find a bunch of people ready to
> assert that his set was one of the highlights of the entire festival,
> hands down. And this year's fest had some sizzling sets indeed, by the
> likes of Richie Hawtin, Luciano, Marco Carola, Steve Bug, Jeff Mills,
> and many more. This guy is good. Really good.
>
> So, when [KONTROL] was approached by SUREFIRE (SF's illest dubstep
> crew) about wanting to collaborate on a show at the beautiful new
> Temple nightclub, we thought about who we'd really like to hear on
> that ridiculous thumping sound system, and the choice was clear...
> Diggler!  We shot his agent an email, crunched the numbers, and
> decided to make it happen!  Hot on the release of his brand new studio
> album EM.Pulse, he's flying over all the way from Frankfurt just for
> this one gig, and we're certain it's going to be one not soon
> forgotten!
>
> And for you dubstep fans out there, Surefire is bringing out no less
> than 3 huge headliners representing some of the hottest names in the
> genre.  Even if you're unfamiliar with this rapidly growing style of
> music, there's no better place to indulge your curiosity than at this
> show.  We have a strong feeling there are going to be plenty of
> dubstep fans leaving with a new appreciation for minimal, and likewise
> techno heads feelin' the dubstep vibe!
>
> We hope you can join us for this fantastic night of music for the
> mind, body, and spirit.  We promise you won't be disappointed.
>
>
> -----> Greg and the [KONTROL] crew
>
> _______________________________________________________
>
>
> Saturday, October 13, 2007
>
> [KONTROL] vs. SUREFIRE
>
> TECHNO vs. DUBSTEP
>
>
>
> featuring in the TECHNO main room:
>
> <<< D.DIGGLER >>>
> live/dj set | *exclusive US appearance*
> (Resopal Schallware, Force Tracks, Cocoon, Raum...musik | Frankfurt)
>
> Craig Kuna  (ESDJCO, Concept SF)
> Nikola Baytala  (S.W.A.T., Robsoul, Tweekin')
> Alland Byallo  (Liebe*Detail, Nightlight)
> Sammy D  (Classic, Utensil)
>
>
>
> and in the DUBSTEP catacombs:
>
> BENGA  (Tempa, Fwd, Planet Mu | London)
> HATCHA  (Tempa, Fwd, KissFM, Planet Mu | London)
> Martyn  (Tempa, Offshore, Soul-R | Netherlands)
> DJ Collage  (Masse-One, Jam Jam | Seattle)
>
> Selector Dub-U  (Surefire, Narco.Hz, SubFM)
> DJ G  (Narco.Hz)
> Emcee Child  (Narco.Hz, Grime City)
>
>
>

> http://www.kontrolsf.com/diggler/DigglerH.jpg
>

>

> 540 Howard Street, SF
> 21+ / 10pm-4am / $15

> http://www.digglermusic.com/

> http://www.discogs.com/artist/D.Diggler

> D.Diggler 2007 promo mix:
> http://www.allandbyallo.com/temple/D.Diggler_Promo_for_Sonne_Mond_Sterne_2007_90min.mp3
>
>
>
> From this week's SF Bay Guardian:
>
> Give props to these two DJ-promotion groups, which have teamed up to
> organize a unique event: a face-off between dubstep and techno DJs. In
> a sense, this could be like one of those family reunions at which
> estranged half brothers first meet. Dubstep would be the loud
> youngster, a hip descendant of dub, garage, and drum 'n' bass (it's
> complicated). Techno would be the elder and moodier teenager, the one
> who's been around the block but doesn't flaunt it. With German techno
> talent D.Diggler and Brit dubstep mixers Benga and Hatcha, there'll be
> small moments of transitional awkwardness overshadowed by an impulse
> to enjoy the camaraderie and dance to deep beats.
> --Kevin Lee

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Ann Coulter now hates Jews....

Although I am Jewish, I actually agree with you...
mostly because I understand your point... that
Organized Religion in its worst form is fanatical
regardless of beliefs. That said, I should also voice
my disdain for religion in general, believing whole
heartedly that membrane theory (the convenient coming
together of string theories) will one day prove that
"Horton Hears a Who" was not a childrens picture book,
but actually a true vision of universal theory...

Blah blah blah... at the end of the day, I am a Jew,
not for the religion, but for the cultural connection
to the past, to the community at large, and to the
circumstances my family has endured over the last
centuries directly, and last millenia indirectly as I
see it.

E

PS... Sarillion... you gotta check the car I am
building... and the electric mini-F1 I am designing in
Autodesk Inventor....

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Fri)

This man who wrote this book visited Guernsey, an island off the coast
of France in the English Channel.  Guernsey does not submit to the
privately owned central bank scheme, rather prints their own debt free
pounds.

Check out this link for more info:

http://www.abrrp.us/American%20Debt.htm


Oh and have a nice weekend

DF


--

There were about 60,000 permanent residents; the average family owned
3.3 cars; their unemployment rate was zero and their standard of
living was very high. Also, there was no public debt and a surplus of
public funds was earning them interest. The Guernsey Treasury
increased the money supply by 50% over a 3 year period and this
increase did not cause any inflation. The price for a gallon of gas in
the UK was about $5, but the price in Guernsey was about $2. Contrary
to the teachings of economics in all higher institutions, inflation,
it was claimed, was not related to the volume of money, but rather to
the size of the commercial debt.

- Dr. Jacques Jaikaran, author of "The Debt Virus"

cop says to you... anything he tries to get you to say... it's a =20

ravers an extra special target of their predations.

deal with the filth.  The basics are, be polite... after all he =20
carries a gun and would probably get away with it if he were to =20
decide to shoot you dead right there.... but never, ever EVER =20
volunteer any information beyond the absolute bare minimum required =20
by law.

>>
>>> Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 13:21:19 -0700
>>> To: terry@hyperreal.org; rationalhatter@gmail.com
>>> From: surfpunk@well.com
>>> CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?
>>>
>>>
>>>>
>>>> Anyone else got some experience/knowledge with this??
>>>
>>>
>>> Tips on dealing with "authorities" - all based on personal =20
>>> experience.
>>>
>>> 1) If you are doing an event, and you are not sure how entirely
>>> 'legal' such an event might be -
>>> have at least one partner - and have a designated role for each
>>> partner for the evening - one partner
>>> should be the 'spokesperson' for the event and be ready to say =20
>>> things
>>> like "yes, officer, this is my event -
>>> what can i do to help you ?" . . . the other partner, should stay =20=

>>> out
>>> of it - entirely - that way, if a trip
>>> to the station is the end result, one of you is free, has access to
>>> phones and bail money, etc.
>>>
>>> 2) Do not try to bullshit the officer, do not try to make the
>>> officer your "buddy" or new best friend,
>>> do not LIE to the officer, carry valid and current ID and let the
>>> officer see it as soon as he asks to
>>> see it - though one time, I had left my ID in the car, because, as I
>>> explained, I had not wanted to
>>> risk losing it on the beach at night where we were doing our
>>> questionably legal event - the officer
>>> in that case was willing to accompany me to my car to inspect my =20
>>> ID -
>>> this served the additional
>>> purpose of getting the officer away from the party.
>>>
>>> Additional tip - being able to honestly look the officer in the eye
>>> helps a lot. Taking responsibility
>>> for what is going on helps a lot.
>>>
>>> 3) Do your own "policing" as the event goes on - it really isn't as
>>> much fun, but somebody has to
>>> stay completely sober (one or two of the people RESPONSIBLE for
>>> putting on the event) for the
>>> duration of the event - this allows the sober person to be ready to
>>> deal with any authorities and/or
>>> any real emergency situations. - By doing your own "policing" I
>>> mean, walking around and being
>>> aware of any situations that might be threatening to get out of
>>> control - like the arrival of a posse
>>> that is already beyond socially acceptable drunk, or the arrival of
>>> people intent on setting off a lot
>>> of fireworks - believe it or not, fireworks draw the attention of
>>> authorities - even more than a thumping
>>> bass. Once you become aware of a potential problem, recruit your
>>> friends and the people you know
>>> to 'keep an eye' on the potential problem situation - surprisingly
>>> often, one of your friends might
>>> know someone in the "drunk posse" and the friend just saying hi, =20
>>> will
>>> chill the whole situation down.
>>>
>>> 4) I know it is a "downer" but do not be afraid to turn the music
>>> down or off if you have good
>>> reason to - ie authorities seem to be cruising the area, or a =20
>>> drunken
>>> posse is getting out of hand -
>>> the people who you want at your event understand - they do not want
>>> to be sent out into the street
>>> or on the way home earlier than expected - 20 minutes of quiet, or
>>> the focus of the entire crowd
>>> on a threatening posse and really chill things out - allowing you to
>>> get back on track for the rest
>>> of the evening.
>>>
>>> 5) Be careful not to admit to any more than you have to - remember,
>>> don't lie - but you don't have
>>> to volunteer a lot, either. I was once asked if what was going on
>>> was "a rave" - I answered it was a gathering
>>> of friends who liked to get together and dance all night once and a
>>> while. Rave was the buzzword
>>> that generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled
>>> at my answer and said -
>>> OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let
>>> you and your friends dance until sunrise -
>>> but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then
>>> showed the officer all of
>>> the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took
>>> all of the information from my ID
>>> and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone
>>> there, I would be arrested, and
>>> if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested =20
>>> - He
>>> gave me his card - and left.
>>>
>>> I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had
>>> handled the situation
>>> and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he
>>> said - if you and your friends
>>> ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know
>>> beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
>>> won't have any problems.
>>>
>>> 6) Sometimes the officers will make a couple of small requests to
>>> test the situation - such as,
>>> could you turn the bass down a bit - I think that is why we got a
>>> complaint from the neighbors -
>>> by complying immediately you give the officer a sense that the
>>> situation IS under your control and that
>>> he is dealing with a reasonable human being.
>>>
>>> 7) Getting argumentative never works - getting indignant never works
>>> - personally knowing some of
>>> the officer's fellow officers and being able to name drop - that
>>> works - but be sure of your relationship
>>> with the officer who's name you are dropping.
>>>
>>> 8) Getting the name of the officers, and their cards if possible is
>>> hugely helpful - especially if
>>> you have already dealt with one officer situation that evening - it
>>> is not uncommon for DIFFERENT
>>> officers to drop by - the sheriff, the local police, the state
>>> police, the park police ALL might have
>>> some jurisdiction over your location - it is helpful to be able to
>>> say Officer so and so of the sheriff's
>>> dept was already here this evening, here is his card - this is what
>>> we discussed . . . .
>>>
>>> 9) Finally, if the word is NO - yield and get you, your stuff and
>>> all of the people out of there
>>> as quickly and quietly as possible - IF you have a back-up location,
>>> that helps a lot - but do NOT
>>> distribute ANYTHING with that information written down - telling
>>> people to head in whatever direction
>>> signaling "everyone's going home now" and pay special attention to
>>> driving carefully !!!
>>> Use your info line for the back-up location info (if you can trust
>>> it) or word of mouth, only.
>>>
>>> I hope this helps . . . . .
>>>
>>>
>>> --------------------------------------------------------------------=20=

>>> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>> There were about 60,000 permanent residents; the average family owned
>> 3.3 cars; their unemployment rate was zero and their standard of
>> living was very high. Also, there was no public debt and a surplus of
>> public funds was earning them interest. The Guernsey Treasury
>> increased the money supply by 50% over a 3 year period and this
>> increase did not cause any inflation. The price for a gallon of gas in
>> the UK was about $5, but the price in Guernsey was about $2. Contrary
>> to the teachings of economics in all higher institutions, inflation,
>> it was claimed, was not related to the volume of money, but rather to
>> the size of the commercial debt.

>>>>Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 13:21:19 -0700
>>>>To: terry@hyperreal.org; rationalhatter@gmail.com
>>>>From: surfpunk@well.com
>>>>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>>Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>Anyone else got some experience/knowledge with this??
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>Tips on dealing with "authorities" - all based on personal
>>>>experience.
>>>>
>>>>1) If you are doing an event, and you are not sure how entirely
>>>>'legal' such an event might be -
>>>>have at least one partner - and have a designated role for each
>>>>partner for the evening - one partner
>>>>should be the 'spokesperson' for the event and be ready to say
>>>>things
>>>>like "yes, officer, this is my event -
>>>>what can i do to help you ?" . . . the other partner, should stay
>>>>out
>>>>of it - entirely - that way, if a trip
>>>>to the station is the end result, one of you is free, has access to
>>>>phones and bail money, etc.
>>>>
>>>>2) Do not try to bullshit the officer, do not try to make the
>>>>officer your "buddy" or new best friend,
>>>>do not LIE to the officer, carry valid and current ID and let the
>>>>officer see it as soon as he asks to
>>>>see it - though one time, I had left my ID in the car, because, as I
>>>>explained, I had not wanted to
>>>>risk losing it on the beach at night where we were doing our
>>>>questionably legal event - the officer
>>>>in that case was willing to accompany me to my car to inspect my
>>>>ID -
>>>>this served the additional
>>>>purpose of getting the officer away from the party.
>>>>
>>>>Additional tip - being able to honestly look the officer in the eye
>>>>helps a lot. Taking responsibility
>>>>for what is going on helps a lot.
>>>>
>>>>3) Do your own "policing" as the event goes on - it really isn't as
>>>>much fun, but somebody has to
>>>>stay completely sober (one or two of the people RESPONSIBLE for
>>>>putting on the event) for the
>>>>duration of the event - this allows the sober person to be ready to
>>>>deal with any authorities and/or
>>>>any real emergency situations. - By doing your own "policing" I
>>>>mean, walking around and being
>>>>aware of any situations that might be threatening to get out of
>>>>control - like the arrival of a posse
>>>>that is already beyond socially acceptable drunk, or the arrival of
>>>>people intent on setting off a lot
>>>>of fireworks - believe it or not, fireworks draw the attention of
>>>>authorities - even more than a thumping
>>>>bass. Once you become aware of a potential problem, recruit your
>>>>friends and the people you know
>>>>to 'keep an eye' on the potential problem situation - surprisingly
>>>>often, one of your friends might
>>>>know someone in the "drunk posse" and the friend just saying hi,
>>>>will
>>>>chill the whole situation down.
>>>>
>>>>4) I know it is a "downer" but do not be afraid to turn the music
>>>>down or off if you have good
>>>>reason to - ie authorities seem to be cruising the area, or a
>>>>drunken
>>>>posse is getting out of hand -
>>>>the people who you want at your event understand - they do not want
>>>>to be sent out into the street
>>>>or on the way home earlier than expected - 20 minutes of quiet, or
>>>>the focus of the entire crowd
>>>>on a threatening posse and really chill things out - allowing you to
>>>>get back on track for the rest
>>>>of the evening.
>>>>
>>>>5) Be careful not to admit to any more than you have to - remember,
>>>>don't lie - but you don't have
>>>>to volunteer a lot, either. I was once asked if what was going on
>>>>was "a rave" - I answered it was a gathering
>>>>of friends who liked to get together and dance all night once and a
>>>>while. Rave was the buzzword
>>>>that generated the 'must shut down now' button - the officer smiled
>>>>at my answer and said -
>>>>OK - this is my beach - I like to keep it clean - I'm going to let
>>>>you and your friends dance until sunrise -
>>>>but you MUST be gone by 7 - and this beach MUST be spotless - I then
>>>>showed the officer all of
>>>>the garbage bags we had to accomplish that purpose - he still took
>>>>all of the information from my ID
>>>>and warned that when he came back at 7 IF there were still anyone
>>>>there, I would be arrested, and
>>>>if there were any garbage left on the beach, I would be arrested
>>>>- He
>>>>gave me his card - and left.
>>>>
>>>>I called him on the following Monday - to thank him for how "we" had
>>>>handled the situation
>>>>and he praised us for how clean we had left the beach - and then, he
>>>>said - if you and your friends
>>>>ever want to come down and dance on my beach,again - let me know
>>>>beforehand- so I'll know its you and you
>>>>won't have any problems.
>>>>
>>>>6) Sometimes the officers will make a couple of small requests to
>>>>test the situation - such as,
>>>>could you turn the bass down a bit - I think that is why we got a
>>>>complaint from the neighbors -
>>>>by complying immediately you give the officer a sense that the
>>>>situation IS under your control and that
>>>>he is dealing with a reasonable human being.
>>>>
>>>>7) Getting argumentative never works - getting indignant never works
>>>>- personally knowing some of
>>>>the officer's fellow officers and being able to name drop - that
>>>>works - but be sure of your relationship
>>>>with the officer who's name you are dropping.
>>>>
>>>>8) Getting the name of the officers, and their cards if possible is
>>>>hugely helpful - especially if
>>>>you have already dealt with one officer situation that evening - it
>>>>is not uncommon for DIFFERENT
>>>>officers to drop by - the sheriff, the local police, the state
>>>>police, the park police ALL might have
>>>>some jurisdiction over your location - it is helpful to be able to
>>>>say Officer so and so of the sheriff's
>>>>dept was already here this evening, here is his card - this is what
>>>>we discussed . . . .
>>>>
>>>>9) Finally, if the word is NO - yield and get you, your stuff and
>>>>all of the people out of there
>>>>as quickly and quietly as possible - IF you have a back-up location,
>>>>that helps a lot - but do NOT
>>>>distribute ANYTHING with that information written down - telling
>>>>people to head in whatever direction
>>>>signaling "everyone's going home now" and pay special attention to
>>>>driving carefully !!!
>>>>Use your info line for the back-up location info (if you can trust
>>>>it) or word of mouth, only.
>>>>
>>>>I hope this helps . . . . .
>>>>
>>>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?




On Thu, Oct 11, 2007 at 11:09:52PM -0700, Sarilion wrote:
> At 09:03 PM 10/11/2007, John B wrote:
> >I'm not sure what rock you've been under, but the pigs ARE your
> >enemy.  Really, who seeks out a job that's so infamous for the
> >rampant abuse of power; except for people who are looking forward to
[...]
> you get to help people.  I'm sure that some of 
> the same kind of people that fight fires fight 
> crime.  

Sure, Sunnyvale has an integrated FD/PD and they switch which they're assigned
to every couple of weeks. :)  (the PD cars have fire gear in the trunk, too)

Seriously, most cops aren't really assholes, but consider if your job was to
cruise around knowing that a large number of people hate you.  They're real
people, most of them start off thinking about how they want to give back to
society, etc... It doesn't take that long for most of them to just want to
survive the day without getting shot in the back.  This is not good for a
positive outlook on life.  A little empathy does go a long way.

As to how to deal with them, friendly politeness and respect do NOT exclude
knowing what not to say.

It's about presence of mind, not fast talking or having a script.

Sure, walk up and ask "Hello officer, how can I help?" or "Can I be of
assistance?"  It's as much a negotiation tactic as anything else.  If you
want to clam up and just call your attorney, go for it.  If not, be smart,
think about what leverage you do or don't have, and what he has.

If he asks "is this your rave?"  you can reply "These are my friends, we're
just here to relax and have a nice time."  Heck, you can even nod.  Just don't
admit to things on his terms.  Redefine in happy, helpful terms.  In short,
suck up without confessing anything.  

If he comments that it's a lot of friends/people, it's easy enough to say
"well, my friends told their friends, and they all know I have an open door
policy for my friends."  Do NOT mention things getting out of hand.

if he says to turn it down, you can say "Sure, I'll go talk to the DJ after
you and I are done talking."

None of which admits to anything, yet all of it keeps you human in his
eyes and brings you partway towards him, making him much more likely to
want to help you.

Attitude IS everything, since yes, he can fuck with you just to make an
example of you if he chooses to.  As long as you don't actually admit to
any wrondoing, you haven't lost anything for trying, and you might actually
get to keep the party going, instead of just "winning" the avoidance of
jail time.

And if you've got an attorney, keep the number on speed dial regardless. :)


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Yes... some cops are nice... but I know first hand people first hand who I
grew up with/went to college with who definitely fit into the Oakland
Riders/Rampart Category.  And I get the feeling, there's a lot more of these
crooked cops than we'd really like to admit.  The ridiculous thing is, in
most cities, the system is set up to protect cops and even keep bad cops on
the force.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?



I didn't actually say anything about them being nice.  They're human, that's
all.  Sure, I've been tailed for driving while asian, mostly out in walnut
creek, or down the peninsula.  SF and Oakland cops have better things to do,
if given some basic politeness, they're smart enough to realize you're smart
enough to keep a handle on things.  Heck, just today one (who actually was
nice about it) let me off for not realizing I'd parked in a towaway zone.
That's a major revenue source for them and one they're encouraged to enforce
so he certainly didn't have to.  He had me and the towtruck was coming down
the street, but getting my cooperative ass out of there instead of backing
up traffic during rush hour was something he was willing to live with.

Even people who aren't particularly nice respond better to people who are.
If you treat them like the assholes some are, even nice people learn to be
assholes.  It's all basic game theory, really.

Hello everyone...
I have a brand new in the the box Battle Pak DJ system from Numark.  It is a
starter system and good for someone looking to explore vinyl.  I'm asking
$300.

~Matthew

http://www.numark.com/battlepakv4
DM950 mixer, 2 TT1625 turntables with cartridges and a pair of slipmats, a
pair of HF125 headphones, and all connecting cables. Plug in and get
scratchin'.The DM950 is a compact, rugged mixer packed with essential
features. Includes a replaceable crossfader, 2-band EQ per channel, durable
steel construction, a comfortable sloped front panel, 2 phono- and 2
line-level RCA inputs, and a 1/4 mic input. The TT1625 is a direct-drive
turntable featuring 10% pitch adjustment, 33 and 45rpm speeds, an aluminum
platter, S-shaped tone arm, and dual start/stop controls.The HF125
headphones feature flexible, 7-position, independently adjustable padded ear
cups; large 40mm mylar speaker drivers; 6' tangle-resistant cord; and padded
headband.

and a pair of slipmats, a pair of HF125 headphones, and all connecting
cables. Plug in and get scratchin&#39;.The DM950 is a compact, rugged mixer
packed with essential features. Includes a replaceable crossfader,

independently adjustable padded ear cups; large 40mm mylar speaker

> Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 15:34:59 -0700
> From: bird415@gmail.com
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Saturday! [KONTROL] vs. Surefire w/ Germany's ama=
zing D.DIGGLER!
>
> So, let me tell you a quick little story.
>
> Back around 2001, I was chatting with a bona fide music freak online
> and asking him what were some of his favorite sets ever. He hooked me
> up with this 4 hour set by a German guy named, amusingly enough, Dirk
> Diggler . It started off with some of the deepest, most sparse dub
> techno imaginable, then gradually gained steam, expertly covering
> every style and tempo of minimal/techno until the last couple hours
> were just straight up slamming dancefloor killers. In the years since
> then, I'd have to say this set has become like an old friend to me,
> and the DJ responsible for it has become one of my all-time favorites,
> sparking an ongoing interest in the minimal techno genre which
> eventually led to the founding of the [KONTROL] parties.
>
> After religiously following (and loving) his sets and productions in
> the 6 years since then, this year at the Detroit Electronic Music
> Festival I finally got to see him play in person, where he dropped an
> amazing 2 hour live/dj set on the main stage. If you talk to any
> techno fan that was there, you'll find a bunch of people ready to
> assert that his set was one of the highlights of the entire festival,
> hands down. And this year's fest had some sizzling sets indeed, by the
> likes of Richie Hawtin, Luciano, Marco Carola, Steve Bug, Jeff Mills,
> and many more. This guy is good. Really good.
>
> So, when [KONTROL] was approached by SUREFIRE (SF's illest dubstep
> crew) about wanting to collaborate on a show at the beautiful new
> Temple nightclub, we thought about who we'd really like to hear on
> that ridiculous thumping sound system, and the choice was clear...
> Diggler! We shot his agent an email, crunched the numbers, and
> decided to make it happen! Hot on the release of his brand new studio
> album EM.Pulse, he's flying over all the way from Frankfurt just for
> this one gig, and we're certain it's going to be one not soon
> forgotten!
>
> And for you dubstep fans out there, Surefire is bringing out no less
> than 3 huge headliners representing some of the hottest names in the
> genre. Even if you're unfamiliar with this rapidly growing style of
> music, there's no better place to indulge your curiosity than at this
> show. We have a strong feeling there are going to be plenty of
> dubstep fans leaving with a new appreciation for minimal, and likewise
> techno heads feelin' the dubstep vibe!
>
> We hope you can join us for this fantastic night of music for the
> mind, body, and spirit. We promise you won't be disappointed.
>
>
> -----> Greg and the [KONTROL] crew
>
> _______________________________________________________
>
>
> Saturday, October 13, 2007
>
> [KONTROL] vs. SUREFIRE
>
> TECHNO vs. DUBSTEP
>
>
>
> featuring in the TECHNO main room:
>
> <<< D.DIGGLER>>>
> live/dj set | *exclusive US appearance*
> (Resopal Schallware, Force Tracks, Cocoon, Raum...musik | Frankfurt)
>
> Craig Kuna (ESDJCO, Concept SF)
> Nikola Baytala (S.W.A.T., Robsoul, Tweekin')
> Alland Byallo (Liebe*Detail, Nightlight)
> Sammy D (Classic, Utensil)
>
>
>
> and in the DUBSTEP catacombs:
>
> BENGA (Tempa, Fwd, Planet Mu | London)
> HATCHA (Tempa, Fwd, KissFM, Planet Mu | London)
> Martyn (Tempa, Offshore, Soul-R | Netherlands)
> DJ Collage (Masse-One, Jam Jam | Seattle)
>
> Selector Dub-U (Surefire, Narco.Hz, SubFM)
> DJ G (Narco.Hz)
> Emcee Child (Narco.Hz, Grime City)
>
>
>
> Check out the flyer here:
> http://www.kontrolsf.com/diggler/DigglerH.jpg

> 21+ / 10pm-4am / $15

2007_90min.mp3
>
>
>
> From this week's SF Bay Guardian:
>
> Give props to these two DJ-promotion groups, which have teamed up to
> organize a unique event: a face-off between dubstep and techno DJs. In
> a sense, this could be like one of those family reunions at which
> estranged half brothers first meet. Dubstep would be the loud
> youngster, a hip descendant of dub, garage, and drum 'n' bass (it's
> complicated). Techno would be the elder and moodier teenager, the one
> who's been around the block but doesn't flaunt it. With German techno
> talent D.Diggler and Brit dubstep mixers Benga and Hatcha, there'll be
> small moments of transitional awkwardness overshadowed by an impulse
> to enjoy the camaraderie and dance to deep beats.
> --Kevin Lee
>

> > Date: Thu, 11 Oct 2007 15:34:59 -0700
> > From: bird415@gmail.com
> > To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Saturday! [KONTROL] vs. Surefire w/ Germany's a=
mazing D.DIGGLER!
> >
> > So, let me tell you a quick little story.
> >
> > Back around 2001, I was chatting with a bona fide music freak online
> > and asking him what were some of his favorite sets ever. He hooked me
> > up with this 4 hour set by a German guy named, amusingly enough, Dirk
> > Diggler . It started off with some of the deepest, most sparse dub
> > techno imaginable, then gradually gained steam, expertly covering
> > every style and tempo of minimal/techno until the last couple hours
> > were just straight up slamming dancefloor killers. In the years since
> > then, I'd have to say this set has become like an old friend to me,
> > and the DJ responsible for it has become one of my all-time favorites,
> > sparking an ongoing interest in the minimal techno genre which
> > eventually led to the founding of the [KONTROL] parties.
> >
> > After religiously following (and loving) his sets and productions in
> > the 6 years since then, this year at the Detroit Electronic Music
> > Festival I finally got to see him play in person, where he dropped an
> > amazing 2 hour live/dj set on the main stage. If you talk to any
> > techno fan that was there, you'll find a bunch of people ready to
> > assert that his set was one of the highlights of the entire festival,
> > hands down. And this year's fest had some sizzling sets indeed, by the
> > likes of Richie Hawtin, Luciano, Marco Carola, Steve Bug, Jeff Mills,
> > and many more. This guy is good. Really good.
> >
> > So, when [KONTROL] was approached by SUREFIRE (SF's illest dubstep
> > crew) about wanting to collaborate on a show at the beautiful new
> > Temple nightclub, we thought about who we'd really like to hear on
> > that ridiculous thumping sound system, and the choice was clear...
> > Diggler! We shot his agent an email, crunched the numbers, and
> > decided to make it happen! Hot on the release of his brand new studio
> > album EM.Pulse, he's flying over all the way from Frankfurt just for
> > this one gig, and we're certain it's going to be one not soon
> > forgotten!
> >
> > And for you dubstep fans out there, Surefire is bringing out no less
> > than 3 huge headliners representing some of the hottest names in the
> > genre. Even if you're unfamiliar with this rapidly growing style of
> > music, there's no better place to indulge your curiosity than at this
> > show. We have a strong feeling there are going to be plenty of
> > dubstep fans leaving with a new appreciation for minimal, and likewise
> > techno heads feelin' the dubstep vibe!
> >
> > We hope you can join us for this fantastic night of music for the
> > mind, body, and spirit. We promise you won't be disappointed.
> >
> >
> > -----> Greg and the [KONTROL] crew
> >
> > _______________________________________________________
> >
> >
> > Saturday, October 13, 2007
> >
> > [KONTROL] vs. SUREFIRE
> >
> > TECHNO vs. DUBSTEP
> >
> >
> >
> > featuring in the TECHNO main room:
> >
> > <<< D.DIGGLER>>>
> > live/dj set | *exclusive US appearance*
> > (Resopal Schallware, Force Tracks, Cocoon, Raum...musik | Frankfurt)
> >
> > Craig Kuna (ESDJCO, Concept SF)
> > Nikola Baytala (S.W.A.T., Robsoul, Tweekin')
> > Alland Byallo (Liebe*Detail, Nightlight)
> > Sammy D (Classic, Utensil)
> >
> >
> >
> > and in the DUBSTEP catacombs:
> >
> > BENGA (Tempa, Fwd, Planet Mu | London)
> > HATCHA (Tempa, Fwd, KissFM, Planet Mu | London)
> > Martyn (Tempa, Offshore, Soul-R | Netherlands)
> > DJ Collage (Masse-One, Jam Jam | Seattle)
> >
> > Selector Dub-U (Surefire, Narco.Hz, SubFM)
> > DJ G (Narco.Hz)
> > Emcee Child (Narco.Hz, Grime City)
> >
> >
> >
> > Check out the flyer here:
> > http://www.kontrolsf.com/diggler/DigglerH.jpg
> >
> > ________________________________________________________
> >
> > Temple Nightclub
> > 540 Howard Street, SF
> > 21+ / 10pm-4am / $15
> > ________________________________________________________
> >
> >
> > LINKS:
> >
> > D.Diggler on MySpace: (with music, free sets to download, charts, etc.!=
)
> > http://www.myspace.com/ddigglermusic
> >
> > D.Diggler's website: (full bio, music previews, charts, and more)
> > http://www.digglermusic.com/
> >
> > D.Diggler's discography:
> > http://www.discogs.com/artist/D.Diggler
> >
> > D.Diggler 2007 promo mix:
> > http://www.allandbyallo.com/temple/D.Diggler_Promo_for_Sonne_Mond_Stern=
e_2007_90min.mp3
> >
> >
> >
> > From this week's SF Bay Guardian:
> >
> > Give props to these two DJ-promotion groups, which have teamed up to
> > organize a unique event: a face-off between dubstep and techno DJs. In
> > a sense, this could be like one of those family reunions at which
> > estranged half brothers first meet. Dubstep would be the loud
> > youngster, a hip descendant of dub, garage, and drum 'n' bass (it's
> > complicated). Techno would be the elder and moodier teenager, the one
> > who's been around the block but doesn't flaunt it. With German techno
> > talent D.Diggler and Brit dubstep mixers Benga and Hatcha, there'll be
> > small moments of transitional awkwardness overshadowed by an impulse
> > to enjoy the camaraderie and dance to deep beats.
> > --Kevin Lee

yo, just got final word.   and the news is good. :)

Dirk Diggler is doing a combo LIVE/DJ set and will be rocking it for THREE
HOURS from 1-4am.

so even if you've got plans eariler, come by after and you'll still catch a
couple hours of this guy when the place is really rockin'.  you seriously
won't regret it.  my friend Monica (Mkat), who's on this list, is one of th=
e
most discerning techno enthusiasts (read: snobs) ;) i know, and she said
Diggler's set was the best she saw at this year's DEMF.  and that's saying
something.


hope to see some SFRavers out sat!

------>GB

Friday, October 19th 10:00pm



Sunset Promotions & Mighty Breaks present Ninja Tune superstar

DJ Vadim

featuring MC's
Abstract Rude & Yarah Bravo

along with local heroes
Zeph & Azeem
DJ Ren (trueskool.org)
Mancub (Space Cowboys)
Murphstar (SEISMIC)
Motion Potion
Uplift
& the Lower Haters

DJ Vadim is a walking proof of the international reach of hip hop. Born in =
the Soviet Union, he immigrated to England as a teenager and in almost no t=
ime had set up a studio and released an EP. Soon signed to the groundbreaki=
ng and forward-thinking English label Ninja Tune, Vadim would spend the 90'=
s releasing a string of singles, compilations and albums that used abstract=
 breaks and trip hop to explore the themes of the country of his birth. His=
 2007 release "Soundcatcher" is almost a decade in the making, with every k=
ick, snare and clap tuned and arranged with the care of a master painter. T=
here are few producers anywhere who have been able to harness such sweet, s=
avory and always tasty sounds into their compositions. That Vadim manages t=
o make such rich music danceable, humorous and often downright funky, is a =
further testament to his genius. Appearing with two acclaimed MC's his perf=
ormance at Mighty will be a party for the dancers and an exposition for the=
 listeners.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] fact or fiction?

------=_Part_25561_2055942.1192223666552
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

It's really easy to bitch about how bad cops are at doing their job, but I
don't see those of you bitching about that lining up for police academy. I
suggest you spend some time reading police blogs and give some consideration
to what exactly goes into even becoming a cop and what kind of (absolutely
excessive) bullshit they have to deal with on a day to day basis.

If every time I arrested someone for a violent crime I had to spend the next
5-6 hours filling out meaningless, repetitive paperwork only to see them
back out on the streets in a month or two, well, yeah, I just might be kind
of pissed off most of the time.

People love to bitch about cops without realizing that they're just trying
to do their job, and they aren't the ones that make the rules. There are bad
cops out there, but I submit to you that those bad cops are the exception
rather than the rule. The real problem is the bureaucracy that makes it
almost impossible for them to do their job.

That and the Federal Reserve.

On 10/12/07, Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net> wrote:
>
>
>
> I didn't actually say anything about them being nice.  They're human,
> that's
> all.  Sure, I've been tailed for driving while asian, mostly out in walnut
> creek, or down the peninsula.  SF and Oakland cops have better things to
> do,
> if given some basic politeness, they're smart enough to realize you're
> smart
> enough to keep a handle on things.  Heck, just today one (who actually was
> nice about it) let me off for not realizing I'd parked in a towaway zone.
> That's a major revenue source for them and one they're encouraged to
> enforce
> so he certainly didn't have to.  He had me and the towtruck was coming
> down
> the street, but getting my cooperative ass out of there instead of backing
> up traffic during rush hour was something he was willing to live with.
>
> Even people who aren't particularly nice respond better to people who are.
> If you treat them like the assholes some are, even nice people learn to be
> assholes.  It's all basic game theory, really.
>
>

> > > to

> > > survive the day without getting shot in the back.  This is not good
> for a
> > > positive outlook on life.  A little empathy does go a long way.

> > > assistance?"  It's as much a negotiation tactic as anything else.  If
> you
> > > want to clam up and just call your attorney, go for it.  If not, be
> smart,
> > > think about what leverage you do or don't have, and what he has.
> > >
> > > If he asks "is this your rave?"  you can reply "These are my friends,
> > > we're
> > > just here to relax and have a nice time."  Heck, you can even
> nod.  Just
> > > don't
> > > admit to things on his terms.  Redefine in happy, helpful terms.  In
> > > short,
> > > suck up without confessing anything.
> > >
> > > If he comments that it's a lot of friends/people, it's easy enough to
> say
> > > "well, my friends told their friends, and they all know I have an open
> > > door
> > > policy for my friends."  Do NOT mention things getting out of hand.
> > >
> > > if he says to turn it down, you can say "Sure, I'll go talk to the DJ
> > > after
> > > you and I are done talking."
> > >
> > > None of which admits to anything, yet all of it keeps you human in his
> > > eyes and brings you partway towards him, making him much more likely
> to
> > > want to help you.
> > >
> > > Attitude IS everything, since yes, he can fuck with you just to make
> an
> > > example of you if he chooses to.  As long as you don't actually admit
> to
> > > any wrondoing, you haven't lost anything for trying, and you might
> > > actually
> > > get to keep the party going, instead of just "winning" the avoidance
> of
> > > jail time.
> > >
> > > And if you've got an attorney, keep the number on speed dial

At 02:14 PM 10/12/2007, you wrote:
>It's really easy to bitch about how bad cops are at doing their job, but I
>don't see those of you bitching about that lining up for police academy. I
>suggest you spend some time reading police blogs and give some consideration

>excessive) bullshit they have to deal with on a day to day basis.
>
>If every time I arrested someone for a violent crime I had to spend the next
>5-6 hours filling out meaningless, repetitive paperwork only to see them
>back out on the streets in a month or two, well, yeah, I just might be kind
>of pissed off most of the time.
>

>to do their job, and they aren't the ones that make the rules. There are bad
>cops out there, but I submit to you that those bad cops are the exception
>rather than the rule. The real problem is the bureaucracy that makes it
>almost impossible for them to do their job.
>

phone, making it go off every 47 seconds, makes instant access to email
quite useless.

Mime-Version: 1.0

X-Virus-Scanned: ClamAV version 0.91.2, clamav-milter version 0.91.2 on paz.well.com
X-Virus-Status: Clean
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Halloweenie


San Francisco may well be on the verge of a nightmare -
I don't wish it on the city - I just think the writing's on the wall.

Most of you know that I was (unlike many of you) -
a huge supporter of Gavin Newsom when he ran for mayor.
For the most part, many citizens agree that he has done
a decent job as mayor - as evidenced by that fact that he has
NO REAL opposition in his run for reelection.
I believe this 'fact' has left him complacent and seemingly
WAY OUT OF TOUCH with "REALITY" and that a major
disaster for San Francisco is only 16 Days Away !!

I truly believe that the following are verifiable "facts":

1)  Halloween, as a MAJOR holiday has continued to evolve
into a bigger and bigger occasion each year - this holiday shows
no sign of diminishing in public popularity.

2)  In many urban areas - especially San Francisco -
Halloween is NOT "just" a kid's holiday - it, in fact, is just
as important a holiday for 100s of thousands of adults.

3)  Like Christmas, New Year's Eve and the Fourth of July -
Halloween is one of those holidays that MUST be observed
on the proper date - just like there are lots of "Christmas"
parties in December - there is no deflecting people's attention
from the main event.  There may be lots of "Halloween"
parties on the weekend before the true date, and that may
be enough for a lot of people - but for MANY people -
Halloween is October 31st - period !

4)  People like "tradition".  For years, the tradition in San Francisco
was to celebrate Halloween along Polk Street - back when Polk Street
was the center of gay life in San Francisco - but for AT LEAST
the last 20 YEARS - the tradition has been to celebrate Halloween
in the Castro - where, as most residents and visitors alike know -
it can be Halloween 365 days a year.  Further complicating the problem -
no other city or area in the entire Bay Area is known for
Halloween night gatherings.

5)  In years, where Halloween falls on a weekend, large public
parties have drawn some of the crowd away from the Castro -
however, with Halloween occurring on a WEDNESDAY this year -
and with an absence of ANY large public parties ANYWHERE
in San Francisco - where exactly are people supposed to go ?
There is NOWHERE else - in the entire Bay Area - you can't
wish this away any more than you can bouga-bouga it away.

6)  Just because Mayor Newsom, his advisors, some (rightfully)
nervous public officials and the police decide to "cancel" Halloween
in the Castro - and OFFER NO ALTERNATIVE - does not mean
that people will stay home or out of San Francisco.

7)  Removing porta potties from the Castro for the evening will not
ensure that people are not FORCED to go to the bathroom in
Castro residents' yards, driveways, and front doors.

8)  Refusing to close the streets does not mean that the streets
will not HAVE to be closed - the city grudgingly admits this, thinking
that maybe a block or two of the Castro itself may have to be shut down.
Closing the MUNI station in the Castro will only contribute to MORE
traffic congestion in the city.

9)  Refusing to properly erect barricades and install metal detectors
at security check points will not reduce the presence of potentially dangers
costumes and accoutrements in the Castro - it will, in fact, INCREASE
the likelihood that someone will get hurt - this is entirely preventable -
and should someone get hurt - I think that a good lawyer will be able
to prove that the city was negligent in not preventing or minimizing
the possibility of serious injury (or worse).

10)  The City of San Francisco is planning to spend money on
an ad campaign telling people to "STAY AWAY" - and they are also
planning to spend money on 600 police officers with a zero tolerance
attitude towards those "under the influence".  Not smart.

11)  The FACT of the matter is that the police and public officials
ARE NEVER in charge of large public gatherings - it is STUPID
of them to think that they are - especially in San Francisco.
There are, in fact, hundreds of thousands of people in San Francisco
who are, in fact, VERY cool - even when "under the influence".
These random, unknown, unofficial people are the ones who CAN
and DO control the crowds at all large public gatherings in San Francisco.

Need an example ? - 2 or 3 Drag Queens (Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence)
can control hundreds if not thousands of people - BETTER - than
100 fully loaded policemen.

12)  OK - Nine people were shot in the Castro last year - not within
the official boundaries of the party, but nearby.  Does ANYONE
in their right mind, think that banning Halloween in the Castro is going
to keep "that element" away ?  No it is not.

Does ANYONE think that by banning sound systems and any kind
of diversion or entertainment that the Castro will be "safer" ?
No it will not.

Does ANYONE think that a largely increased police presence - that
is, in fact, LOOKING FOR TROUBLE (zero tolerance) - will make
the Castro safer for its residents and businesses ?  In fact, the absence
of diversions, the crowds and the police presence add up to a powder keg
of potential trouble.

As I see it the purpose of public officials and the police is to create
an environment where businesses can FLOURISH and citizens
can gather, safely. (asking Castro
businesses, especially bars, to close down on one of their potentially
most lucrative evenings of the year is, in a word - STUPID.
Making the people coming to the Castro the enemy is - STUPID.

The truth in the old saying - when life gives you lemons, make lemonade -
couldn't be more applicable here.  Many of us PERSONALLY know
people who could turn this whole thing around - even at this late hour.

The CITY OF SAN FRANCISCO SHOULD

1)   Get at least 8 to 10 Sound Systems into the Castro for the evening.

2)   Have a publicly sanctioned 'kid event' (organized by Cliff's)
       happening at 5 in the afternoon.

3)   Get a couple of hundred (at least) porta potties on the scene.

4)  Effectively "seal off" Castro by 6 in the afternoon - require EVERYONE
entering the area to pass through metal detectors - have your police presence
at the barricades on standby - ready to assist - not ready to confront.

5)  Get some pieces of 'oh,wow' Burning Man art on display for the evening.
Get a couple of major burn platforms in place - people love bonfires.

6)  Ask for help - from Anon Salon, from  SFRaves, from The Sisters, from
Tranny Shack, from Burners,  from Hippies, from Freaks - there are hundreds
of organized and disorganized social and arts groups that could at the drop
of a hat SHOW UP IN FORCE - all amazingly well costumed looking to dance,
to look and be looked at - NONE OF THEM LOOKING FOR TROUBLE.

All of this (and more) could be accomplished in 15 Days - and the resultant
good vibes could save the city a lot of hassles that seem inevitable if the
current "denial and confrontation" attitude coming from city hall continues.

Gavin, get a clue - if the current drift on Halloween in the Castro 
continues -
you WILL be held directly accountable - by the electorate !!


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Halloweenie

A densely populated residential neighborhood with a reputation that
pushes the buttons of a large chunk of American society is probably
the worst place to have an drunken, rowdy, public, jam packed event.

I'm not sure why anybody would advocate for maintaining this event in
the Castro and not moving it to SOMA or around City Hall, or even
South Beach, where the other fests take place. If it's so strongly
linked to the Castro culture, have a low-key parade instead that lasts
an hour or so and move the parties indoors.

Seriously...it's dark, alcohol-fueled, and the majority of the
participants are unidentifyable due to costuming and it's so densely
packed that anything can happen.

I went only once when I first moved here and was so bruised up from
all the drunken yahoos that I've vowed never to go back. I also had my
new car keyed but some drunken asshole.

> 7)  Removing porta potties from the Castro for the evening will not
> ensure that people are not FORCED to go to the bathroom in
> Castro residents' yards, driveways, and front doors.

That right there is the very reason anybody living in the Castro would
probably argue for banning the event outright. If I owned property in
the Castro, I'd set up a neighborhood watch to make sure nobody in a
costume entered my street on that particular night.

The only thing "forcing" public balast making, vandalism or any of the
other behavior that typically happens around this event is disrespect
for oneself and another's property, and the level of tolerance the
neighborhood has shown in the past.

-SK

On 10/15/07, Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote:
>
> San Francisco may well be on the verge of a nightmare -
> I don't wish it on the city - I just think the writing's on the wall.
>
> Most of you know that I was (unlike many of you) -
> a huge supporter of Gavin Newsom when he ran for mayor.
> For the most part, many citizens agree that he has done
> a decent job as mayor - as evidenced by that fact that he has
> NO REAL opposition in his run for reelection.
> I believe this 'fact' has left him complacent and seemingly
> WAY OUT OF TOUCH with "REALITY" and that a major
> disaster for San Francisco is only 16 Days Away !!
>
> I truly believe that the following are verifiable "facts":
>
> 1)  Halloween, as a MAJOR holiday has continued to evolve
> into a bigger and bigger occasion each year - this holiday shows
> no sign of diminishing in public popularity.
>
> 2)  In many urban areas - especially San Francisco -
> Halloween is NOT "just" a kid's holiday - it, in fact, is just
> as important a holiday for 100s of thousands of adults.
>
> 3)  Like Christmas, New Year's Eve and the Fourth of July -
> Halloween is one of those holidays that MUST be observed
> on the proper date - just like there are lots of "Christmas"
> parties in December - there is no deflecting people's attention
> from the main event.  There may be lots of "Halloween"
> parties on the weekend before the true date, and that may
> be enough for a lot of people - but for MANY people -
> Halloween is October 31st - period !
>
> 4)  People like "tradition".  For years, the tradition in San Francisco
> was to celebrate Halloween along Polk Street - back when Polk Street
> was the center of gay life in San Francisco - but for AT LEAST
> the last 20 YEARS - the tradition has been to celebrate Halloween
> in the Castro - where, as most residents and visitors alike know -
> it can be Halloween 365 days a year.  Further complicating the problem -
> no other city or area in the entire Bay Area is known for
> Halloween night gatherings.
>
> 5)  In years, where Halloween falls on a weekend, large public
> parties have drawn some of the crowd away from the Castro -
> however, with Halloween occurring on a WEDNESDAY this year -
> and with an absence of ANY large public parties ANYWHERE
> in San Francisco - where exactly are people supposed to go ?
> There is NOWHERE else - in the entire Bay Area - you can't
> wish this away any more than you can bouga-bouga it away.
>
> 6)  Just because Mayor Newsom, his advisors, some (rightfully)
> nervous public officials and the police decide to "cancel" Halloween
> in the Castro - and OFFER NO ALTERNATIVE - does not mean
> that people will stay home or out of San Francisco.
>
> 7)  Removing porta potties from the Castro for the evening will not
> ensure that people are not FORCED to go to the bathroom in
> Castro residents' yards, driveways, and front doors.
>
> 8)  Refusing to close the streets does not mean that the streets
> will not HAVE to be closed - the city grudgingly admits this, thinking
> that maybe a block or two of the Castro itself may have to be shut down.
> Closing the MUNI station in the Castro will only contribute to MORE
> traffic congestion in the city.
>
> 9)  Refusing to properly erect barricades and install metal detectors
> at security check points will not reduce the presence of potentially dangers
> costumes and accoutrements in the Castro - it will, in fact, INCREASE
> the likelihood that someone will get hurt - this is entirely preventable -
> and should someone get hurt - I think that a good lawyer will be able
> to prove that the city was negligent in not preventing or minimizing
> the possibility of serious injury (or worse).
>
> 10)  The City of San Francisco is planning to spend money on
> an ad campaign telling people to "STAY AWAY" - and they are also
> planning to spend money on 600 police officers with a zero tolerance
> attitude towards those "under the influence".  Not smart.
>
> 11)  The FACT of the matter is that the police and public officials
> ARE NEVER in charge of large public gatherings - it is STUPID
> of them to think that they are - especially in San Francisco.
> There are, in fact, hundreds of thousands of people in San Francisco
> who are, in fact, VERY cool - even when "under the influence".
> These random, unknown, unofficial people are the ones who CAN
> and DO control the crowds at all large public gatherings in San Francisco.
>
> Need an example ? - 2 or 3 Drag Queens (Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence)
> can control hundreds if not thousands of people - BETTER - than
> 100 fully loaded policemen.
>
> 12)  OK - Nine people were shot in the Castro last year - not within
> the official boundaries of the party, but nearby.  Does ANYONE
> in their right mind, think that banning Halloween in the Castro is going
> to keep "that element" away ?  No it is not.
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DIRTY w/ Lawgiverz, FCB - October 20th @ DNA Lounge

DIRTY
October 20th, 2007
DNA Lounge - 375 11th St.
$10 presales - Here!!
$10 b4 11pm / $15 after
10pm - 4am
21+

It's been a few months since Evil Breaks has done a bigger party, and
we figured we'd come back with something HUGE!!! We can't wait to see
what these guys sound like on DNA's amazing sound system, and along
with the amazing local support, Visuals by Viberation, and a special
surprise guest upstairs, I really don't think you're going to want to
miss this.


E.B.'s Dirty little room w/visuals by Viberation:


Lawgiverz (Trigger/Botchit) - UK

Lawgiverz, a.k.a. R-Kidz and Noize, have been dropping audio bombs for
the last five years on Botchit & Scarper, Trigger Recordings and more.
Lawgiverz have produced, programmed and remixed with a bizarre
selection of artists such as Jeff Beck, Dave Stewart and The Human
League. They would like you to know that none of this really matters.
Just that if you find yourself in front of the Trigger sound system or
at DNA during their laptop and turntable set, prepare to be destroyed
with a helping of alien love in the Electrobreaks style.



Fine Cut Bodies (Chi Recordings/Record Records) - Budapest

Even though the name Fine Cut Bodies implies more than one person,
behind the FCB letters is only one man, Kevin aka Attila Fodor. His
musical tastes are extremely broad which is reflected in the musical
preferences of *Chi Recordings*, the label he co-founded in 2000. One
of the most important taste-maker DJs in Hungary, he has been one of
the key DJs/promoters that built up the huge breaks scene in Hungary
and he is now starting to build up the world class underground minimal
and tech-house scene in Budapest.

As a DJ, Kevin's taste is determined more by his musical attitude than
by any specific genre: he looks for music that's experimental but not
selfish, interesting but not unlistenable. As a producer, he has
released tracks in many genres and is always looking for new sonic
adventures. Kevin's tracks have been licensed for numerous
compilations and he has collaborated with and remixed for some of the
hottest names in electronic music.

Aaron Jae (E.B./XM Radio/Space Cowboys)
Bam (Evil Breaks/ABN)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)
Raydeus (Pronoia)



Beat Church hosting the upstairs room:

Lawgiverz (A 2nd Mid-tempo set)

Kitty-D (The Glitch Mob/Beat Church)
Hookerz & Blow (Mozaic vs EPROM)
Benchun(False Profit)

--

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Halloweenie

Why don't the organizers get together and propose an alternative
rather than waiting for a bureacracy to do it for them? The City
shouldn't be expected to come up with innovative solutions. That's the
job of the citizens.

-SK

On 10/15/07, Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote:
>
> I actually agree with you - the city's true failure in all this
> is its failure to provide an alternative
>
> At 11:54 AM 10/15/2007, you wrote:
> >A densely populated residential neighborhood with a reputation that
> >pushes the buttons of a large chunk of American society is probably
> >the worst place to have an drunken, rowdy, public, jam packed event.
> >
> >I'm not sure why anybody would advocate for maintaining this event in
> >the Castro and not moving it to SOMA or around City Hall, or even
> >South Beach, where the other fests take place. If it's so strongly
> >linked to the Castro culture, have a low-key parade instead that lasts
> >an hour or so and move the parties indoors.
> >
> >Seriously...it's dark, alcohol-fueled, and the majority of the
> >participants are unidentifyable due to costuming and it's so densely
> >packed that anything can happen.
> >
> >I went only once when I first moved here and was so bruised up from
> >all the drunken yahoos that I've vowed never to go back. I also had my
> >new car keyed but some drunken asshole.
> >
> > > 7)  Removing porta potties from the Castro for the evening will not
> > > ensure that people are not FORCED to go to the bathroom in
> > > Castro residents' yards, driveways, and front doors.
> >
> >That right there is the very reason anybody living in the Castro would
> >probably argue for banning the event outright. If I owned property in
> >the Castro, I'd set up a neighborhood watch to make sure nobody in a
> >costume entered my street on that particular night.
> >
> >The only thing "forcing" public balast making, vandalism or any of the
> >other behavior that typically happens around this event is disrespect
> >for oneself and another's property, and the level of tolerance the
> >neighborhood has shown in the past.
> >
> >-SK
> >
> >On 10/15/07, Jim Cyr <surfpunk@well.com> wrote:
> > >
> > > San Francisco may well be on the verge of a nightmare -
> > > I don't wish it on the city - I just think the writing's on the wall.
> > >
> > > Most of you know that I was (unlike many of you) -
> > > a huge supporter of Gavin Newsom when he ran for mayor.
> > > For the most part, many citizens agree that he has done
> > > a decent job as mayor - as evidenced by that fact that he has
> > > NO REAL opposition in his run for reelection.
> > > I believe this 'fact' has left him complacent and seemingly
> > > WAY OUT OF TOUCH with "REALITY" and that a major
> > > disaster for San Francisco is only 16 Days Away !!
> > >
> > > I truly believe that the following are verifiable "facts":
> > >
> > > 1)  Halloween, as a MAJOR holiday has continued to evolve
> > > into a bigger and bigger occasion each year - this holiday shows
> > > no sign of diminishing in public popularity.
> > >
> > > 2)  In many urban areas - especially San Francisco -
> > > Halloween is NOT "just" a kid's holiday - it, in fact, is just
> > > as important a holiday for 100s of thousands of adults.
> > >
> > > 3)  Like Christmas, New Year's Eve and the Fourth of July -
> > > Halloween is one of those holidays that MUST be observed
> > > on the proper date - just like there are lots of "Christmas"
> > > parties in December - there is no deflecting people's attention
> > > from the main event.  There may be lots of "Halloween"
> > > parties on the weekend before the true date, and that may
> > > be enough for a lot of people - but for MANY people -
> > > Halloween is October 31st - period !
> > >
> > > 4)  People like "tradition".  For years, the tradition in San Francisco
> > > was to celebrate Halloween along Polk Street - back when Polk Street
> > > was the center of gay life in San Francisco - but for AT LEAST
> > > the last 20 YEARS - the tradition has been to celebrate Halloween
> > > in the Castro - where, as most residents and visitors alike know -
> > > it can be Halloween 365 days a year.  Further complicating the problem -
> > > no other city or area in the entire Bay Area is known for
> > > Halloween night gatherings.
> > >
> > > 5)  In years, where Halloween falls on a weekend, large public
> > > parties have drawn some of the crowd away from the Castro -
> > > however, with Halloween occurring on a WEDNESDAY this year -
> > > and with an absence of ANY large public parties ANYWHERE
> > > in San Francisco - where exactly are people supposed to go ?
> > > There is NOWHERE else - in the entire Bay Area - you can't
> > > wish this away any more than you can bouga-bouga it away.
> > >
> > > 6)  Just because Mayor Newsom, his advisors, some (rightfully)
> > > nervous public officials and the police decide to "cancel" Halloween
> > > in the Castro - and OFFER NO ALTERNATIVE - does not mean
> > > that people will stay home or out of San Francisco.
> > >
> > > 7)  Removing porta potties from the Castro for the evening will not
> > > ensure that people are not FORCED to go to the bathroom in
> > > Castro residents' yards, driveways, and front doors.
> > >
> > > 8)  Refusing to close the streets does not mean that the streets
> > > will not HAVE to be closed - the city grudgingly admits this, thinking
> > > that maybe a block or two of the Castro itself may have to be shut down.
> > > Closing the MUNI station in the Castro will only contribute to MORE
> > > traffic congestion in the city.
> > >
> > > 9)  Refusing to properly erect barricades and install metal detectors
> > > at security check points will not reduce the presence of
> > potentially dangers
> > > costumes and accoutrements in the Castro - it will, in fact, INCREASE
> > > the likelihood that someone will get hurt - this is entirely preventable -
> > > and should someone get hurt - I think that a good lawyer will be able
> > > to prove that the city was negligent in not preventing or minimizing
> > > the possibility of serious injury (or worse).
> > >
> > > 10)  The City of San Francisco is planning to spend money on
> > > an ad campaign telling people to "STAY AWAY" - and they are also
> > > planning to spend money on 600 police officers with a zero tolerance
> > > attitude towards those "under the influence".  Not smart.
> > >
> > > 11)  The FACT of the matter is that the police and public officials
> > > ARE NEVER in charge of large public gatherings - it is STUPID
> > > of them to think that they are - especially in San Francisco.
> > > There are, in fact, hundreds of thousands of people in San Francisco
> > > who are, in fact, VERY cool - even when "under the influence".
> > > These random, unknown, unofficial people are the ones who CAN
> > > and DO control the crowds at all large public gatherings in San Francisco.
> > >
> > > Need an example ? - 2 or 3 Drag Queens (Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence)
> > > can control hundreds if not thousands of people - BETTER - than
> > > 100 fully loaded policemen.
> > >
> > > 12)  OK - Nine people were shot in the Castro last year - not within
> > > the official boundaries of the party, but nearby.  Does ANYONE
> > > in their right mind, think that banning Halloween in the Castro is going
> > > to keep "that element" away ?  No it is not.
> > >
> > > Does ANYONE think that by banning sound systems and any kind
> > > of diversion or entertainment that the Castro will be "safer" ?
> > > No it will not.
> > >
> > > Does ANYONE think that a largely increased police presence - that
> > > is, in fact, LOOKING FOR TROUBLE (zero tolerance) - will make
> > > the Castro safer for its residents and businesses ?  In fact, the absence
> > > of diversions, the crowds and the police presence add up to a powder keg
> > > of potential trouble.
> > >
> > > As I see it the purpose of public officials and the police is to create
> > > an environment where businesses can FLOURISH and citizens
> > > can gather, safely. (asking Castro
> > > businesses, especially bars, to close down on one of their potentially
> > > most lucrative evenings of the year is, in a word - STUPID.
> > > Making the people coming to the Castro the enemy is - STUPID.
> > >
> > > The truth in the old saying - when life gives you lemons, make lemonade -
> > > couldn't be more applicable here.  Many of us PERSONALLY know
> > > people who could turn this whole thing around - even at this late hour.
> > >
> > > The CITY OF SAN FRANCISCO SHOULD
> > >
> > > 1)   Get at least 8 to 10 Sound Systems into the Castro for the evening.
> > >
> > > 2)   Have a publicly sanctioned 'kid event' (organized by Cliff's)
> > >       happening at 5 in the afternoon.
> > >
> > > 3)   Get a couple of hundred (at least) porta potties on the scene.
> > >
> > > 4)  Effectively "seal off" Castro by 6 in the afternoon - require EVERYONE
> > > entering the area to pass through metal detectors - have your
> > police presence
> > > at the barricades on standby - ready to assist - not ready to confront.
> > >
> > > 5)  Get some pieces of 'oh,wow' Burning Man art on display for the evening.
> > > Get a couple of major burn platforms in place - people love bonfires.
> > >
> > > 6)  Ask for help - from Anon Salon, from  SFRaves, from The Sisters, from
> > > Tranny Shack, from Burners,  from Hippies, from Freaks - there are hundreds
> > > of organized and disorganized social and arts groups that could at the drop
> > > of a hat SHOW UP IN FORCE - all amazingly well costumed looking to dance,
> > > to look and be looked at - NONE OF THEM LOOKING FOR TROUBLE.
> > >
> > > All of this (and more) could be accomplished in 15 Days - and the resultant
> > > good vibes could save the city a lot of hassles that seem inevitable if the
> > > current "denial and confrontation" attitude coming from city hall
> > continues.
> > >
> > > Gavin, get a clue - if the current drift on Halloween in the Castro
> > > continues -
> > > you WILL be held directly accountable - by the electorate !!
> > >
> > >
