Subject: [sfraves] why the scene is how it is and how we can change it

------=_Part_442_4624817.1193300540781
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I'm about to make a lot of enemies with this, but hey, it's truth. Here are
my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what we have to do to change
it. I've compiled a list of the things that whether you realize it or not,
are negatively affecting the scene. They may be well intentioned, but the
laws of cause and effect are what we really have to look at here

1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the rave is about them
2. People being spectators rather than participators in the rave experience
3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of enemies, but i'll make my case if
you can supress your kandi filled brain and continue reading)
4. A lack of creativity and originality and artistry in the creation of a
rave
5. The need to appeal to the masses for the pure desire of money (if you are
going to do this as a promoter you have no right to call your party a rave)

Let's review, shall we?

1. First of all DJ's seem to hold themselves above the music they're
playing, as if they're the center of the rave, not the ravers, or the music,
which is destroying the very soul of rave. people tend to face the stage and
cheer the dj on, rather than dance and express themselves or interact and
enjoy the EXPERIENCE of the rave. THE DJ IS NOT A GOD, AND STOP PRETENDING
HE IS.

2 I would say the mass majority of people that come into a rave come in with
the mindset of coming to be entertained not to be an entertainer. You ought
to come with the mindset of being a contributer to the rave experience and
creating your OWN FUN. be an artist, dress up, bring cookies, shit, bring a
propane gun and fire that shit off in the middle of the dance floor.

3 Here's the one people will probably hound me on but let me explain.
Alright, i get it. it's a nice jester, wait, no it isn't. you spend hours
making an armful of kandi and guess what? how much thought did you put into
each piece? how original, personal, or thoughtful is that little piece of
plastic? kandi is a fad with good intentions that's inspiring conformity
over creativity and originality. why don't you try making individual gifts
with thought put behind each one and give a few gifts to a few people that
really deserve it? rather than whore out your pieces of plastic to "seem"
like a generous person. Not to mention the perpetuation of kandi mostly
perpetuates a kiddy fashion statement or fad

4 How many raves have you seen that have, oh lets see, a room, a table, some
cd'js....maybe a couple posters. There is a clear lack of decorations and
mood setting themes. come on! make me think im under water or in a cavern or
in a fucking jungle with bat shit insane ape monkeys. There's also a clear
lack of costume and roleplay (seriously, people throwing the party ought to
be dressed up with an alter-ego to flare in an artistic fashion to the
people coming in the door) as well as you could bring in things for people
to interact with at the rave. how about a box full of mirrors that people
can sit inside? (ok i stole that one from burning man, but still, you get
the idea, or maybe interactive lights. a hug booth. maybe you could do some
performance art on one side of the room, SERIOUSLY)

5 Please don't try to tell everyone and their mother to come to your rave
(or any rave), UNLESS you are willing to seriously tell them what a rave is
supposed to be about, and that they know they're supposed to be a
contributing member to the rave experience, rather than a spectator to see
something that "everyone's doing"

Ok, that's it. You can hate me or love me for it i don't care, but that's my
views on why rave's (i should say some because their are some very very few
raves that do follow this criteria, but i would say most do)

Go be an artist, dress up, play games, contribute, have fun, and most of
all, fuck shit up. scare the crap out of people

later

------=_Part_442_4624817.1193300540781--

DJ Mag's results of the top DJ poll just came out. Popularity contests are
always rigged through aggressive Myspace campaigns and apparant jakking, so
we can all pretty much toss this one.

A better poll would attemp to draw out and qualify: performance, technique,
style, innovation, # of releases, remixes and or # of bookings.

Anybody on this list run the Nitevibe dreamteam poll? I'd love to see them
integrate some of these questions. I'm sure
the results would look a lot different than they have in the past few years=
.

-Solekandi


http://www.residentadvisor.net/news.aspx?id=3D8903

Partying like it's 1999? Trance and progressive house were again big winner=
s
in DJ Mag's controversial reader's poll.

For a sixth year running, the top spot went to a trance jock - this time
30-year-old Dutchman Armin Van
Buuren<http://www.residentadvisor.net/dj-page.aspx?id=3D6>,
who took the number one spot from last year's winner Paul Van Dyk. The
undeniably huge Tiesto (who has 307,887 friends on MySpace) nabbed second
place, while progressive house stalwarts John Digweed and Sasha rounded out
the top five.

"It's a really big honour, I'm kind of stunned, y'know?" Van Buuren told DJ
Mag. "It's basically a dream come true!"

Hard techno also made a traditionally big showing with Umek, Carl Cox,
Valentino Kanzyani, Marco Bailey all making the list, while DJ Mag's strong
UK focus snagged places for local radio names such as Pete Tong, Judge Jule=
s
and Lisa Lashes. Psychedelic trance also proved popular with the likes of
Infected Mushroom, Astrix and Yahel all placing highly.

Curiously, plenty of votes came in for acts not really known for their
DJing, including The Chemical Brothers, Daft Punk, Trentemoller, BT and
Booka Shade.

This year's poll was steeped in controversy, with a number of DJs, includin=
g
Christopher Lawrence and DJ Dan, being disqualified amid accusations of
vote-rigging <http://www.residentadvisor.net/news.aspx?id=3D8926>. This yea=
r
DJ Mag collated the 345,000 cast votes in-house for the first time, and als=
o
instituted new rules to cut down on multiple-voting, a persistent problem
with Internet polls. "This year, I made a decision to investigate votes
where the same IP address appeared over 50 times for the same person,"
explains publisher James Robertson on the DJ Mag website.

*DJ Mag Top 100 2007*

1. Armin Van Buuren
2. Ti=EBsto
3. John Digweed
4. Paul Van Dyk
5. Sasha
6. Above & Beyond
7. Carl Cox
8. Ferry Corsten
9. Infected Mushroom
10. David Guetta
11. Deep Dish
12. Paul Oakenfold
13. Markus Schulz
14. Hernan Cattaneo
15. Sander Van Doorn
16. Eddie Halliwell
17. James Zabiela
18. Astrix
19. Richie Hawtin
20. Marco V


--=20

www.myspace.com/filtersf

------=_Part_3635_19297494.1193346709814--

Message-ID: <7a86c50c0710261257o1c73c465g9e30dad3b9494bce@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Fri, 26 Oct 2007 12:57:27 -0700
From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>
To: "Peter Farr" <fender1212@gmail.com>
Cc: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <81ecd2150710250122l76e5bd1cu8bbcde1ab048480e@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline
References: <81ecd2150710250122l76e5bd1cu8bbcde1ab048480e@mail.gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] why the scene is how it is and how we can change it

you're going to the wrong parties.

what were the last 5 parties that you attended?


On 10/25/07, Peter Farr <fender1212@gmail.com> wrote:
> I'm about to make a lot of enemies with this, but hey, it's truth. Here are
> my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what we have to do to change
> it. I've compiled a list of the things that whether you realize it or not,
> are negatively affecting the scene. They may be well intentioned, but the
> laws of cause and effect are what we really have to look at here
>
> 1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the rave is about them
> 2. People being spectators rather than participators in the rave experience
> 3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of enemies, but i'll make my case if
> you can supress your kandi filled brain and continue reading)
> 4. A lack of creativity and originality and artistry in the creation of a
> rave
> 5. The need to appeal to the masses for the pure desire of money (if you are
> going to do this as a promoter you have no right to call your party a rave)
>
> Let's review, shall we?
>
> 1. First of all DJ's seem to hold themselves above the music they're
> playing, as if they're the center of the rave, not the ravers, or the music,
> which is destroying the very soul of rave. people tend to face the stage and
> cheer the dj on, rather than dance and express themselves or interact and
> enjoy the EXPERIENCE of the rave. THE DJ IS NOT A GOD, AND STOP PRETENDING
> HE IS.
>
> 2 I would say the mass majority of people that come into a rave come in with
> the mindset of coming to be entertained not to be an entertainer. You ought
> to come with the mindset of being a contributer to the rave experience and
> creating your OWN FUN. be an artist, dress up, bring cookies, shit, bring a
> propane gun and fire that shit off in the middle of the dance floor.
>
> 3 Here's the one people will probably hound me on but let me explain.
> Alright, i get it. it's a nice jester, wait, no it isn't. you spend hours
> making an armful of kandi and guess what? how much thought did you put into
> each piece? how original, personal, or thoughtful is that little piece of
> plastic? kandi is a fad with good intentions that's inspiring conformity
> over creativity and originality. why don't you try making individual gifts
> with thought put behind each one and give a few gifts to a few people that
> really deserve it? rather than whore out your pieces of plastic to "seem"
> like a generous person. Not to mention the perpetuation of kandi mostly
> perpetuates a kiddy fashion statement or fad
>
> 4 How many raves have you seen that have, oh lets see, a room, a table, some
> cd'js....maybe a couple posters. There is a clear lack of decorations and
> mood setting themes. come on! make me think im under water or in a cavern or
> in a fucking jungle with bat shit insane ape monkeys. There's also a clear
> lack of costume and roleplay (seriously, people throwing the party ought to
> be dressed up with an alter-ego to flare in an artistic fashion to the
> people coming in the door) as well as you could bring in things for people
> to interact with at the rave. how about a box full of mirrors that people
> can sit inside? (ok i stole that one from burning man, but still, you get
> the idea, or maybe interactive lights. a hug booth. maybe you could do some
> performance art on one side of the room, SERIOUSLY)
>
> 5 Please don't try to tell everyone and their mother to come to your rave
> (or any rave), UNLESS you are willing to seriously tell them what a rave is
> supposed to be about, and that they know they're supposed to be a
> contributing member to the rave experience, rather than a spectator to see
> something that "everyone's doing"
>
> Ok, that's it. You can hate me or love me for it i don't care, but that's my
> views on why rave's (i should say some because their are some very very few
> raves that do follow this criteria, but i would say most do)
>
> Go be an artist, dress up, play games, contribute, have fun, and most of
> all, fuck shit up. scare the crap out of people
>
> later
>


-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

In-Reply-To: <BAY110-W33820ADE5C0862B818737B85960@phx.gbl>
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] why the scene is how it is and how we can change it

I like all of your points Peter and I agree with them. Hate to say it but
the rave culture has now become commercialized. Big name DJs think they are
all that and the true passion for creating music to spite the 'man' have all
died.

I believe this is why vinyl is fading as well. BPM is now closed and the
section that use to be dedicated all for EDM in Virgin is now mostly for
video games and they only have one wall for vinyl, which are mostly for
Timberlake/Paris Hilton wax....sucks!

This is why I support the underground movement and am part of the Moksha
Tribe. I want our rebirth to stimulate the true following of dance music,
the love, the respect and not to see how many people a promoter can shove
into a small space just to make a profit.

-Smitty

Subject: RE: [sfraves] why the scene is how it is and how we can change it


Not everyone's out to make a buck, and not every headlining DJ has a god co=
mplex - I think quite a few of us on this list know quite a few folks and c=
an attest to that.=20

But if you dig crap like Armin Van Tiesto Oaken-berg, you are buying into t=
he "top 10" commercial DJ sound/image, and you get what you pay for.=20

That's one reason I love SF - less of those kindsa of folks - we have peopl=
e like Garth & Jim Hopkins and Jeno & other names that have been doing it f=
or YEARS and don't sport that asshole 'tude.=20

Plus, I have seen more free events here than any other city I have lived in=
 or played in...if you all are experiencing that sort of crap, you need to =
change where you go, who you hang out with, or what clubs/Dj's/promoters yo=
u support....

~ Marco

>> On 10/25/07, Peter Farr wrote:
>>> I'm about to make a lot of enemies with this, but hey, it's truth. Here
> are
>>> my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what we have to do to
> change
>>> it. I've compiled a list of the things that whether you realize it or
> not,
>>> are negatively affecting the scene. They may be well intentioned, but t=
he
>>> laws of cause and effect are what we really have to look at here
>>>
>>> 1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the rave is about them
>>> 2. People being spectators rather than participators in the rave
> experience
>>> 3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of enemies, but i'll make my ca=
se
> if
>>> you can supress your kandi filled brain and continue reading)

 a
>>> rave

u
> are
>>> going to do this as a promoter you have no right to call your party a

>>>
>>> 1. First of all DJ's seem to hold themselves above the music they're
>>> playing, as if they're the center of the rave, not the ravers, or the
> music,

e
> and
>>> cheer the dj on, rather than dance and express themselves or interact a=
nd
>>> enjoy the EXPERIENCE of the rave. THE DJ IS NOT A GOD, AND STOP

>>> HE IS.

> with
>>> the mindset of coming to be entertained not to be an entertainer. You

> and
>>> creating your OWN FUN. be an artist, dress up, bring cookies, shit, bri=
ng
> a
>>> propane gun and fire that shit off in the middle of the dance floor.

of

y

> gifts
>>> with thought put behind each one and give a few gifts to a few people
> that
>>> really deserve it? rather than whore out your pieces of plastic to "see=
m"
>>> like a generous person. Not to mention the perpetuation of kandi mostly
>>> perpetuates a kiddy fashion statement or fad
>>>

rn

et

>>> On 10/25/07, Peter Farr wrote:

e
>> are
>>>> my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what we have to do to
>> change
>>>> it. I've compiled a list of the things that whether you realize it or
>> not,
>>>> are negatively affecting the scene. They may be well intentioned, but =
the
>>>> laws of cause and effect are what we really have to look at here
>>>>
>>>> 1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the rave is about them
>>>> 2. People being spectators rather than participators in the rave
>> experience
>>>> 3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of enemies, but i'll make my c=
ase
>> if
>>>> you can supress your kandi filled brain and continue reading)
>>>> 4. A lack of creativity and originality and artistry in the creation o=
f a
>>>> rave
>>>> 5. The need to appeal to the masses for the pure desire of money (if y=
ou
>> are
>>>> going to do this as a promoter you have no right to call your party a
>> rave)
>>>>
>>>> Let's review, shall we?
>>>>
>>>> 1. First of all DJ's seem to hold themselves above the music they're
>>>> playing, as if they're the center of the rave, not the ravers, or the
>> music,
>>>> which is destroying the very soul of rave. people tend to face the sta=
ge
>> and
>>>> cheer the dj on, rather than dance and express themselves or interact =
and
>>>> enjoy the EXPERIENCE of the rave. THE DJ IS NOT A GOD, AND STOP
>> PRETENDING
>>>> HE IS.
>>>>
>>>> 2 I would say the mass majority of people that come into a rave come i=
n
>> with
>>>> the mindset of coming to be entertained not to be an entertainer. You
>> ought
>>>> to come with the mindset of being a contributer to the rave experience
>> and
>>>> creating your OWN FUN. be an artist, dress up, bring cookies, shit, br=
ing
>> a
>>>> propane gun and fire that shit off in the middle of the dance floor.
>>>>
>>>> 3 Here's the one people will probably hound me on but let me explain.
>>>> Alright, i get it. it's a nice jester, wait, no it isn't. you spend ho=
urs
>>>> making an armful of kandi and guess what? how much thought did you put
>> into
>>>> each piece? how original, personal, or thoughtful is that little piece=
 of
>>>> plastic? kandi is a fad with good intentions that's inspiring conformi=
ty
>>>> over creativity and originality. why don't you try making individual
>> gifts
>>>> with thought put behind each one and give a few gifts to a few people
>> that
>>>> really deserve it? rather than whore out your pieces of plastic to "se=
em"
>>>> like a generous person. Not to mention the perpetuation of kandi mostl=
y
>>>> perpetuates a kiddy fashion statement or fad
>>>>
>>>> 4 How many raves have you seen that have, oh lets see, a room, a table=
,
>> some
>>>> cd'js....maybe a couple posters. There is a clear lack of decorations =
and
>>>> mood setting themes. come on! make me think im under water or in a cav=
ern
>> or
>>>> in a fucking jungle with bat shit insane ape monkeys. There's also a
>> clear
>>>> lack of costume and roleplay (seriously, people throwing the party oug=
ht
>> to
>>>> be dressed up with an alter-ego to flare in an artistic fashion to the
>>>> people coming in the door) as well as you could bring in things for
>> people
>>>> to interact with at the rave. how about a box full of mirrors that peo=
ple
>>>> can sit inside? (ok i stole that one from burning man, but still, you =
get
>>>> the idea, or maybe interactive lights. a hug booth. maybe you could do
>> some
>>>> performance art on one side of the room, SERIOUSLY)
>>>>
>>>> 5 Please don't try to tell everyone and their mother to come to your r=
ave
>>>> (or any rave), UNLESS you are willing to seriously tell them what a ra=
ve
>> is
>>>> supposed to be about, and that they know they're supposed to be a
>>>> contributing member to the rave experience, rather than a spectator to
>> see
>>>> something that "everyone's doing"
>>>>
>>>> Ok, that's it. You can hate me or love me for it i don't care, but tha=
t's
>> my

eople like Garth & Jim Hopkins and Jeno & other names that have been doing =
it for YEARS and don't sport that asshole 'tude.
>>>

d in or played in...if you all are experiencing that sort of crap, you need=

find the right crowd, the group, the right peoiple, the right setting...

Peter Farr wrote:
> I'm about to make a lot of enemies with this, but hey, it's truth. Here
> are
> my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what we have to do to change
> it. I've compiled a list of the things that whether you realize it or not,
> are negatively affecting the scene. They may be well intentioned, but the
> laws of cause and effect are what we really have to look at here
>
> 1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the rave is about them
> 2. People being spectators rather than participators in the rave
> experience
> 3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of enemies, but i'll make my case
> if
> you can supress your kandi filled brain and continue reading)
> 4. A lack of creativity and originality and artistry in the creation of a
> rave
> 5. The need to appeal to the masses for the pure desire of money (if you
> are
> going to do this as a promoter you have no right to call your party a
> rave)
>
> Let's review, shall we?
>
> 1. First of all DJ's seem to hold themselves above the music they're
> playing, as if they're the center of the rave, not the ravers, or the
> music,
> which is destroying the very soul of rave. people tend to face the stage
> and
> cheer the dj on, rather than dance and express themselves or interact and
> enjoy the EXPERIENCE of the rave. THE DJ IS NOT A GOD, AND STOP PRETENDING
> HE IS.
>
> 2 I would say the mass majority of people that come into a rave come in
> with
> the mindset of coming to be entertained not to be an entertainer. You
> ought
> to come with the mindset of being a contributer to the rave experience and
> creating your OWN FUN. be an artist, dress up, bring cookies, shit, bring
> a
> propane gun and fire that shit off in the middle of the dance floor.
>
> 3 Here's the one people will probably hound me on but let me explain.
> Alright, i get it. it's a nice jester, wait, no it isn't. you spend hours
> making an armful of kandi and guess what? how much thought did you put
> into
> each piece? how original, personal, or thoughtful is that little piece of
> plastic? kandi is a fad with good intentions that's inspiring conformity
> over creativity and originality. why don't you try making individual gifts
> with thought put behind each one and give a few gifts to a few people that
> really deserve it? rather than whore out your pieces of plastic to "seem"
> like a generous person. Not to mention the perpetuation of kandi mostly
> perpetuates a kiddy fashion statement or fad
>
> 4 How many raves have you seen that have, oh lets see, a room, a table,
> some
> cd'js....maybe a couple posters. There is a clear lack of decorations and
> mood setting themes. come on! make me think im under water or in a cavern
> or
> in a fucking jungle with bat shit insane ape monkeys. There's also a clear
> lack of costume and roleplay (seriously, people throwing the party ought
> to
> be dressed up with an alter-ego to flare in an artistic fashion to the
> people coming in the door) as well as you could bring in things for people
> to interact with at the rave. how about a box full of mirrors that people
> can sit inside? (ok i stole that one from burning man, but still, you get
> the idea, or maybe interactive lights. a hug booth. maybe you could do
> some
> performance art on one side of the room, SERIOUSLY)
>
> 5 Please don't try to tell everyone and their mother to come to your rave
> (or any rave), UNLESS you are willing to seriously tell them what a rave
> is
> supposed to be about, and that they know they're supposed to be a
> contributing member to the rave experience, rather than a spectator to see
> something that "everyone's doing"
>
> Ok, that's it. You can hate me or love me for it i don't care, but that's
> my
> views on why rave's (i should say some because their are some very very
> few
> raves that do follow this criteria, but i would say most do)
>
> Go be an artist, dress up, play games, contribute, have fun, and most of
> all, fuck shit up. scare the crap out of people
>
> later
>

Calamity Jane
Hickory
Sixty4k
Seventh Swami

From sfraves-return-142452-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sun Oct 28 18:27:21 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-142452-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk

Message-ID: <4724D47A.5090204@defsf.com>
Date: Sun, 28 Oct 2007 11:27:06 -0700
From: Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com>
User-Agent: Thunderbird 1.5.0.7 (Windows/20060909)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To:  sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] raves not retro

i had a discussion with a non raver/clubgoer just the other day and i 
was surprised to hear her say, "raves? what is this 1992?" and i 
realised that maybe we're too successful at being underground as a 
culture. but then i realized, 'hey wait, aren't clubs the most retro of 
all?' if anything, raves are a succession or transcendence of clubs. 
possibly the current trend is a step backward in our scene... where our 
music is being pigeonholed into clubs and deemed club music. the sound 
of which is only fit to be played at clubs.

sure i can agree that epic trance sounds awful in a small room or purely 
ridiculous.. and hard heavy schranz is only good for a dirty warehouse 
with a strobelight and a red flood light, but this current trend in our 
music will eventually change. maybe sway back to harder and heavier 
music possibly because clubs are the thing now. sort of a club revolt as 
in the origins of our scene.

take the techno trend for example. although i welcome the artistic and 
thoughtful directions of the current trends in techno.. i have to say 
there is definitely something to hard and pummeling excstatic awakenings 
that happen at a hard techno party. but if only producers would not lose 
the art for harder music i think we'd not have the trend of going all 
soft and minimal and clublike.

anyone else have seen this in their respective genres?

sean

defsf.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

On Sat, 27 Oct 2007, Eric Spire wrote:

> I have lots of pictures of parties that were exactly
> like what you are hoping foor annd describing.... It
> was called QUEST...

Preface: 
oh crap this reply was way-too-long...oh well....guess 
I should title it: "Quest impressions: according to Terry"

I'll speak a little on Quest (and stroke Eric's ego), since I've 
just got home and am winding down from Tonal last night (which 
kicked ass btw)...

I've worked with a lot of crews, from l33t UGs to mega-massives, 
Quest was one of the best series of massives in the late '90s. 
I'll be speaking from a behind-the-scenes perspective.

First the obvious, Quest was heavily and efficiently 
organized...A strong crew. Me coming into Quest from either a 
Feel-Good (small budgets/no attention-to-detail) and Harmony 
(scrappy, yet pinpoint attention-to-detail), it was refreshing 
and inspiring to work with Quest (killer budgets + pinpoint 
attention-to-detail)

A few examples of Quest's effort: mass produced props--as 
opposed to Harmony's individually crafted prop approach, 
Quest would still hand craft props but on a machined massive scale. They 
would also built BIG sets, like the life-sized elephants. Huge 
organic displays like floral arrangements from Passionflora/NYC, 
free fruit banquets integrated into the displays.

Eric/Quest, as opposed to other promoters, was always 
directing our efforts "over-our-shoulder", requesting effects, 
evaluating them, giving feedback, providing adequate back-up 
support. I think he had a team of contractors/Theater-geeks 
that were indispensible "rafter monkeys" in helping us put shit 
together. We learned a lot from working with them.

Their laser/lighting production was way over-complicated, but 
impressive. I seem to remember them boring through a 6' thick 
header beam at 85th/Baldwin to suspend lasers and/or sound. In 
the end it was always worth it as you'd see really original 
set-ups.

Quest drew a great crowd (at their biggest 12k?), from pretty 
humble beginnings they became a substantial equal to The 
Gathering massives in their hey-day.

There was also a Quest at the Brookdale Lodge, which was in my 
"domain" at the time, yet he ballzed-out a smaller party with 
uncontrollable debauchery. Harmony, Viberation(me), and Quest 
all threw parties at the place during that time. Eric's 
was probably the worst as controllable (Jen was pissed about 
that...tsk!!) But still a great party.

All-in-all, a lot of great memories, creative explosion, and 
aweesome execution. Thanks Quest.

(stroke your ego enough Eric???, hope the spider-bite's doing 
okay ;-)

-terry

------------------------------------------
terry estioko     | terry@hyperreal.org
http://www.viberation.com

	boundary="----=_Part_2172_9172173.1193600672163"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] raves not retro

------=_Part_2172_9172173.1193600672163
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

It's the format of most clubs in SF that's the problem, not the fact that
it's a club per se (see Fabric in London and Watergate or Panorama in Berlin
as examples). The right combination of factors will bring together the best
of the "rave" experience and the legitimacy of a club...but not here, and
not quite yet.

There's very little transcendence that can be experienced from 10-2,
especially when most club nights don't get going till 11:30 - 12:00. How far
can you really go in two hours of clubbing? It ends up being more of a
social hour and the music can't really progress that far.

Longer nights is the key to a better scene, no matter what the music is.

Anyway, this is an old story...isn't it? And it has more to do with our
political culture than our ability as EDM. Friends from Japan and Berlin
were in town this weekend and we had a lot to talk about on this topic....

I'd love to see the days when we, too, could have parties that "didn't get
going till 2:00" and ended at Noon the next day.

The LA techno secene seem to be going in this direction. I'm sure it has to
do with more available spaces and the fact that it's, well....LA.

-Solekandi


On 10/28/07, Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com> wrote:
>
> i had a discussion with a non raver/clubgoer just the other day and i
> was surprised to hear her say, "raves? what is this 1992?" and i
> realised that maybe we're too successful at being underground as a
> culture. but then i realized, 'hey wait, aren't clubs the most retro of
> all?' if anything, raves are a succession or transcendence of clubs.
> possibly the current trend is a step backward in our scene... where our
> music is being pigeonholed into clubs and deemed club music. the sound
> of which is only fit to be played at clubs.
>
> sure i can agree that epic trance sounds awful in a small room or purely
> ridiculous.. and hard heavy schranz is only good for a dirty warehouse
> with a strobelight and a red flood light, but this current trend in our
> music will eventually change. maybe sway back to harder and heavier
> music possibly because clubs are the thing now. sort of a club revolt as
> in the origins of our scene.
>
> take the techno trend for example. although i welcome the artistic and
> thoughtful directions of the current trends in techno.. i have to say
> there is definitely something to hard and pummeling excstatic awakenings
> that happen at a hard techno party. but if only producers would not lose
> the art for harder music i think we'd not have the trend of going all
> soft and minimal and clublike.
>
> anyone else have seen this in their respective genres?
>
> sean
>
> defsf.com
>

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>

www.myspace.com/filtersf

Subject: [sfraves] Tonal: I approve

--_4580abc0-703c-4d54-9d67-173663ded1bb_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


Alright, so I moved up here for college from socal (greatest decision ever)=
. Tonal was my first party up here, and I AM IN LOVE! I paid FIVE DOLLARS t=
o get in; 15 dollars is a bargain (and most likely a busted party) in LA. T=
here was no overpriced parking, no shuttle, no map point garbage... NO SHAD=
Y BS! They even threw in FREE WATER, WTF!?! Keep your pants on for just a m=
oment, this is but the beginning...

After walked in and looked around, my jaw hit the floor... the theme of the=
 party was actually carried out! The mannequin heads placed on the speakers=
 and elsewhere brought me alongside Alex deLarge for a night of oh, so fulf=
illing ultra-violence! However, we cannot forget the old in-out, in-out. Th=
e projector provided plenty of sensual visual delights, dashed with a hint =
of morbid horror scenes to spice things up. I don't know about you guys, bu=
t Alice (from Resident Evil) tearing stuff up and getting all pissed off, s=
imultaneously mixed with some honeys getting down, challenged the boundarie=
s of my imagination. Needless to say, I don't think I've ever been that hor=
ny on a dance floor in my life.

It even gets better, the costumes enhanced my visual experience more than a=
 death-star-laser-beam fired directly upon a happy hardcore dance floor. I'=
ve never had so much fun just looking at people! I must give a shout out to=
 the guy dressed as Nosferatu, I want to party with vampires every night I =
go out from now on. The girl in the droog outfit had me convinced that I wa=
s at the Korova milkbar with Alex, getting ready for some ultra-violence wh=
ile sipping on some milk-plus; not to mention, she convinced me that lady d=
roogs can be unbearably attractive (ultra-violence isn't just for the gents=
 anymore!). It sure as hell beats watching cracked out kandi kids massaging=
 each other in the middle of the dance floor.

And of course, we can't forget about the music. I'm not a house-head, but I=
 definitely got down to those funky, techy, electro beats! However, I don't=
 think I heard a single acid line that night; what a shame for the genre th=
at breed the term. Call me old-fashioned, but I think the TB-303 is the gre=
atest machine ever conceived; rumors say that it has induced sonic orgasms =
in several instances. Maybe I'm just too much of a psytrancer. Regardless, =
I got down proper to some groovy tunes.

My first party up here left an amazing first impression. Let's hope that it=
 just gets better from here. Now, if only Moontribe and droidbehavior came =
up with me, then it would be paradise...

_________________________________________________________________
Help yourself to FREE treats served up daily at the Messenger Caf=E9. Stop =
by today.
http://www.cafemessenger.com/info/info_sweetstuff2.html?ocid=3DTXT_TAGLM_Oc=
tWLtagline=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Party Review: Halloween

Hey wow I totally agree Nico.  Saturday night was one of those parties that rekindles your love for the music.  

I had originally been planning to lay low and not go out when Marco furnished me with the perfect excuse...he needed a ride.  So I ended up getting to the party way early and I stayed until around 3AM or so. I was still keeping it low key, since I knew I might have to leave unexpectedly.  My wife was very generously watching all the kids at home.

Marco opened the night with a sweet breaks set with MC Pupil on the mike.  This set really got going when Marco brought out the big bass and Pupil got flowing.  I especially enjoyed the mix with "Poppa Was a Rolling Stone" which is one of my favorite songs of all time from that era. Pupil is great BTW.

RAW/6BLOCC was the musical highlight for me...I've been digging dubstep for a while now, but this set (with an MC I didn't know and then MC Pupil again) was just totally rocking.  Wow, unquestionably the best dubstep mix I've ever heard even if there was one notable mixing glitch.  I need to get some dubstep records now I think.

Another highlight was Heather Heart's set upstairs.  I had seen Heather previously at the same venue before and I really enjoyed her style of trance.  I'm not a huge trance fan, but I've enjoyed both of Heather's sets which I've seen.  Later in the evening Heather came up and complimented me on my costume...<swoon> ;) Heather was dressed as a cheerleader and well if I wasn't married...just kidding, she was just super sweet.  Her friend Luna was beautiful also.

Since I hadn't really been planning to go, I was sort of tired when I got to the venue.  But the yummy breaks, dubstep, and trance got me moving even in my state of near exhaustion.  With a five month old at home, I haven't been sleeping that great for a few months now, but I was up and dancing at various points. 

I saw Marco of course (you Ok there dude?), Osby <hugz>, Redstickman, Agent Smith and his wife, ChuckG and his partner Paul, and I finally got to meet Chuck's GF Meagan.  I was super impressed with Meagan's presence Chuck.  You had better be nice to that girl!

Agent's Smith's wife takes the best costume award for her Dirty OBGYN outfit.  The gold speculum and 40oz made it!  Too funny.  I also liked whomever had the light up fish costume...wow that was pretty impressive.  Sorry I didn't get to meet you Nico, or did I?  I was dressed as Papa Gehde voodoo lord of death.

MBM came on right before I had to go, actually after I was supposed to go, so I didn't see nearly enough of Mr. Dangers, but what I did see was excellent.  I love MBM's projections which seem to compliment the music so well.

Another evening without much sleep well spent.

Can't wait for the next one!

Peace,

Peter

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

and that means it was fun.

On 10/28/07, Mark <rabid_donkey@msn.com> wrote:
>
> Alright, so I moved up here for college from socal (greatest decision eve=
r). Tonal was my first party up here, and I AM IN LOVE! I paid FIVE DOLLARS=
 to get in; 15 dollars is a bargain (and most likely a busted party) in LA.=
 There was no overpriced parking, no shuttle, no map point garbage... NO SH=
ADY BS! They even threw in FREE WATER, WTF!?! Keep your pants on for just a=
 moment, this is but the beginning...
>
> After walked in and looked around, my jaw hit the floor... the theme of t=
he party was actually carried out! The mannequin heads placed on the speake=
rs and elsewhere brought me alongside Alex deLarge for a night of oh, so fu=
lfilling ultra-violence! However, we cannot forget the old in-out, in-out. =
The projector provided plenty of sensual visual delights, dashed with a hin=
t of morbid horror scenes to spice things up. I don't know about you guys, =
but Alice (from Resident Evil) tearing stuff up and getting all pissed off,=
 simultaneously mixed with some honeys getting down, challenged the boundar=
ies of my imagination. Needless to say, I don't think I've ever been that h=
orny on a dance floor in my life.
>
> It even gets better, the costumes enhanced my visual experience more than=
 a death-star-laser-beam fired directly upon a happy hardcore dance floor. =
I've never had so much fun just looking at people! I must give a shout out =
to the guy dressed as Nosferatu, I want to party with vampires every night =
I go out from now on. The girl in the droog outfit had me convinced that I =
was at the Korova milkbar with Alex, getting ready for some ultra-violence =
while sipping on some milk-plus; not to mention, she convinced me that lady=
 droogs can be unbearably attractive (ultra-violence isn't just for the gen=
ts anymore!). It sure as hell beats watching cracked out kandi kids massagi=
ng each other in the middle of the dance floor.
>
> And of course, we can't forget about the music. I'm not a house-head, but=
 I definitely got down to those funky, techy, electro beats! However, I don=
't think I heard a single acid line that night; what a shame for the genre =
that breed the term. Call me old-fashioned, but I think the TB-303 is the g=
reatest machine ever conceived; rumors say that it has induced sonic orgasm=
s in several instances. Maybe I'm just too much of a psytrancer. Regardless=
, I got down proper to some groovy tunes.
>
> My first party up here left an amazing first impression. Let's hope that =
it just gets better from here. Now, if only Moontribe and droidbehavior cam=
e up with me, then it would be paradise...

Ah Mutex...yeah he was pretty good.  Enjoyed his set too.  

I forgot about Zeph and Azeem, some really great hip hop was played.  Right around that point I was lurking by the fountain of blood and severed baby arms.

I also forgot to mention the free CD someone gave me while I was hanging upstairs early in the evening.  Some glitchy techno from Ed Colmar.  I think Ed is channeling Nikola Tesla during parts of this CD.  Very enjoyable for the drive home!  Thanks to whomever gave it to me...was that Ed himself?  I think it was. 

Check it:  http://www.edcolmar.com

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: "electrofunk138@hotmail.com" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: nico <nico@viberation.com>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, October 29, 2007 12:40:58 PM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Party Review: Halloween


Yea, I really can't say enuff about R.A.W's sets (dubstep & d&b) - he really tore it the fuck up, and my MC (MC Pupil) even got to rock it out w/ him during his dubstep set. Forest Green brought it way harder and tighter than I have heard her throw down in a long long while, and of course folks like Heather Heart & Mutex brought the tasty 4x4 ruckus. 

Meat Beat started off pretty good, but it was not my favorite set they ever played - it got kind of way too spacey toward the middle of the set for my taste. 

One of the best parts of the night though, was Azeem & Zeph - these two guys are just getting massive. Had the crowd rocking out proper.

Thanks to all who caught my set and paid me compliments - I sincerely appreciate it!!!

ez.
Marco


> From: nico@viberation.com
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Date: Mon, 29 Oct 2007 01:50:34 -0700
> Subject: [sfraves] Party Review: Halloween
>
> Was amazing.
>
> RAW murdered everyone. Heather Hart buried the corpses. And the rest made the gravestones. Forrest's set was great, I love it when she beats the decks hard with her techno. Can't get enough of that.
>
> Sunday was rough just from the standpoint that it was a letdown from Saturday night. *shrug*
>
> love always

Ah Ed Colmar.. I have this great 2 tape mix set of his called Lies I got 
way back when. I think I kept them both because I love the graphic 
design so much. And the music is great too.

I keep wanting DJ's to start releasing mixtapes again. Some of my 
favorite mixes ever have been on mixtapes and I think it would be dope 
to go home from a party with a new mix you have to scrounge around the 
house looking for a walkman to listen to.

-t

Subject: [sfraves] Stockton, Otherworld, Tonal, and Bam's twin brother

--0-1196021159-1193690880=:58347
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

We had two mandatory parties to hit up in Stockton first. The first required me to dress like one of The Beatles, so I went with the black turtleneck from the white album. Check.

After the Beatles party @ the airport, Megan & I put on the orange jumpsuites & hit up Jeff's house in Stockton where my buddy Headcase was spinning. HC rocked it proper, and we grabbed Paul to head out to Otherworld. We jumped off the shuttle around 1:30, caught Osby just in time for a picture. Our boy J-Bar arrived around 2:30, and good times were had. Sorry I missed your set Marco; couldn't get there earlier. Glad we had a chance to say Hi anyways. 

Peter, always awesome to see you too man!!! Nice fit! I'm going to start going to work like that. Hope your better half took it easy on you, but I'm happy to vouch for you if need be, lol

MBM, always a good show. Didn't catch much more, because it was time to jump in the car & head to TONAL!!!!!

Arrived clad in the orange jumpsuit @ Tonal LITERALLY just in time for 4:20. Party still crackin!!! J-Bar & I found the other Josh and good times were had. Couldn't find Terry, but big up's to the visuals man. Guess I'll buy you a drink next round. Enjoyed Rooz' set. At least I think that was him upstairs.

Finally, I told my boy Josh there was a guy at the bar in a cowboy hat that looked like Bam. Joked with him that it was Bam's twin brother. Guess I was wrong. Sorry I didn't say hi to you either, but it was almost 5 and I was thirsty. 

Home & in bed around 7. Woke up late. Still rambling. . . Big up's to Andrew before I forget.

peace
CKG



--0-1196021159-1193690880=:58347--

From: "electrofunk138@hotmail.com" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>

Yea, I really can't say enuff about R.A.W's sets (dubstep & d&b) - he really tore it the fuck up, and my MC (MC Pupil) even got to rock it out w/ him during his dubstep set. Forest Green brought it way harder and tighter than I have heard her throw down in a long long while, and of course folks like Heather Heart & Mutex brought the tasty 4x4 ruckus. 

Meat Beat started off pretty good, but it was not my favorite set they ever played - it got kind of way too spacey toward the middle of the set for my taste. 

One of the best parts of the night though, was Azeem & Zeph - these two guys are just getting massive. Had the crowd rocking out proper.

Thanks to all who caught my set and paid me compliments - I sincerely appreciate it!!!

ez.
Marco

Subject: [sfraves] WR: Thursday Night: The real Birthday Bithday day night celebration

OK... so it was planned weeks ago, but a bunch of FnFers decided to go to
the SF Opera House for the show The Magic Flute... the night b4 i got the
perfect outfit ready, this black n gray stipped kinda zoot suit kinda
dealie, my grey DK shirt & this yummy grey tie w/ black & red blothes, &
my red converse...

Went to Berk to ride w/ Puddin', Rabbit, & Astra... we "Carpooled" to the
City (in the carpool lane 'cause it was B4 7PM still.. YAAAAY), got
parkin' right by City hall, then made this most fab walk to the Opera w/
yummy dressed people in a possee... it was Dope!! YAAAY

OK.. so here's the story in short (I'll try) from my POV... this traveler
dude from outta nowhere appears & a dragon is chasing him... he faints &
these 3 ladies show up & kill the dragon, & revive the travelor dude..
then this birdman, PapaGino, appears too playing this wooden harmonica & a
cage of birds he sells... the three ladies deliver a message to the
traveler dude from the Queen that her daughter needs to be saved from the
Evil King... so they arm the prince with a magic flyte to play when he's
in danger & he will be saved & they armed Papagino w/ this hang held
carosal thingie of bells (this of that light thing you hold in your hand
that spins & gives a light show, that thing from DisneyLand).. so somehow
the traveler dude & Papagino seperate... traveler dude ends up in a forest
where he plays the flute when all the wild animals appear & he starts
dancing with all of them & this like 3 foot tall parrot that has  red
converse shoes on like mine.. Papagino ends up in a dungeon w/ this grren
fat dude & sees the Princess... ok.. then there was alota back & forth w/
these gaurds, Papgino, the travelor dude, the evil king makes an
appearence w/ a village of peopl3 who worship him & hold on to his every
word that he's the coolest dude around yada yada & there's alota pyramid
climbing.. at one point, Papagino & the traveler dude couldn't talk 'cause
the gaurds told them not to & they will find the Loves of their lives...
Papagino finds Birdwoman Papagina then they have their own story line of
escaping the clutches of the Evil King.. & there's this whole thing about
the evil king sacrificing his people to a better life when they die.. then
he put the traveler dude & the pruncess on a test to see if they survive &
if they do, then they can live happily ever after.. so they walked through
a vulcano & survived, then they walked though the bottom of the sea &
survived ('cause the whole time, he played the magic flute & that
protected them)  It ended up being that the evil king was the good king &
the Queen was really evil... then the princess & the traveler due &
Papagino & Papagina & all the furry animals all lived happily ever after! 
The End

The whole thing was in German & there were screens that had subtittles to
what they were singing in German!  It was a good show.. but there were 2
solos i did fall asleep in 'cause ooh gosh... the story was just to fukced
up for me to like get.. Hello 2Day... i mean... yeah... I was confuzed,
but it was good & they sang really good!

After that i met up w/ an Austrailian Homie who was in town for a few
nights.. so that was fun!!!

Theni went to Compression!!  OK.. I know how I always said that
compression @ Beer Cellar was Dope esp after they remodeled.. but Hello
2day.. compression @ Temple in the Old Scool room... OOOH MY FUCKIN"
GOODNESS, OH MY GOSSH!!!!  So like DJs were Aye~N, Jamalcom, Sharpie, &
Ivry.. i thought it was a special surprise guest, but that was the week
b4.. so i just Grooved w/. all the Thursday Night Junglists that showed
up!  Afterwards... i was just gonna hang out in SOMA since it was on ly 2
hour wait 'til BART opened.. but Aye~N got pissed @ me for even thinking
about waiting in SOMA.. so he made sure i went to his house in Lower
Haight.. so me & Sharpie had this looooooong mondo talk about everything &
caught up w/ everything after Aye~N went to bed & we watched cartoons
too.. around 4:30, I left & went walking to the bus stop on haight
thinkin' i could catch the night owl.. b ut after like 15 minz, nada.. but
there wre hella buses passing by on the other street.. so i walked there &
asked this Crack Lady pretending to talk on a cell phone where the bus
was, & she told me to walk down to Market.. oooh.. Big G.. if you're
reading this... if you & lyds got awoken by singing outside your pad..
that was me 'casuse I was confuzed!  But 2 hours later, i made it home!!! 
Right as my parents woke up... I crashed!@ :)

But that was a very fun night!!!  YAAAAY!!!

Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] WR: Bday Celebration PT2: hallOWeen Shindig!!

So like it was Saturday & that means no buses running around Hercules to
get to the main bus stop... so luckily i was able to call Westcat & have a
small bus pick me up... YAAAY!!  Well.. total commute time took like 3
hours.. but i made it to Oakland & made it to Odub!

OK.. the whole fuckin' night was damn fuckin' Amazing!!  It was sooo Nice
to be around Family & to Celebrate my Birthday 1  more time & celebrate
everyone elses Scorp Birthdays early & late & on that night!!!  OK..
decor... the folks @ Odub went all out & man.. heads hangin' everywhere, a
graveyard, a witch in the corner, a ghost from Africa in the smoking room
(OK.. i made the Ghost).. but yeah.. cobwebs everywhere smoke, scary
visuals & lights from RA.. Red China Light Balls, wooden thingies.. it was
seriously Groovy & yeah.. they went all out!!  I was there early & kinda
put some nick knacks around ;)  Well.. yeah.. i did the opening door shift
too kinda...

Music: my faves were the opening set in the main room, the guy i 4get his
name, but he did  a fuckin' wicked breakcore set in the side room!  I
Loved RAW.. ooooooooooh... his fuckin' Hip Hop into Dub Step set in the
main room was Sick... Holy Fuckin' Shit man... so Dope!!  Then he did this
Jungle set in the side room FUCK it made me so Happy!!  But yeah, those
are the 2 that come to mind like really strong atm.. I mean... the music
was nothing less that mondo fuckin' Yummy all night... although i didn't
reeally go upstairs 'cause i was surrounded by so much Jungle, Breakcore,
& oooh.. Forest's Techno set.. i mean.. i coulda sworn she dropped a few
Electro Yummy in her set too.. but yeah.. she brought it hard & LoL..
there was a group of us in the smoking room that ran to the main room when
she got on!@!!!!  LOLOLMAO.. Hello 2day... yeah.. it was very easy getting
stuck in teh smoking room even if you weren't smoking for some reason..
well.. I mean.. like i totally did 'cause i mean.. yeah... I mean.. sets
even got off by an hour & yeah.. but everything still Yummy!!

People:  The vibe was fuckin' Thick!! I mean.. there were alota noobs who
never been, there was alota familia who it touched me so much to hang out
w/ (esp El Jaun, Love you Fucker).. i saw soo may people i aint seen in
forever & it was just a good way to spend a saturday night!!  Yeah.. it
was even Dope seein' Chuckie & NotAmanda like stroll in @ some weird
hour!!

By 7 something... pretty much the leftovers & stragglers.. we all bunched
up stairs for Marin's morning Sunrise set & brocked out to her Hip Hop!! 
Ooooh... Mikey & Piggy did a lil hip hop thinie too.. i was upthere for
that too for a bit... then around like 8:30.. me Sam & ummm.. ok.. let's
call her Stephinie for now walked to the BART & that was a journey..

LOL.. good times!!  Mondo Yummy Groovy Awesome Wicked Times!!  I Love you
OW!!!  Thank U for a BAd Ass Night!!!

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Oh yeah... Peter, that was Ed Colmar that gave you a CD... story with him
is that he went into retirement for well.. like 2 years.. but i think he's
back now which is good 'cause we need his Choclate Techno!!!  Oh yeah..
Fuckin' Shit... When Ed was in the side room doin' his live pa breakcore
shit... HOLY FUCK MAN... I was in HEAVEN!!!  Hello 2day!!   OK.. The End
Part 2!!  Love U SFR!!!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Anything happening in NYC this weekend or next?

Sub Swara

November, 2 2007 at Sub Swara 023 @ Love
179 Macdougal St, New York,
Cost :

After a monstrous capacity-rockin'2 year anniversary debut at Love
with the Glitch Mob, the Sub Swara posse comes back in November with a
night that touches all kinds of bass drenched territory. Hailing from
RONI SIZE'S legendary REPRAZENT & FULL CYCLE crews, DJ SUV (V
Recordings) will be Joining Sub Swara on the wheels with his trademark
spread of globally inflected organic junglist and dubstep
sensibilities. Also sharing the stage will be E.L.F (a frequent
collaborator with Tipper), straight from Maui, coming correct with his
melodically saturated bass weight that's been turning heads nationwide
throughout 2007. And as always, the Sub Swara crew will be rockin' the
live soundsystem proper. Nutshell: Sub Swara 023 Friday November 2,
2007 Love 179 Macdougal Street @ W. 8th 10 PM-6 AM $10 advance and on
Reduced List before 1AM/$15 door DISCOUNT ADVANCE TICKETS available at
www.musicislove.net Links, Sounds, Images & Connex: www.subswara.com
www.musicislove.net www.myspace.com/subswara www.djsuv.net
www.myspace.com/dhruvamusic www.myspace.com/freekusmaximus
www.myspace.com/juakali www.myspace.com/bassocietymusic
www.foreignfamiliar.com www.subswara.tribe.net

Subject: Re: [sfraves] raves not retro

Because clubs want 80s music and all the electric-clash/wave stuff.
Thank fucking christ for that. Rave-house-techno needed to die. It
became regressive. 


On Sun, 28 Oct 2007 11:27:06 -0700, "Sean Ocean" <seanocean@defsf.com>
said:
> i had a discussion with a non raver/clubgoer just the other day and i 
> was surprised to hear her say, "raves? what is this 1992?" and i 
> realised that maybe we're too successful at being underground as a 
> culture. but then i realized, 'hey wait, aren't clubs the most retro of 
> all?' if anything, raves are a succession or transcendence of clubs. 
> possibly the current trend is a step backward in our scene... where our 
> music is being pigeonholed into clubs and deemed club music. the sound 
> of which is only fit to be played at clubs.
> 
> sure i can agree that epic trance sounds awful in a small room or purely 
> ridiculous.. and hard heavy schranz is only good for a dirty warehouse 
> with a strobelight and a red flood light, but this current trend in our 
> music will eventually change. maybe sway back to harder and heavier 
> music possibly because clubs are the thing now. sort of a club revolt as 
> in the origins of our scene.
> 
> take the techno trend for example. although i welcome the artistic and 
> thoughtful directions of the current trends in techno.. i have to say 
> there is definitely something to hard and pummeling excstatic awakenings 
> that happen at a hard techno party. but if only producers would not lose 
> the art for harder music i think we'd not have the trend of going all 
> soft and minimal and clublike.
> 
> anyone else have seen this in their respective genres?
> 
> sean
> 
> defsf.com

> > Peter Farr wrote:
> > > I'm about to make a lot of enemies with this, but
> > hey, it's truth. Here
> > > are
> > > my thoughts on the way the scene is going and what
> > we have to do to change
> > > it. I've compiled a list of the things that
> > whether you realize it or not,
> > > are negatively affecting the scene. They may be
> > well intentioned, but the
> > > laws of cause and effect are what we really have
> > to look at here
> > >
> > > 1. DJ's with over-inflated ego's who believe the
> > rave is about them
> > > 2. People being spectators rather than
> > participators in the rave
> > > experience
> > > 3. Kandi (here's where i'm making a lot of
> > enemies, but i'll make my case
> > > if
> > > you can supress your kandi filled brain and
> > continue reading)
> > > 4. A lack of creativity and originality and
> > artistry in the creation of a
> > > rave
> > > 5. The need to appeal to the masses for the pure
> > desire of money (if you
> > > are
> > > going to do this as a promoter you have no right
> > to call your party a
> > > rave)
> > >
> > > Let's review, shall we?
> > >
> > > 1. First of all DJ's seem to hold themselves above
> > the music they're
> > > playing, as if they're the center of the rave, not
> > the ravers, or the
> > > music,
> > > which is destroying the very soul of rave. people
> > tend to face the stage
> > > and
> > > cheer the dj on, rather than dance and express
> > themselves or interact and
> > > enjoy the EXPERIENCE of the rave. THE DJ IS NOT A
> > GOD, AND STOP PRETENDING
> > > HE IS.
> > >
> > > 2 I would say the mass majority of people that
> > come into a rave come in
> > > with
> > > the mindset of coming to be entertained not to be
> > an entertainer. You
> > > ought
> > > to come with the mindset of being a contributer to
> > the rave experience and
> > > creating your OWN FUN. be an artist, dress up,
> > bring cookies, shit, bring
> > > a
> > > propane gun and fire that shit off in the middle
> > of the dance floor.
> > >
> > > 3 Here's the one people will probably hound me on
> > but let me explain.
> > > Alright, i get it. it's a nice jester, wait, no it
> > isn't. you spend hours
> > > making an armful of kandi and guess what? how much
> > thought did you put
> > > into
> > > each piece? how original, personal, or thoughtful
> > is that little piece of
> > > plastic? kandi is a fad with good intentions
> > that's inspiring conformity
> > > over creativity and originality. why don't you try
> > making individual gifts
> > > with thought put behind each one and give a few
> > gifts to a few people that
> > > really deserve it? rather than whore out your
> > pieces of plastic to "seem"
> > > like a generous person. Not to mention the
> > perpetuation of kandi mostly
> > > perpetuates a kiddy fashion statement or fad
> > >
> > > 4 How many raves have you seen that have, oh lets
> > see, a room, a table,
> > > some
> > > cd'js....maybe a couple posters. There is a clear
> > lack of decorations and
> > > mood setting themes. come on! make me think im
> > under water or in a cavern
> > > or
> > > in a fucking jungle with bat shit insane ape
> > monkeys. There's also a clear
> > > lack of costume and roleplay (seriously, people
> > throwing the party ought
> > > to
> > > be dressed up with an alter-ego to flare in an
> > artistic fashion to the
> > > people coming in the door) as well as you could
> > bring in things for people
> > > to interact with at the rave. how about a box full
> > of mirrors that people
> > > can sit inside? (ok i stole that one from burning
> > man, but still, you get
> > > the idea, or maybe interactive lights. a hug
> > booth. maybe you could do
> > > some
> > > performance art on one side of the room,
> > SERIOUSLY)
> > >
> > > 5 Please don't try to tell everyone and their
> > mother to come to your rave
> > > (or any rave), UNLESS you are willing to seriously
> > tell them what a rave
> > > is
> > > supposed to be about, and that they know they're
> > supposed to be a
> > > contributing member to the rave experience, rather
> > than a spectator to see
> > > something that "everyone's doing"
> > >
> > > Ok, that's it. You can hate me or love me for it i
> > don't care, but that's
> > > my
> > > views on why rave's (i should say some because
> > their are some very very
> > > few
> > > raves that do follow this criteria, but i would
> > say most do)
> > >
> > > Go be an artist, dress up, play games, contribute,
> > have fun, and most of
> > > all, fuck shit up. scare the crap out of people
> > >
> > > later
> > >

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Nov.3rd [KONTROL] w/ Tadeo, Damian Schwartz LIVE, Vadim, & Solar

Saturday, November 3rd, 2007

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


NET 28 SHOWCASE ft. from in Madrid, Spain:

<<< TADEO >>>

( Cyclical Tracks . CMYK Musik . Apnea . M=FApa )

Influenced by seminal techno artists like Plastikman and
Jeff Mills, Tadeo's productions fuse the early sound of
Detroit with tones of jazz and cutting-edge electronics.
His energetic DJ sets are the culmination of years of
experimentation and working the crowds at his own basement
techno events in Spain.  Don't miss what's sure to be a
slamming San Francisco debut!


and:

<<< DAMI=C1N SCHWARTZ >>> LIVE!

( Musica Charlista . M=FApa . CMYK Musik . Apnea )

With 5 years of production and 3 years of outstanding
releases on some of Spain's brightest techno labels to his
credit, it's no wonder why this 24-year-old Madrid native
is in high demand.  From his innovative solo projects to
his work as Musica Charlista with labelmate Alex Under,
Dami=E1n has consistently delivered his signature avant-garde
sound to ecstatic dancefloors across the globe.



plus special guests:

VADIM ( loft.n.space . LESS : NYC)

Last heard at the wicked Platform underground earlier this
year, NYC's minimal evangelist Vadim returns with another
foray into techno's darker corners and heavier rhythms:
throbbing, deep space music that will get you lost inside
your own head.


and:

SOLAR ( Bang The Box . Bionic : SF )

Sure, you know Solar from his years with the Sunset crew
and from rocking damn near every last party in town over
the past decade...but tonight he'll show he can still
surprise with a techy set crafted specially for KONTROL.


with [KONTROL] residents:

ALLAND BYALLO   ( Leibe*Detail . Nightlight Music )

NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . S.W.A.T. )


________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

[ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K29/K29F.jpg

Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K29/K29B.jpg

Poster:
http://www.allandbyallo.com/projects/kontrol/1103/poster/K29P.jpg


____________________________________________________


TADEO

Tadeo is influenced by various branches of electronic music,
especially by Detroit Techno and Cristian Vogel, Neil Landstrum,
Plastikman and Jeff Mills productions. In his first stage, he created
the collective Domestic Techno with DJ Slick, carrying out parties in
several clubs and basements of their city.

Throughout time he has tested almost every single style of electronic
dance music.  After a large period of techno investigation and
development, Tadeo runs his actual art collective Javha oriented to
all kinds of art expressions, and Cyclical Tracks, a conceptual techno
label. In this second stage, he purified his technique and studied
with care the connection with audience, trying to make this connection
the principal resource of his sets. Since then and little by little,
minimal and electronic sounds have started to become a natural rule
both in his sets and productions. He also has a predilection for dub
and sounds which emanate from Jamaican music. In May 2004 he released
his first 12" in his own label, Cyclical Tracks, and a remix for Alex
Under on CMYK002. In November 2004 he released Dub Infection
(APNEA002), featuring the techno-dub legend Paul St. Hilaire aka
Tikiman.

In June 2005 Tadeo released Lup! (CT-02): this time the music took a
step away from dub while his Detroit Techno influences were more
noticeable... dark and unstoppable dance, pure groove that impressed
artists like Magda, Troy Pierce, Luciano, Damian Lazarus, Marco
Carola, and countless others.  His innovative and dancefloor-friendly
tracks have appeared on mix compilations by techno heavy-hitters such
as Luciano, Loco Dice, Chris Liebing, Richie Hawtin and Tiefschwarz,
to name a few.


Tadeo's Website:
http://www.cyclicaltracks.com/

Tadeo's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Tadeo

Tadeo's MySpace profile:
http://www.myspace.com/cyclicaltracks

Music samples on Beatport.com
http://www.beatport.com/Tadeo

Tadeo on YouTube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D6PcRp0xkO64



________________________________________________


DAMI=C1N SCHWARTZ

At only 24 years of age, Dami=E1n Schwartz has already has logged 5
years producing electronic music, and 3 years releasing and working
with the Madrid platform Net 28, which includes the labels Apnea,
Bemysheep, CMYKmusik, Cyclical Tracks, Mupa and Pulpa. He joined Net
28 after meeting Alex Under, with whom he created the Musica Charlista
project. Dami=E1n is also responsible for the youngest record label of
the Net 28 family, M=FApa.

As a producer Dami=E1n inclines towards the avant-garde: developing
multiple musical concepts, turning his music into something original
and unique.  Surprise, jazz, harmony and melody are the common factors
in Dami=E1n=B4s solo productions, though never losing sight of the dance
floor.  The concept is the most important matter in his universe:
images, ideas and sensations giving shape to the concept, and the
music as the courier of that message, filling the space as the water
fills everything on its route.  Raw sequences, unique samples, strong
patterns, frantic rhythms, innovation, inspiration... Techno as you've
never really heard it.


Dami=E1n Schwartz's website:
http://www.mupa.biz/

Dami=E1n Schwartz's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Dami%C3%A1n+Schwartz

Dami=E1n Schwartz's MySpace Profile:
http://www.myspace.com/damianschwartz

Music samples on Beatport.com
http://www.beatport.com/Damian%20Schwartz

Dami=E1n Schwartz on YouTube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D9qCavnxr-Xc


________________________________________________


VADIM

Vadim, originally from Moscow where he graduated from music school for
classical guitar, has been DJing and promoting electronic events in
NYC since 1999. His first DJ gigs were at underground parties in small
clubs and infamous outdoor "bridge" parties. Between 1999 and 2005 he
worked with Jason as SubtleChaos DJing and promoting parties around
NYC. Vadim and his new partner Igal are also known as "loft.n.space"
which is a concept that was born when a vacant factory loft in
Brooklyn has appeared as a perfect spot for a party. Since then,
loft.n.space has hosted latenight and afterhours events with
international DJs and live acts such as Dan Bell (Tresor), Zip & Sammy
Dee (Perlon), Alka_Rex (Supralinear, Resopal), Vince Lemieux (Musique
Risqu=E9e), and Pheek (Minus, Archipel).  Currently Vadim is a resident
at one of NYC's most respected weekly events - "LESS" @ Annex.


Vadim's MySpace profile:
http://www.myspace.com/comtak

________________________________________________


SOLAR

C'mon people. You know who this guy is.


Solar's MySpace profile:
http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=3Duser.viewprofile&friendid=
=3D135504

http://www.kontrolsf.com

From: sarah parkin <sarahparkin78@mailworks.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, October 30, 2007 6:29:13 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] raves not retro


Because clubs want 80s music and all the electric-clash/wave stuff.
Thank fucking christ for that. Rave-house-techno needed to die. It
became regressive. 


On Sun, 28 Oct 2007 11:27:06 -0700, "Sean Ocean" <seanocean@defsf.com>
said:
> i had a discussion with a non raver/clubgoer just the other day and i
 
> was surprised to hear her say, "raves? what is this 1992?" and i 
> realised that maybe we're too successful at being underground as a 
> culture. but then i realized, 'hey wait, aren't clubs the most retro
 of 
> all?' if anything, raves are a succession or transcendence of clubs. 
> possibly the current trend is a step backward in our scene... where
 our 
> music is being pigeonholed into clubs and deemed club music. the
 sound 
> of which is only fit to be played at clubs.
> 
> sure i can agree that epic trance sounds awful in a small room or
 purely 
> ridiculous.. and hard heavy schranz is only good for a dirty
 warehouse 
> with a strobelight and a red flood light, but this current trend in
 our 
> music will eventually change. maybe sway back to harder and heavier 
> music possibly because clubs are the thing now. sort of a club revolt
 as 
> in the origins of our scene.
> 
> take the techno trend for example. although i welcome the artistic
 and 
> thoughtful directions of the current trends in techno.. i have to say
 
> there is definitely something to hard and pummeling excstatic
 awakenings 
> that happen at a hard techno party. but if only producers would not
 lose 
> the art for harder music i think we'd not have the trend of going all
 
> soft and minimal and clublike.
> 
> anyone else have seen this in their respective genres?
> 
> sean
> 
> defsf.com
>

> ----- Original Message ----
> From: sarah parkin <sarahparkin78@mailworks.org>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Tuesday, October 30, 2007 6:29:13 PM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] raves not retro
>
>
> Because clubs want 80s music and all the electric-clash/wave stuff.
> Thank fucking christ for that. Rave-house-techno needed to die. It
> became regressive.
>
>
> On Sun, 28 Oct 2007 11:27:06 -0700, "Sean Ocean" <seanocean@defsf.com>
> said:
> > i had a discussion with a non raver/clubgoer just the other day and i
>
> > was surprised to hear her say, "raves? what is this 1992?" and i
> > realised that maybe we're too successful at being underground as a
> > culture. but then i realized, 'hey wait, aren't clubs the most retro
>  of
> > all?' if anything, raves are a succession or transcendence of clubs.
> > possibly the current trend is a step backward in our scene... where
>  our
> > music is being pigeonholed into clubs and deemed club music. the
>  sound
> > of which is only fit to be played at clubs.
> >
> > sure i can agree that epic trance sounds awful in a small room or
>  purely
> > ridiculous.. and hard heavy schranz is only good for a dirty
>  warehouse
> > with a strobelight and a red flood light, but this current trend in
>  our
> > music will eventually change. maybe sway back to harder and heavier
> > music possibly because clubs are the thing now. sort of a club revolt
>  as
> > in the origins of our scene.
> >
> > take the techno trend for example. although i welcome the artistic
>  and
> > thoughtful directions of the current trends in techno.. i have to say
>
> > there is definitely something to hard and pummeling excstatic
>  awakenings
> > that happen at a hard techno party. but if only producers would not
>  lose
> > the art for harder music i think we'd not have the trend of going all
>
> > soft and minimal and clublike.
> >
> > anyone else have seen this in their respective genres?
> >
> > sean
> >
> > defsf.com
> >

CHUCK G wrote:
> I love the fact our internet still works; that's so fuckin' reppin. You out there Terry?
>    
>   CKG
>   
.
umm, like, not to put to fine a point on it, such as, y'know, the whole 
damned point of Al Gore creating the Internets was/is that it's a 
decentralized communications system capable of withstanding *a full-on 
nuclear attack* and still keeping all of out Nation's Military 
Command\Control & Response structures in place.

The fact that the NebWets turned into the greatest single repository of 
human knowledge, since the Library of Alexandria, (and Sam Walton's 
wildest strip mall/big box store fantasy, wet dream), in the blink of an 
eye, was one of those unanticipated consequences that we hear so much about.

A couple of tectonic plates, miles below earth's surface, shrugging 
their shoulders and scratching an itch, for a moment, is no cause for 
alarm, the real threat of burning the thing down and having to start 
over, from scratch, is from within.

All you need is some idiot 15 year old kid out behind the barn, with a 
book of matches in the form of 20 lines of malicious virus code that can 
bring this bitch to its knees, and then you've got really something to 
worry about and keep you up night.

Speaking for nobody, I'd be much more concerned about that particular 
scenario, than some random and rare 5+ pointer, that shook up a few 
people, (that even took the time to bother to notice), before breakfast.

As always, ymmv.

PS: JC when you get to the Isle of Manhattan, gimme a call at 646 918 
3656 I've a friend in Williamsburgh that you might like 2 meet.

He's doing a modern day update of 1984 called "Winston's World" that 
can  be found here: http://www.mrdrinkwater.com/

~Nyc

From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com

  SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Cc: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Message-ID: <754169.77986.qm@web32414.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Nice shake!

Actually the whole resilance to nuclear attack thing is pretty overblown depending on what you are talking about.  While it would be hard to bring down the entire global Internet, taking out a specific country is not hard and it has happened.  For example, the ruling junta in Myanmar shut down the Internet to control information flow during the recent protests there.  Another example would be the Russian hacker attacks on Estonia following the removal of a Soviet era war monument.

Here in the US, the Internet backbone consists in part of a number of Internet Exchange Points which connect the various ISPs allowing them to exchange data.  According to Wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Exchange_Point) there are only 20-30 of these in the United States located in a similar number of cities. If these were taken out in their entirety some aspects of the public US Internet might still work, but I wouldn't count on it.

Regards,

Peter

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Nice shake!

It would be pretty hard to take down the US's interweb... There are dozens
of colo's just standing by in case some of the AS routers fail/die... All an
ISP needs to do is login and change the static route and fixed... It happens
daily... 

Here is an active monitor that will show when the interweb is having a
problem... 

www.internethealthreport.com 

I rely on sites like these to track where problems, for my customers, are in
routing to us. 

-r4ph

>> alarm, the real threat of burning the thing down and having to start 
>> over, from scratch, is from within.
>>
>> All you need is some idiot 15 year old kid out behind the barn, with a 
>> book of matches in the form of 20 lines of malicious virus code that 
>> can bring this bitch to its knees, and then you've got really 
>> something to worry about and keep you up night.
>>
>> Speaking for nobody, I'd be much more concerned about that particular 
>> scenario, than some random and rare 5+ pointer, that shook up a few 
>> people, (that even took the time to bother to notice), before breakfast.
>>
>> As always, ymmv.
>>
>> PS: JC when you get to the Isle of Manhattan, gimme a call at 646 918 
>> 3656 I've a friend in Williamsburgh that you might like 2 meet.
>>
>> He's doing a modern day update of 1984 called "Winston's World" that 
>> can  be found here: http://www.mrdrinkwater.com/
>>
>> ~Nyc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] raves not retro

------=_Part_8419_32623829.1193850443321
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I think the majority of the public sees 'raves' as a thing for chitlins. A
kind of ecstasy and reach around back rub rite of passage. Kids discover it
at 17 and burn out by 19, or they hold out and become coked out clubheads by
22.
I seem to hear a lot of 'I used to go to raves, then I went to recovery'
stories from a certain generation that was 18 around the turn of the
millennium.

The problem is there are many kinds of ravers, who rave for many different
reasons. Clubs are legal and convenient. They are always there, they don't
get broken up at 2am when you're up to your shenanigans. There is no hunting
for map points. If you want to get f'd up and meet some hos, the club serves
both of those purposes with gusto.

If you start yammering at most dance music consumers about Temporary
Autonomous Zones and reclaiming space and spiritual experiences they will
politely excuse themselves and go find more drugs/hos/pleasant feelings. And
it's a phase for them anyway, like listening to Nirvana or swinging or World
of Warcraft.



On 10/28/07, Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com> wrote:
>
> i had a discussion with a non raver/clubgoer just the other day and i
> was surprised to hear her say, "raves? what is this 1992?" and i
> realised that maybe we're too successful at being underground as a
> culture. but then i realized, 'hey wait, aren't clubs the most retro of
> all?' if anything, raves are a succession or transcendence of clubs.
> possibly the current trend is a step backward in our scene... where our
> music is being pigeonholed into clubs and deemed club music. the sound
> of which is only fit to be played at clubs.
>
> sure i can agree that epic trance sounds awful in a small room or purely
> ridiculous.. and hard heavy schranz is only good for a dirty warehouse
> with a strobelight and a red flood light, but this current trend in our
> music will eventually change. maybe sway back to harder and heavier
> music possibly because clubs are the thing now. sort of a club revolt as
> in the origins of our scene.
>
> take the techno trend for example. although i welcome the artistic and
> thoughtful directions of the current trends in techno.. i have to say
> there is definitely something to hard and pummeling excstatic awakenings
> that happen at a hard techno party. but if only producers would not lose
> the art for harder music i think we'd not have the trend of going all
> soft and minimal and clublike.
>
> anyone else have seen this in their respective genres?
>
> sean
>
> defsf.com
>
