From: dj sinestro <djsinestro@hotmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Wed, 31 Oct 2007 13:41:52 -0400
Importance: Normal
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 31 Oct 2007 17:41:52.0521 (UTC) FILETIME=[52796F90:01C81BE5]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] On the idea of a new style of party

--_cd8ccaa8-068a-4979-aa43-80f4e2f03e6d_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable



I just had a brain fart.

On my local list (dcraves) we have been discussing ways to create a new sty=
le of party that focus's on the patron rather then the superstar Dj (as it =
orginally was back in the early days of parties circa late 80's early 90's)=
. We had come to the conclusion that more then anything else, basic economi=
cs were getting in the way of doing this because of the need for headlining=
 DJ's to fill the party and thus having to put them on a pedastal (big name=
 on the flyer, all partygoers looking at the DJ idolizing, etc), which is r=
eally counterproductive to the orginal idea of rave in the first place. I m=
ean, honestly, when you break it down, DJ's play other people's music. Ther=
e is really no need for all this fawning on them lol.

This comic best illustrates this and how it has stagnated the scene
http://www.cyborganization.org/trance.jpg

So we thought it would be best to market the party with no Dj names on the =
flyers, Stick the Dj in some place that the crowd would not intentionally a=
ll be looking at him(hidden somewhere?) and concentrate the party funds tow=
ards atmosphere and doing whatever is needed to focus the party on the patr=
on and not the DJ. This still caused an issue due to the problem of having =
the big dj to pull the big numbers out to the party.






So the whole idea of creating and marketing a party without the use of
DJ's on the flyers and also making sure the crowd doesn't have the DJ
in view was widely accepted I think on this list. We could all agree that
this type of party would be "the" party that could change the current
status quo and perhaps create a new style of party.



My original argument stated economics was holding this back based on patron=
s only going to parties that had their favorite dj's



but





What if the promoter were to market the party with no DJ's on the flyer but=
 book a big name?=20

If said promoter did 3 or 4 of these, word of mouth alone would fill
his parties based on the "possibility" of any big name dj being there, even=
 though you never know what you would get.

Granted, the first couple parties would have to be in small locations
and then grow, however, if it was done correctly with the focus on the
enviroment then just the idea of suprise DJ's would excite people and
entice them to make sure they don't miss out, less they might miss a Dj
they have always wanted to hear. This would ultimatly allow the
promoter to truly experiment with new styles and have the freedom he
needs to push the envelope. one month he could have superstar dj
whoever then the next month unknown but badass new dj. And since the
party would be focused more on the individual party goer then the DJ,
He could focus his attention more on helping that aspect grow.



Thoughts?




Sinestro

I like large posteriors and I cannot prevaricate.

--_cd8ccaa8-068a-4979-aa43-80f4e2f03e6d_--

You're just replacing one idol with a different one.
Some party promoter hoozball, for instance. Or some stupid celebrity.
I'd love to see CREWS get reputations, now.
In fact, I often go to certain crews' events no matter who is playing, even
if I only recognize one name and don't like him much, because I know the
event will have a certain vibe or an amazing location.
So. Pimp The Crew. :) Or, maybe, pimp the party. People go to Monster
Massive in LA every year no matter who is playing...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] On the idea of a new style of party

this is not a new idea.

but it's not a bad one, either.


On 10/31/07, dj sinestro <djsinestro@hotmail.com> wrote:
>
>
> I just had a brain fart.
>
> On my local list (dcraves) we have been discussing ways to create a new s=
tyle of party that focus's on the patron rather then the superstar Dj (as i=
t orginally was back in the early days of parties circa late 80's early 90'=
s). We had come to the conclusion that more then anything else, basic econo=
mics were getting in the way of doing this because of the need for headlini=
ng DJ's to fill the party and thus having to put them on a pedastal (big na=
me on the flyer, all partygoers looking at the DJ idolizing, etc), which is=
 really counterproductive to the orginal idea of rave in the first place. I=
 mean, honestly, when you break it down, DJ's play other people's music. Th=
ere is really no need for all this fawning on them lol.
>
> This comic best illustrates this and how it has stagnated the scene
> http://www.cyborganization.org/trance.jpg
>
> So we thought it would be best to market the party with no Dj names on th=
e flyers, Stick the Dj in some place that the crowd would not intentionally=
 all be looking at him(hidden somewhere?) and concentrate the party funds t=
owards atmosphere and doing whatever is needed to focus the party on the pa=
tron and not the DJ. This still caused an issue due to the problem of havin=
g the big dj to pull the big numbers out to the party.
>
>
>
>
>
>
> So the whole idea of creating and marketing a party without the use of
> DJ's on the flyers and also making sure the crowd doesn't have the DJ
> in view was widely accepted I think on this list. We could all agree that
> this type of party would be "the" party that could change the current
> status quo and perhaps create a new style of party.
>
>
>
> My original argument stated economics was holding this back based on patr=
ons only going to parties that had their favorite dj's
>
>
>
> but
>
>
>
>
>
> What if the promoter were to market the party with no DJ's on the flyer b=
ut book a big name?
>
> If said promoter did 3 or 4 of these, word of mouth alone would fill
> his parties based on the "possibility" of any big name dj being there, ev=
en though you never know what you would get.
>
> Granted, the first couple parties would have to be in small locations
> and then grow, however, if it was done correctly with the focus on the
> enviroment then just the idea of suprise DJ's would excite people and
> entice them to make sure they don't miss out, less they might miss a Dj
> they have always wanted to hear. This would ultimatly allow the
> promoter to truly experiment with new styles and have the freedom he
> needs to push the envelope. one month he could have superstar dj
> whoever then the next month unknown but badass new dj. And since the
> party would be focused more on the individual party goer then the DJ,
> He could focus his attention more on helping that aspect grow.
>
>
>
> Thoughts?
>
>
>
>
> Sinestro
>

>
> I like large posteriors and I cannot prevaricate.
> www.rehabrecords.net

I guess it is on our end on the east coast.
We did do something along these lines though with the sleaze parties back i=
n 2000 when electroclash first came out and it did well based on the idea t=
hat you could only hear that style at our party, so it brought people out b=
ased on the idea rather then who was playing it. Either way though, I reall=
y feel as though the party scene in general tends to focus on Dj's rather t=
hen the patron itself whereas it didn't seem to do that in the early 90's.=
=20


Sinestro

>>> DJ Mag's results of the top DJ poll just came out. Popularity
>>> contests are

>>> jakking, so
>>> we can all pretty much toss this one.
>>>
>>> A better poll would attemp to draw out and qualify: performance,
>>> technique,
>>> style, innovation, # of releases, remixes and or # of bookings.
>>>
>>> Anybody on this list run the Nitevibe dreamteam poll? I'd love to
>>> see them
>>> integrate some of these questions. I'm sure
>>> the results would look a lot different than they have in the past
>>> few years.
>>>
>>> -Solekandi
>>>
>>>
>>> http://www.residentadvisor.net/news.aspx?id=3D8903
>>>
>>> Partying like it's 1999? Trance and progressive house were again
>>> big winners
>>> in DJ Mag's controversial reader's poll.
>>>
>>> For a sixth year running, the top spot went to a trance jock - this
>>> time
>>> 30-year-old Dutchman Armin Van
>>> Buuren<http://www.residentadvisor.net/dj-page.aspx?id=3D6>,
>>> who took the number one spot from last year's winner Paul Van =20
>>> Dyk. The
>>> undeniably huge Tiesto (who has 307,887 friends on MySpace) nabbed
>>> second
>>> place, while progressive house stalwarts John Digweed and Sasha
>>> rounded out
>>> the top five.
>>>
>>> "It's a really big honour, I'm kind of stunned, y'know?" Van Buuren
>>> told DJ
>>> Mag. "It's basically a dream come true!"
>>>
>>> Hard techno also made a traditionally big showing with Umek, Carl =20=

>>> Cox,
>>> Valentino Kanzyani, Marco Bailey all making the list, while DJ
>>> Mag's strong
>>> UK focus snagged places for local radio names such as Pete Tong,
>>> Judge Jules
>>> and Lisa Lashes. Psychedelic trance also proved popular with the
>>> likes of
>>> Infected Mushroom, Astrix and Yahel all placing highly.
>>>
>>> Curiously, plenty of votes came in for acts not really known for =20
>>> their
>>> DJing, including The Chemical Brothers, Daft Punk, Trentemoller, BT
>>> and
>>> Booka Shade.
>>>
>>> This year's poll was steeped in controversy, with a number of DJs,
>>> including
>>> Christopher Lawrence and DJ Dan, being disqualified amid
>>> accusations of
>>> vote-rigging <http://www.residentadvisor.net/news.aspx?id=3D8926>.
>>> This year
>>> DJ Mag collated the 345,000 cast votes in-house for the first time,
>>> and also
>>> instituted new rules to cut down on multiple-voting, a persistent
>>> problem
>>> with Internet polls. "This year, I made a decision to investigate
>>> votes
>>> where the same IP address appeared over 50 times for the same =20
>>> person,"
>>> explains publisher James Robertson on the DJ Mag website.
>>>
>>> *DJ Mag Top 100 2007*
>>>
>>> 1. Armin Van Buuren
>>> 2. Ti=EBsto
>>> 3. John Digweed
>>> 4. Paul Van Dyk
>>> 5. Sasha
>>> 6. Above & Beyond
>>> 7. Carl Cox

>>> 20. Marco V

----- Original Message ----
From: r4ph <sfraves@kiddzero.com>
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, October 31, 2007 8:22:01 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Nice shake!

It would be pretty hard to take down the US's interweb... There are dozens
of colo's just standing by in case some of the AS routers fail/die... All an
ISP needs to do is login and change the static route and fixed... It happens
daily... 

Here is an active monitor that will show when the interweb is having a
problem... 

www.internethealthreport.com 

I rely on sites like these to track where problems, for my customers, are in
routing to us. 

-r4ph

-----Original Message-----
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com [mailto:dangrsmind@yahoo.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, October 31, 2007 7:24 AM
To: Nyc W. Alberts; SFR
Cc: CHUCK G
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Nice shake!

Actually the whole resilance to nuclear attack thing is pretty overblown
depending on what you are talking about.  While it would be hard to bring
down the entire global Internet, taking out a specific country is not hard
and it has happened.  For example, the ruling junta in Myanmar shut down the
Internet to control information flow during the recent protests there.
Another example would be the Russian hacker attacks on Estonia following the
removal of a Soviet era war monument.

Here in the US, the Internet backbone consists in part of a number of
Internet Exchange Points which connect the various ISPs allowing them to
exchange data.  According to Wikipedia
(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Exchange_Point) there are only 20-30
of these in the United States located in a similar number of cities. If
these were taken out in their entirety some aspects of the public US
Internet might still work, but I wouldn't count on it.

Regards,

Peter

----- Original Message ----
From: Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com>
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Cc: CHUCK G <chuckg_421@yahoo.com>
Sent: Wednesday, October 31, 2007 7:37:51 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Nice shake!

Nyc W. Alberts wrote:

What I was saying: http://tinyurl.com/yu67zb

Imagine he knew JAVA or Perl, was bored, looking for a little excitement,
and instead of matches this kid had a keyboard and an anonymous connection.

....
.
umm, like, not to put to fine a point on it, such as, y'know, the whole
damned point of Al Gore creating the Internets was/is that it's a
decentralized communications system capable of withstanding *a full-on
nuclear attack* and still keeping all of out Nation's Military
Command\Control & Response structures in place.

>
> The fact that the NebWets turned into the greatest single repository 
> of human knowledge, since the Library of Alexandria, (and Sam Walton's 
> wildest strip mall/big box store fantasy, wet dream), in the blink of 
> an eye, was one of those unanticipated consequences that we hear so 
> much about.
>
> A couple of tectonic plates, miles below earth's surface, shrugging 
> their shoulders and scratching an itch, for a moment, is no cause for 
> alarm, the real threat of burning the thing down and having to start 
> over, from scratch, is from within.
>
> All you need is some idiot 15 year old kid out behind the barn, with a 
> book of matches in the form of 20 lines of malicious virus code that 
> can bring this bitch to its knees, and then you've got really 
> something to worry about and keep you up night.
>
> Speaking for nobody, I'd be much more concerned about that particular 
> scenario, than some random and rare 5+ pointer, that shook up a few 
> people, (that even took the time to bother to notice), before breakfast.
>
> As always, ymmv.
>
> PS: JC when you get to the Isle of Manhattan, gimme a call at 646 918
> 3656 I've a friend in Williamsburgh that you might like 2 meet.
>
> He's doing a modern day update of 1984 called "Winston's World" that 
> can  be found here: http://www.mrdrinkwater.com/

> ~Nyc
